DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1987-88[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1987-88APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1987-88]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88 and cognate Bills was interrupted last night, I was making the point that the Australian people deserve better from this Government than the inadequate response provided by this Budget to the current economic situation. A great shortcoming of the Budget is that it has destroyed the options for Australia in the face of any change in the international economic climate. That climate has changed with the stock market crash and, as a result, this Budget is sinking Australia further into the mire. This is magnified by the Government's failure to take correct initiatives since the stock market crash. Since that crash the Government has done two things. Firstly, it has allowed a 10 per cent devaluation of the Australian dollar. Secondly, it has supported a 7 per cent wage increase.
—A $7 wage increase.

—I thank Senator Hamer for his assistance. The Government has supported a $7 a week first tier wage increase. The 10 per cent devaluation will have a number of detrimental consequences for the Australian economy. It will add about one per cent to the consumer price index. It will add about $1 billion to our interest payments on our existing foreign debt, thereby worsening the invisibles on our balance of payments by $1 billion. The devaluation will also worsen our trade imbalance by some $300m. Finally, this devaluation once and for all destroys the myth, which has already been laid bare, that this is a balanced Budget. The inadequate response of the Government to the stock market crash will add a further $1 billion to the existing real deficit of between $2 billion and $3 billion in this Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night, I dealt extensively with the folly of allowing wage increases that are double those of our trading partners. For the Government to support first and second tier increases in the face of the impact of the stock market crash reveals its total irresponsibility. More accurately, it reveals a government controlled by trade union power. Lower global growth is an inevitable result of the stock market crash. Even though in reality the fall in stock market values is only back to the approximate levels of early last year, the psychological effect will be to reduce consumption and investment spending. This will obviously be reflected in Australia, so the 2 to 2 1/2 per cent rate of economic growth on which the Budget was predicated is more likely to be zero or even negative growth.

By increasing liquidity in our economy in the context of existing high liquidity, the Government is building up further long term problems for the economy in an effort to paper over its immediate problems. The longer the Government delays taking the hard decisions about appropriate remedial action-and those hard decisions are, first, a realistic approach to wage levels and, secondly, real and significant reductions in government spending, rather than the camouflage to which we have been treated in this Budget-the greater and more painful will be the adjustment required later. Senator Walsh accuses his leaders of complacency. That is not so. Complacency is an emotion reserved for junior Ministers. At the top is genuine, 100 per cent, gold plated, unadulterated smugness, overweening arrogance and preening self-satisfaction, and it is that, in part, that has resulted in the Government failing to take the necessary action to correct economic imbalances which are currently evident.

It does not require me to pass judgment on the failed economic management of this Government. The world economy has done that. In the recent crash in the stock markets around the world, values were discounted by some 20 to 30 per cent, but in Australia they were down by some 40 per cent. Clearly, the international financial markets are not impressed by our self-proclaimed world's greatest Treasurer (Mr Keating). The international financial markets obviously believe that the Government has lost control of fiscal and monetary policy, is unable to contain wage escalations and has presided over the greatest fall in living standards in Australian history. That is why it is important that the amendment that will be moved by the Opposition with regard to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is carried by this chamber. That amendment reads:
At end of motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(1) this Bill is part of a continuing pattern of failure by the Hawke Government to face up to the need for adequate and timely adjustment of the economy;
(2) this failure by the Hawke Government has heightened Australia's vulnerability to changes in world economic conditions at this time of crisis on world financial markets;

(3) because the Government has squandered time and resources while persistently running Australia into massive debt, our national economic options are now so narrowly limited as to largely deprive us of independent options; and

(4) the Government no longer has the scope to protect jobs, to stop the prospective rise in unemployment, to stem the continuing rise in numbers of Australians living in poverty or to protect the position of families more generally;

and therefore calls on the Government to revise its fiscal, labour market, taxation and other micro-economic policies with a view to providing a more appropriate economic framework to meet our current economic and social dangers''.

The points made in that foreshadowed amendment home in on our current economic difficulties and provide the alternative approach and the alternative strategy which must be adopted by this Government if it is to provide sound economic management over the next 12 months in light of the current international economic climate. Only an approach which adopts a much tougher stand on government spending and a much tougher approach to wage determination will, indeed, provide the climate in which Australia can weather the approaching storm. It is important that that foreshadowed amendment to the second reading motion be supported by this chamber.

In conclusion, while the Treasurer basks in the false euphoria of the phoney balanced Budget which I have highlighted during this debate, I offer him a real challenge; that is, to balance the average Australian family's household budget. I offer a quotation from Mr Keating's avowed hero, Thomas Jefferson. I think he had the Budget in mind when he said:
Indeed I tremble for my country when I reflect that God is just.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget is part of the continuing pattern of failure by this Government to face up to the need to adjust the economy to cope with the kinds of economic difficulties that we are trying to cope with at the moment. This is just one more failure by the Government. We have a government that has been prepared to fritter away our time and our money and leave us with an enormous foreign debt-previous speakers have referred to the size of that debt, $83 billion net-and a current account deficit that is far too high.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the policies of the last 4 1/2 years, we have run out of options. Australia is staring the lack of options squarely in the face. I believe that that was highlighted yesterday when most of the commentators in this nation breathed a sigh of relief and said, `Wow, we suffered only a $1.2 billion increase in our debt'. For goodness sake, what has the nation come to when we can countenance an increase of over $1 billion a month in our indebtedness? Have we lost all sense of reality? Can the Government possibly get off the hook when this is what the nation has been brought to? In making hay while the sun shines and failing to recognise that prudent governments should make provision for the future, the Government has squandered the good years that we have had and we are now having to cut back; but we are cutting back on the Government's responsibilities, including the most important responsibility of all-the defence of the country.

The current budgetary response to unfavourable economic conditions has been short term penny-pinching with no thought to the future. That is borne out by a number of the facts which have been revealed in the recent Estimates committee hearings. They reveal that not only has the Government failed in fiscal and monetary policy terms, but it has also failed in basic good housekeeping of the nation. We on this side of the Parliament recognise that all government departments have to tighten their belts in response to these tough economic times. These economic circumstances are not likely to improve in the short term; so it is more vital than ever that the moneys that are available to government departments are spent wisely and that savings are made where they can be made. But we have to be very careful to see that these savings are not short term savings at the expense of long term efficiency. That is what I mean by `good housekeeping'.

One of the most absorbing and worthwhile jobs which senators have to do, I believe, is serving on Estimates committees of the Senate in which the spending of government departments is scrutinised and seeing that money is being spent as wisely as possible. I am very concerned that money is not always being spent wisely and that decisions are being made which could be disastrous economically and disastrous in other ways in the long term.

I believe that two major responsibilities of government have to be satisfied before any thought can be given to expenditure in other areas. I think the two major responsibilities of government are the protection of law and order and the defence of the country. These are the concerns of the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Defence. Both departments were examined by Estimates Committee E, of which I am a member. Another very important area of responsibility for the Federal Government is the management of Commonwealth assets-assets which belong to the people of Australia. Those are the concerns of the Department of Administrative Services, which also comes before Estimates Committee E.

That Committee found evidence that in all three departments decisions are being made which are concerned more with short term economies than with long term efficiency. The maintenance of law and order, the security of our country and the effective management of our national assets are not expendable. They must be carried out to the best of our ability within the inevitable economic constraints.

In recent months fraud against the Commonwealth has been particularly newsworthy. It is a matter to which the Government, to give it credit, has been paying some attention. However, it has been a matter to which the Government has been giving attention on and off over the whole 4 1/2 years of its life. But action seems to be what has been lacking. The amount lost through fraud has never been clearly quantified but we know that it runs into billions of dollars. The estimates vary widely. The Attorney-General's Department has the responsibility for the detection and recovery of fraud against the Commonwealth but I believe that it is not being given the resources which are necessary to do the job as well as it might.

In 1985 the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) asked for 1,364 extra staff. In the last three years the police have had 294 more staff as a promised 3-year manpower increase. They certainly cannot be expected to give equal priority to and carry out with equal ability all of the jobs they are given. They have to juggle resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —That goes against the evidence given to you at the Estimates Committee.

—In no way does it go against the evidence. I think the honourable senator must have a very short memory. The officers sent to the hearings were very loyal but they had to admit that they did some jobs better than others and they had to make adjustments to their priorities. That is a very loyal way of saying, `We cannot do everything that we are expected to do as well as we are expected to do it'. They have enormous responsibilities. They have to deal with drug trafficking, organised crime, fraud against the Commonwealth, Australian Capital Territory policing, protection of internationally protected persons, coastal protection and counter terrorism, as well as with specific matters referred to the Australian Federal Police by the Commonwealth. They simply do not have a hope of doing all these things at the same time and they are limited by the fact that, naturally enough, most personnel have to specialise in areas of the highest priority. This limits their ability to shift their resources around to meet the changing priorities.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely further manpower is justified when the Australian Federal Police, like the Director of Public Prosecutions, is cost efficient in that what it recovers from its investigations pays for the resources outlaid on those investigations. If the AFP and the Director of Public Prosecutions were given the resources they would be able to achieve a great deal because, as I have said, they are cost effective. In the last two years the Director of Public Prosecutions has had judgments entered for nearly $97m and has actually collected $37m with more to come. I believe that it is a very effective way of paying for a service which is needed to protect the nation against fraud and to prevent people ripping off the system. The extra resources granted to the Director of Public Prosecutions during the time that that $37m was collected amounted to $5.8m. The benefits exceed the costs, therefore, by 6 1/2:1. Let me quote from the civil remedies report of the Director of Public Prosecutions, which states:

To pass legislation attacking crime or criminals is never, of itself, a sufficient response. What must then be done is to take the necessary administrative steps . . . adequate resources are a condition precedent to success in practice.
We need to spend money to get the money back for the Commonwealth.

The important thing to remember is that highly qualified people are needed in both the Australian Federal Police and the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, but those people are lost to private enterprise, which can pay them more. We must look at what we can do to recruit and keep good people. The Government must have the will to decide that it is prepared to put sufficient people on the payroll to solve the problems that exist-problems with priorities in the Australian Federal Police and problems with moneys outstanding to the Commonwealth that are not being brought in fast enough because of lack of resources.

In reference to the proceeds of crime legislation, which will give the Australian Federal Police wide-ranging powers to assist in following the money trail in major fraud investigations and in forfeiture of the proceeds of crime, the annual report of the Australian Federal Police states that `in order to fully utilise the legislation, the AFP will require not only additional resources but investigators with a high degree of specialisation'. I am not just talking about the benefits to the nation in money terms although, clearly, that is extremely important, especially when the Government is casting about for revenue and for savings in expenditure. If a matter being investigated has a key deterrent effect on others, surely criminals will be less inclined to think that they can get away with fraud, and Australia will be a more wholesome place as a result. Surely, that also must be an aim of a national government.

It is time we got our priorities right. In these tough times, programs such as Art in Working Life are still being funded, and they could well be funded by some of the wealthy unions that are the beneficiaries of such programs. We are still keeping the Constitutional Commission moving around the country in grand style at a great cost. We are installing spa baths and desks worth $5,000 each for parliamentarians in the new Parliament House. We are producing extremely costly publications, such as Windows onto Worlds, and we are funding John Brown's overseas trips. I was interested to learn that yesterday he said that he has spent only 7 per cent of his time as a Minister away on overseas trips. Only 7 per cent! They are the sorts of things on which the Government has been spending money. I question the Government's priorities, and I am sure Australians everywhere question those priorities when they are compared with the expense of recovering more of what is lost every day through fraud against the Commonwealth.

Government agencies seem to have little regard for getting value for money. I think of the Parliament House Construction Authority and the history of the Department of Housing and Construction. Both those bodies, I believe, have little appreciation of the fact that the dollars they are spending are the hard-won dollars earned by the taxpayers of Australia. It should be a priority to maximise the returns due to the Commonwealth and to perform the vital tasks of a government as efficiently as possible.

When referring to the question of management of Commonwealth assets, we must ensure that they are managed as effectively as possible so that a minimum is wasted and a minimum is lost through illegal activities. Despite some very public lessons in relation to the sale of Hercules aircraft, the Department of Administrative Services does not yet seem to have come to grips with the problem. The fraud report that I mentioned earlier had instructions to all Commonwealth departments that they are to put into place measures to prevent and detect fraud against their departments. The departments have had that report since about March this year, but I was concerned to find when the Department of Administrative Services appeared before the Estimates Committee that it is really still considering the matter.

The sale of Hercules aircraft has been a matter of national concern for a number of months and years. Clearly, the lessons that should have been learnt by the Department from that sale have not been taken on board and effective action has not been taken for the future. The Commonwealth has been defrauded of moneys under the Hercules aircraft contract-two contractors have failed the Department-and lessons should have been learnt. The fraud report made it clear that all departments had to upgrade their techniques. I shall quote from a report of Estimates Committee E, which states:
The Committee also examined in some detail a number of issues arising from the proposed sale of surplus Hercules aircraft.

Government purchasing and sales activities are obviously areas where, unless proper safeguards are in place, fraudulent practices may occur. In particular, where novel selling options arise there is a need to ensure that adequate checks, controls and fraud prevention measures have been developed to minimise and preferably eliminate any potential for fraud in new ventures where official experience may be less extensive than in other areas. The Committee considers that it is important that the lessons to be learnt from the way in which the Hercules matter has been processed should not be overlooked.
Mr Holdich, departmental Deputy Secretary, told the Committee:

We are looking at the recommendations of the fraud inquiry. We are seeing in what ways we need to alter our arrangements to take account of the recommendations of that committee. We have already taken steps to strengthen the arrangements in the purchasing and sales area so that these sorts of problems that we have had in the past should not recur. We have not finalised precisely what we are going to do-we still have a couple more months to work that out-but action is being taken to try to strengthen the arrangements to prevent these sorts of abuses in the future.
The Committee also states:

. . . that there is always a need for high standards of official care and diligence in devising methods to minimise the incidence of fraud in government purchasing and sales activities. Finalisation of precise and effective procedures requires serious and urgent attention.

I did not get the impression from the answers received that that serious and urgent attention was being addressed. I may be being unfair-I am sure that Senator Ray would consider that I am-but the answer that the Committee received from the Deputy Secretary was like one received from Sir Humphrey: `We are looking at it. We are seeing in what ways we should do it. We have not finalised it precisely'. I am not satisfied with that because I am concerned that the Department, which is dealing with Commonwealth assets worth millions of dollars and which is dealing with Commonwealth contracts, should be an extremely efficient organisation. The fraud report should have been one on which action was being taken to implement the recommendations as fast as possible. The Department should not have said that it still had `a couple more months to work that out'. I should have hoped that with the experiences the Department has had in the past it would have worked it out already.

I now turn to security. Some of the responsibility for our internal security, for example, in relation to airports, lies with the AFP. They are constrained by a lack of manpower in the same way as the defence forces, as I said earlier. We were told by the Department that the resources are sufficient to meet the level of threat as it currently exists. But one cannot go on talking down the threat to meet the resources that are available, and I suspect that that is what is being done. We must be prepared for the unexpected. I suspect that `to meet the level of threat as it currently exists' means that one is writing the threat once one knows what one's resources are.

That is the situation that applies in regard to the defence forces today. Mr Dibb, who reported on the Australian defence situation for the Government only last year, said that a 3 per cent real increase was needed each year to meet credible contingencies. But the appropriation has already been whittled away this year to a one per cent reduction in real terms. In reality, the defence of the country cannot be maintained for any length of time against even a low level threat because of the drain on manpower in our defence forces.

The lack of care that the Government has shown for this problem is evident in the Budget cut for the repair and maintenance of defence housing. The cut is not huge; it is $1.3m. In national Budget terms, it represents a drop in the bucket. However, it is one more blow to the service families. The lack of maintenance of defence homes in the past has been the very reason that so many of the homes have become sub-standard. The Department considers 60 per cent of defence housing to be sub-standard. To allow the maintenance of defence houses to drop by even the smallest amount is, firstly, a waste of Commonwealth assets, which we cannot afford, and, secondly, it puts one more nail in the coffin of Australia's defence, because the inadequate housing for our defence families is well recognised to be one of the major reasons why today the defence forces have such a high wastage rate. What could be more degrading to one's quality of life than living in a substandard home, frequently in a very substandard area of the nation?

We have been hearing in recent weeks of how proud the Government is of the fact that, at long last, it has established the Defence Housing Authority. The legislation to set up this body, which was in the pipeline for nearly two years, has finally gone through the Parliament. But at the very time it was going through the Parliament, the Government was cutting back on repairs and maintenance of existing defence housing. It is just incredible and beyond belief how the Government can even contemplate such a move when the drain in manpower is costing a fortune in terms of training replacements.

It would be a worthwhile investment if the necessary money to carry out repairs were made available as soon as possible. If this were done, savings would be made in the recruitment and training costs of the personnel who are needed to replace those people who can no longer put up with the conditions. Mr Acting Deputy Presi-dent, I want to draw your attention to last year's figures. It was revealed that last year it cost Australia $91m to recruit and train-that is just for basic training, not corps training or any further advanced training-the replacements for the 8,614 men and women who left in 1985-86. This year we have lost 8,919 people-that is, 300-odd more than the year before. So the figures are up again. In this coming year, with the way separation rates are going, it looks as if we will be replacing 10,000 people. I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it cost us $91m for basic training and recruiting to make up for the 1985-86 separations. We cannot afford to lose that sort of money. That is what I am talking about when I say that there has been bad housekeeping.

Not only is this Government bad at running the economy in every other area; it is also short-sighted in its basic housekeeping. Some of that $91m could have been invested effectively in improving the quality of life of these people so that the families do not say, `That is it. We are off'. Service families are now taking matters into their own hands and in an unprecedented way they are holding public meetings right around the country. Many service people are leaving and they tend to be the people with a lot of experience. The cost of basic training does not tell the story at all because we are losing people of senior non-commissioned officer and middle officer rank who are older and usually married. The high separation rates are being caused by the effect of service conditions on their families.

We constantly hear about the pilots. They are not, by any means, the only people who are leaving. They are just somehow more colourful and perhaps more newsworthy. The pilots we are losing have between six and 16 years of experience. A large number of them are qualified flying instructors. It is criminal that we are losing them as they are very difficult to replace. Let us not forget that we are also losing our computer operators, engineers, ground engineers, ground staff and signals people-people who can still expect to get a good job outside the defence forces even though our unemployment rate is running at 8.2 per cent. When unemployment is high the defence forces, traditionally, do not have high wastage rates. The fact that we have such high separation rates at this time means that the people leaving are really very desperate. Of course, we are losing the very best qualified and most experienced people and therein lies the terrible seriousness for the country. Air Vice-Marshal Bradford told the Estimates Committee E that service people are leaving for quality of life reasons.

The Royal Australian Navy has also had its problems. It is having great difficulty in finding crews for our submarines. I do not believe that we have a full complement of submariners. The position had been helped by the very satisfactory increase in the submariners allowance some months ago. Clearly, a very major part of the problem is that allowances just have not kept up with the times and people will not stay around and put up with unsatisfactory quality of life when their pay is not keeping up. Pay is not the only factor but it obviously contributes to the difficulties.

We have difficulties with landing craft which are laid up in Cairns because, we are told, we do not have the manpower to maintain them. What if we had to conduct a landing anywhere around the coast of Australia or amongst our near neighbours? We have island territories such as Christmas Island, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Island. We have to think about these things if we are really serious about defending the people of Australia. Yet clearly we are shortsighted in regard to our expenditure within the defence vote, quite apart from the fact that the defence vote has been cut so seriously. These decisions are affecting our very ability to defend the country.

I draw attention to the effect on the defence vote of the drop in the Australian dollar. The Australian dollar was estimated in the Budget only a few weeks ago to have an exchange rate of US71c-today it is US69c. The 2c difference may not mean a lot to many people, to the man in the street, but it is very serious because last year 62.2 per cent of the defence equipment and stores vote was spent overseas and the vote in this year's Budget for capital expenditure on equipment and stores is $2,590,319,000. That is an enormous amount of money. Any change in the exchange rate immediately has an impact on our ability to equip ourselves. So when this Government is so careless about the future in its fiscal and monetary policy, when it is careless about its housekeeping, we all pay for this in a host of hidden ways, some of which will be seen by many people only when it is too late.

In these times it is extremely important that the country, its assets and its people are made as secure as possible. We cannot afford to continue to lose billions of dollars through fraud. We have to provide the resources to allow fraud to be thwarted. We cannot afford to allow corruption or lack of manpower to erode law and order in this country. We cannot afford to allow Australia to be vulnerable to attack. To allow these basic responsibilities of a national government to slip is not economically sensible; it is quite irresponsible. I believe that the priorities of this Government are quite misplaced. We simply cannot afford to have all the programs that we have become used to having but which are essentially luxuries at the expense of programs which are vital. I can only hope that the Government will see reason and will address this imbalance and allocate its resources more efficiently to meet our most urgent needs. I consider it a disgrace that we have been brought to this situation by a government which has had the time to make the adjustments necessary to enable Australia to become more productive and so put a stop to the growth in our foreign debt. But the cupboard is now bare. We have all been encouraged to make the most of the good times for as long as they last. We have all been encouraged to eat cake. We will be lucky if in the future we can be guaranteed bread and cheese.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) and of course to support the Opposition's amendment. It is interesting to look at the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and in particular the Government's economic strategy included in that speech. The Treasurer stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's policy response has been innovative, strong, and most of all, right.
Notwithstanding the enormity of the trade difficulties we have faced, our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.

It was obvious from Senator Walsh's subsequent comments that he did not agree. He referred, as everyone is aware, to some 200 programs which could be cut by a government with the courage to do so. I find it fascinating and somewhat hypocritical that as regular as clockwork Senator Walsh comes in here and demands to see the cuts which would be proposed by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, and others and yet as a senior Minister in this Government he is coy about divulging his own list of 200 programs. I would be interested to hear that some time from Senator Walsh. In fact, if he named them, it might take some of the heat out of the current Caucus room debate on privatisation.

Even before the stock market crash, Senator Walsh had quite justifiable reservations about the lack of real courage by this Government to address government expenditure. The Treasurer said that the Labor Government's economic strategy is now bearing fruit. Let us have a look at some of that fruit. Since this Hawke Labor Government came to power gross foreign debt has increased from $34 billion to $109 billion. Net foreign debt has increased from some $21 billion to approximately $83 billion. The Treasurer has blamed big trade deficits in the early 1980s for the build-up in the foreign debt burden, which is patently not correct. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for our current account balance show a deficit for 1984-85 of $11 billion; for 1985-86, $14.5 billion; for 1986-87, $13.6 billion; and so far, including yesterday's figures for October, for 1987-88, $4.75 billion. I find it extraordinary, as do other speakers from this side, that somehow a figure of approximately $1.2 billion for the month of October is looked upon as something good. It is an appalling balance of payments figure. It is an improvement on the figure for the equivalent month last year but I compare it, for instance, with the final year of the Fraser Government. I believe the figure was something like $600m for the same month. So it is double what it was for October in 1983-84 when the policies of the previous Liberal-National Party Government were in effect. So foreign debt is out of control.

I turn to interest rates. I think one must always be careful to point out that interest rates in Australia are important relative to competing nations. The prime bank rate is the one that we should all look at because that is the rate available to some parts of the private sector. It has constantly been more than double that of our trading partners. I ask: Is it any wonder that, in an effort to compete, the private sector has chased funds from overseas and thus lifted the level of the private sector overseas debt? At least the private sector overseas debt can be serviced because it has been put to productive use. One cannot say the same about government overseas debt. In regard to taxation, I think it is worth quoting Thomas Jefferson's inaugural presidential address, in 1801, when he said:

A wise and frugal government, which shall restrain men from injuring one another, which shall leave them otherwise free to regulate their own pursuits of industry and improvement, and shall not take from the mouth of labour the bread that it has earned . . .
This Government has been very adept at taking from the mouth of labour the bread that it has earned. It has talked loud and long about tax reform. The Treasurer, in his Budget Speech, bragged:
We have done it the right way-by better targeting government spending and by repairing and reforming the tax system.

The fact is that this is the highest taxing, highest spending government in Australia's history. In June 1983 Government receipts totalled $48.5 billion. As at June 1988 the Budget estimate is $78.12 billion-an increase of 61 per cent in four years under this Labor Government. The volume of tax legislation in the last two years has exceeded that of the previous 40 years. It has become even more complicated. There has not been the simplification promised to us by the incumbent Government. There are few accountants who would not agree that we have one of the most complicated tax systems. For instance, it is absolutely impossible for anyone to understand the capital gains tax. In fact, there are only a few accountants who really know what the Government is on about.

Let us look at another of the fruits of this Government-inflation. Our inflation rate is running at about 9 per cent, or perhaps a little higher. Let us compare the figures. As at May this year, the latest month for which I have figures available, for comparative purposes, Australia's inflation rate was 9.3 per cent. It is true that it has recently come down to about the 9 per cent figure. Japan's inflation rate at that time was minus 0.4 per cent, the figure for Holland was minus 1.1 per cent, the United Kingdom, 4.2 per cent and the United States (US) 3.8 per cent. The only countries ahead of us on the inflationary scale are Greece, Iceland, New Zealand, Norway and Turkey.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spain.

—And Spain. I thank Senator Ray. A figure that is not often cited is that of wholesale prices. I think it provides a guide as to what the future inflation rate will be. I think it is worth looking at the latest edition of the Economist, which compares wholesale prices in various countries throughout the world. Wholesale prices in Australia were running at 8.4 per cent, West Germany, minus 1.7 per cent, Holland, minus 0.1 per cent, Japan, minus 0.2 per cent-so there were decreases in prices in those countries-and the United Kingdom, 3.5 per cent. So our wholesale prices, which are indicative of what lies ahead of us in regard to inflation, are about eight to nine times higher than prices in countries like West Germany and Japan. This is the unhappy situation foisted on the so-called lucky country by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The question one has to ask, of course, is: What has the Government done about it? It has done one or two things. Firstly, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has leaked to the media the contents of his letter to the President of the United States, demanding that the US cut its deficit. Secondly, the Treasurer, in an address to the Fabian Society in Melbourne, tipped a bucket over the Whitlam Government, acknowledging the great and lasting damage done to the Australian economy by the last Labor Government. Obviously, he was working on the basis that, after a certain passage of time, one can follow the practices of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and China and tip a bucket over a previous leader and a previous government. That enlightened discovery could have been heightened by the acknowledgment of the great damage done to our manufacturing industry by the then president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, who is now the Prime Minister of this country.

Everyone surely knows that, if we are to get out of this mess, we have to become more productive. Our unit costs of production must be reduced so that our exports are more competitive and so that we can move with confidence into import replacement. The key ingredients for this to happen, the sorts of things that will make people invest in enterprises that are either export oriented or import replacement oriented, are as follows: our interest rates must be equal to or lower than those of our trading partners. As I have shown, this is patently not the case in Australia. Our interest rates are two to three times higher than those of our trading partners. There must be new capital investment. The recent collapse of the dollar, of course, means higher prices for essential capital equipment, which must be imported if we are to become more productive.

Labour unit costs of production must also be competitive. While wages are a large part of the cost, many other factors must be addressed in regard to labour unit costs, and not just talked about. Restrictive work practices which were foisted upon this country and on industries in more affluent times must be abandoned. We cannot afford to talk about trading off dollars to get rid of practices which have destroyed industry and jobs; they must be abandoned. Restrictive work practices really mean being paid for not working. The most common, of course, is what is termed `featherbedding', which means two or three people doing the job of one. These practices are endemic throughout Australia. They are a major cause of the increases in the unit costs of production, and thus our lack of competitiveness. They exist in every industry one looks at. Australia, which is an island continent, has some of the highest seaboard costs in the world. I mention also costs in the construction industry, as exemplified by some of the practices we have recently seen with the new Parliament House, the mining industry, the transport industry, educational institutions, the public sector, and so on. There was, and regrettably still is, an attitude in Australia that, if three or four people are doing work which can be done by one or two, somehow that will help the level of employment. That is a recipe for long term unemployment because it makes us less competitive. It is also a disincentive for investment.

It was a great error of judgment for the Government to support the national wage rise of $7 a week. It has been reported to me that when Cabinet discussed whether it would oppose or support a $7 a week increase, Mr Kelty sat outside the door of the Cabinet room to make sure it supported it. We know who is calling the shots in this country. We cannot pay ourselves more when the world economy is moving in the other direction. I do not wish to fuel gloomy talk of a recession, but none other than Mr Rupert Murdoch was recently quoted as saying:
I would be very surprised if we don't have a recession in this country within the next few months.

He is also quoted as saying that he expected that the stock market crash would have a greater impact on consumer confidence in Australia than in any other country. We must wind back debt, not run the risk of increasing it with a wage rise, which may increase imports and blow out the current account deficit even further. The Australian newspaper on Friday, 30 October 1987, when discussing last week's national wage case, put it this way:

It is difficult to imagine any action that the Federal Government could take that would be more dangerous to Australia's economy than the submission it has made to the Arbitration Commission at its hearing on the national wage case.

The message being shouted to the world is that this country does not take the financial crisis seriously and is so dependent on the good graces of the leaders of the trade union movement that the achievement of a spurious industrial peace is of more concern than our long-term economic survival.

While all this was happening, figures just released show a sharp rise in the unemployment figures. The rise in the October unemployment figure is disturbing to everyone. It appears that Australia remains locked in to an unemployment level of around 8 per cent or more. The United States, for instance, has an unemployment level of 6 per cent. Our level of 8 per cent compares very unfavourably with that.

If this were not enough, figures have also just been released which show that industrial disputes rose to their highest level of the year in July. Mark Davis, writing in the Australian Financial Review of 17 November, said that the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures showed that after a sharp fall in the level of industrial disputes during the election campaign in June it more than doubled in July to its highest monthly level this year. That is another cynical example, if one were needed, of unions managing to keep the lid on things long enough to disguise their real intent-to ensure that their party gets back into power.

The growth in the list of our country's economic woes in four short years is almost unbelievable. We just seem to lurch from one crisis to another. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer are obviously totally unwilling or totally incapable of doing anything about it. The Government's response to the stock market crash and our precarious economy reminds me of that little rhyme made famous by Hughes Mearns:
As I was going up the stair, I saw a man who wasn't there.
He wasn't there again today, I wish, I wish he'd stay away.

Ignoring the issue and wishing it would go away is of no help to Australia whatsoever. Australia is locked in to the global economy. The world has changed. Government policy must be flexible enough to react to that change. Of course, the question is whether it is too late. Has this Government frittered away the opportunity? I think it has. That is what is reflected in the Opposition amendment, which states:
At end of motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(1) this Bill is part of a continuing pattern of failure by the Hawke Government to face up to the need for adequate and timely adjustment of the economy;
(2) this failure by the Hawke Government has heightened Australia's vulnerability to changes in world economic conditions at this time of crisis on world financial markets;

(3) because the Government has squandered time and resources while persistently running Australia into massive debt, our national economic options are now so narrowly limited as to largely deprive us of independent options; and

(4) the Government no longer has the scope to protect jobs, to stop the prospective rise in unemployment, to stem the continuing rise in numbers of Australians living in poverty or to protect the position of families more generally;

and therefore calls on the Government to revise its fiscal, labour market, taxation and other micro- economic policies with a view to providing a more appropriate economic framework to meet our current economic and social dangers''.

There has been inaction by the Treasurer and reliance by him on the J-curve. We do not hear too much about the J-curve these days but the theory of the J-curve was: collapse the dollar-diminish the value of our currency on international markets-thus making our exports more competitive. The theory was that a lower dollar would increase the cost of our imports thus creating more import replacement and, Q.E.D., the problem would be solved. The Treasurer persisted with reliance on that simple exercise. It did not work. It did not work for a number of reasons, which I will not go into at this stage. Notwithstanding the reservations of Senator Button with regard to that, what has happened is that the Government, by just pursuing this course of action and doing nothing else, has got us in the position where we really do not have a feather to fly with. We are arguably in one of the most economically precarious situations in the history of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88 and cognate Bills and as they apply, in particular, to this nation's Bicentenary. There has been a lot of talk about the economy in this debate and I will be commenting on the economy later in my speech. Perhaps first, though, we could have a little change of outlook in regard to what is going on. The Australian Bicentennial Authority will spend $136m on this wonderful occasion. There have been attempts, and no doubt there will be more attempts, to play down the event. It is my belief that, no matter who we are, there should be no reason why a majority of Australians should not be able to celebrate their 200th birthday. People are expecting a celebration and funds have been allocated. I am rather disappointed that Senator Wood is not in the chamber-he was supposed to speak prior to me-because I intended to mention something that he said in his maiden speech. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have a vision for the Bicentennial. I see the Bicentennial as a time when, rather than celebrate a manufactured history put together in some public relations sweat shop and sold to us the way they sell margarine and jeans, there should be a true reappraisal of Australian history so we can move on from there.

I hope that his view is not shared by too many people in Australia. I do not think it is. The facts of the matter are that most Australians have had ties with Australia for 200 years. Senator McGauran is one of our newer imports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on! There will be a personal explanation about that one.
—I will say something about that later that might interest you, Senator McGauran.
—Senator McKiernan.

—I am sorry. Senator McGauran was sitting here a moment ago. I wish to congratulate the Bicentennial Authority on the way it has tried to produce a balanced, very interesting and constructive program for 1988. Of course, much of the money is coming from the Federal Government, but much also is coming from the people-State and local government and private enterprise. It is truly a community exercise; so it should be. Regardless of all the criticism we have, we should be looking forward to it with great anticipation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will mention some of the community projects. If I can be somewhat parochial, Madam Acting Deputy President, you will be as pleased as I am to see that my State, Tasmania, will be represented at World Expo 88. We are looking forward to going to the great State of Queensland and being part of the Expo celebrations. Of course, it is unfortunate, and it is becoming more evident, that people from around the world who want to come to Australia in 1988 will be able to do so only with much difficulty. It has been reported to me that, for instance, there are standby waiting lists on international flights up to February or March next year. That is quite unacceptable. The Government has a responsibility and it should have realised that one cannot just go out and advertise a great event like our Bicentenary and not take note of this, among other things. I suppose that it is as a result of the economy and our dollar being so low that people want to come here on the cheap and see what we have. It seems that we do not have enough flights coming in. Belatedly, I think Senator Gareth Evans has made some arrangements with Qantas Airways Ltd. But I think that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, will be aware that these proposals will not come in until 1 October. World Expo 88 concludes on 31 October, so that will be a big help!

Let me return to a list of things that will be happening during the Bicentenary. In Tasmania, the major projects, both ongoing ones and those of a more permanent nature, will cost about $10.4m, of which $2.3m is to come from the Commonwealth Government and $6.3m from the State, with local government, particularly the Glenorchy City Council, paying $1.7m. The Derwent Centre in Hobart, which will cost $7.6m, will probably be the most expensive and best remembered bicentennial project in Tasmania. It is something that is needed in the south of the State, and will be an entertainment centre of world class. There are other projects, such as the athletics centre at Penguin costing $900,000 and the Dowling Street stadium at Launceston costing $1.5m. A National Trust of Australia restoration fund, to restore some of our beautiful old buildings, will raise about $300,000.

The community activities will be of great interest to everybody. For instance, in my munici-pality we are planning to restore the oldest farm building in Australia, dating from about 1806. The restoration of a farm building that old and the relocation of artefacts and evidence of our history over the last 200 years into an area like that are things that we can enjoy for many years, and they will give people an idea of what a great country we have and the amount of work that has gone into this great country of Australia over the past 200 years. Diverse activities are planned around Tasmania. For instance, on Flinders Island there are plans to extend the local museum and establish native gardens and carry out tree plantings. The penitentiary chapel and criminal courts are being improved. The wind-driven sails at the Callington Mill will once again turn. Everybody knows that Tasmania is well known for superfine wools, and the Tasmanian Wool Museum in the historic village of Ross will show the history and development in the area of this important industry. Even an old hotel that served the goldfields of Mangana is to be renovated.

The major bicentennial project in the City of Launceston is the creation of an urban forest close to the centre of the city. These are all very tangible innovations for our bicentennial year and I believe that they are projects that will put their mark on our State for many years to come. There will be many major sporting centres, most importantly the athletic stadium in Launceston and the Derwent Centre at Glenorchy. We shall host the world pennyfarthing championships. While these are all reasonably minor events, I am leading up to one of the two main events being promoted by the Commonwealth Government during the bicentenary year and for which funds of about $6.8m are being provided-the magnificent tall ships race from Hobart to Sydney. If anybody is intending to travel to Hobart, I can assure him that it is the only place, apart from Sydney, where one can see all these tall ships together.

We are proud and pleased to have many international vessels coming to Australia for the Bicentenary. It is interesting to note that quite a few of these tall ships are already on their way. The Young Endeavour, the British gift to Australia, has already arrived in Western Australia. The annual report of the Australian Bicentennial Authority shows that, owing to a visit from the now demoted Hon. Barry Cohen, MP to five South American countries-I am sure that he must have had a wonderful time-two tall ships are coming from South America. At least he was successful in one of his overseas jaunts. I just hope that Mr John Brown was just as successful for Australia in his more recently publicised overseas visit.

The Tall Ships Race 1988 will focus world attention on Australia, and this is the first time that such a spectacular gathering of vessels will be seen in the Southern Hemisphere. It is the biggest gathering of tall ships since the salute to the Statue of Liberty in America. One can see that we are looking forward with a great deal of hope. I trust that it will not bore the Senate too much if I list some of the overseas vessels that will be coming to Hobart. Those vessels represent many countries, large and small. A 13-metre ketch is coming from the principality of Andorra. From Ecuador comes a 78-metre barque called the Guayas. Another ship coming as a result of Barry Cohen's persuasions is the Captain Miranda, a 60-metre schooner from Uruguay. India will be represented by Varuan, a 29-metre brig. I point out to Senator McKiernan that Ireland will be represented by Asgard II, a 31-metre brigantine, and I am sure that, if he can find his way south to Hobart, the crew will be more than happy to trade some Irish whisky with him.

Switzerland will be represented by the Galatea, a 22-metre ketch. Spain will be represented by one of the most famous tall ships in the world, the Juan Sebastian Del Cano, a 113-metre barquentine. Our friends from Oman will be represented by the Shabab Oman, a 54-metre barquentine. The Netherlands is sending the Abel Tasman-not the one that plies between Melbourne and Devonport, but a 23-metre schooner. Poland will be sending a magnificent 108-metre fully rigged ship, the Dar Mlodziezq, on which there are young Australian crew members. New Zealand will be represented by the Spirit of New Zealand. As I have said, the United Kingdom will be represented by the Young Endeavour, its $4m bicentenary gift to Australia. This sail training vessel will be used around Australia in the years to come and it will be a great memorial to our bicentenary year. The United States of America will be represented by The Eagle, a 90-metre barque which is that country's most famous tall ship.

Germany has a tall ship coming, the Gorch Fock. Japan will be represented by the Nippon Maru. I am led to believe that Italy and Russia have leased tall ships to compete in the event. A great variety of international vessels will be coming to Hobart. They will be complemented by our own. Some States have tall ships either under construction or already constructed. In my own State we have a replica of one of the most famous early vessels in Australia's history. I refer to the Lady Nelson. It is currently being built in Tasmania and is being funded by Tasmanians. I am hopeful that that vessel will be competing in the tall ships race from Hobart to Sydney. Interestingly enough, the Lady Nelson was probably Australia's first armed naval vessel. It played a big part in the early history of Australia; in fact, it investigated and charted Port Phillip Bay and it carried disenchanted settlers from Norfolk Island to a place called New Norfolk in Tasmania. It had a very colourful history. Unfortunately, it ended up on an island called Baba Island, north-east of Timor, where the crew were slaughtered and the ship was burned. Nevertheless, Tasmanians will be very proud to have the Lady Nelson competing in that event.

Although nominations do not close until the end of November, it has already been confirmed that at least another 150 vessels will be participating in the event, such as maxi-yachts and privately owned tall ships. I would like to detail to the Senate both the role and the importance of the tall ships to Tasmania and, in particular, to its capital city of Hobart. As Australia's second oldest city and the site of one of the world's most beautiful harbours, situated in the Derwent estuary, it is fitting that Hobart should be chosen as the starting point for the vessel race to Sydney. It reminds me of the early days when grain clippers raced from Tasmania to Sydney to feed the starving colony. It is certainly going to be the most spectacular event in Tasmania's recent history. We estimate that Hobart's population will increase by half. That will mean that almost 100,000 people will flock to the capital to witness this unique event. From the day the ships converge on Hobart, on 10 January, 5,000 young people will be living on the various vessels moored in the Derwent River. For those honourable senators who are not aware, most of the crews of these international ships and yachts will range between 18 and 20 years of age.

As I said, along with about 200 to 250 of these vessels, we will have ocean liners and warships all round the harbour. For the uninitiated, a tall ship is defined as any sailing vessel with a minimum waterline length of 9.14 metres. Of those competing in the event, half the crew must be young people. As well as that, there will be other races for rated yachts. To cope with the influx, streets along the Hobart waterfront are to be cordoned off to create a huge pedestrian mall. Shops in the city are to be granted extended hours and the famous Salamanca market will operate on a daily basis. At the height of the celebration the docks will be illuminated by decorative lighting from the ships. I am pleased to say that I am aware already that my Party Whip, Senator Reid, and her husband will be attending. I just hope that quite a lot of the other senators have had their appetites whetted and will be going down to Hobart in January.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll try to get there.

—I thank the honourable senator. On 14 January the 200-plus vessels participating in the Hobart to Sydney tall ships race will be escorted by four warships, two cruise ships and thousands of spectator craft in a massive parade of sail on the Derwent River to the starting line in Storm Bay. It is envisaged that this will result in a line of ships and sails stretching for 15 kilometres down our wonderful river. At 1430 hours, following a salute to the reviewing officer off the John Jarrow light, the fleet will head to Sydney. I believe the Governor-General will be starting that race.

SPEECH.PARA: Such events do not come without cost. I referred earlier to the $6.8m that the Australian Bicentennial Authority has allocated for this wonderful event. At least half a million dollars will be spent on the provision of emergency and other services by local authorities, such as the police and the State Emergency Service. In Sydney there is to be a parade of sail on the harbour on 26 January, the day after Britain hands over its magnificent gift that I mentioned, the Young Endeavour. I am very proud that my State is playing such a significant role in this once in a lifetime event. As I said earlier, it brings together vessels and young sailing trainees from Europe, Asia and North and South America. I know that the generous hospitality and friendship for which Tasmania has a world-wide reputation will, once again, come to the fore. Perhaps we should not forget that the ultimate aim and legacy of the Tall Ships Race 1988 will be the establishment of a national program of sail training for Australia's young people, with all the associated benefits that go with it. Equally important will be the international good will and bonds of friendship between Australia and other nations which will flow from this event.

As I mentioned earlier, other things will be happening in 1988 all round Australia. I think 1988 is a year that we should be celebrating and one in which we should look back on our history, but it is also one in which thinking Australians should be very careful. I do not believe that 1988 is a year that we should get carried away and start wrecking our Constitution. There has been some talk about changes to our Constitution and changes to our flag. I know that some people in the Government are keen on changing our flag and are talking about having a republic. I believe that 1988 is a time to reflect on our history and to retain our ties and our local identity.

I repeat that 1988 is a once-off event. We will have to wait at least another 200 years for the next event. None of us will be here to see it. Let us hope that the people of Australia will shake off the feeling of doom and gloom that seems to pervade the country at this time when we look at what is happening to our economy. It will be a good opportunity for the Government to show some leadership to this country in an economic sense. It might start taking notice of some of its members who seem to be talking economic sense-I refer to Senator Peter Walsh, of course. In 1988, if the Government is so inclined, it could give Australia the best bicentenary birthday present it could receive; that is, some tough economic decisions that will set Australia on the right path.

Mr Hawke has been talking about export heroes. In looking at the forward figures I noted with a lot of pride and interest that Tasmania and Queensland are the only two States that have expectations above the national average. I hope that those export heroes will get the encouragement that Mr Hawke talks about. The Government should take note and set us on the economic path that we have all been asking for and talking about in the debates over the last day or so.

In conclusion, I am proud to be associated with and talk on the allocation to the Australian Bicentennial. There will be a lot of debate about what is going on in 1988, but it is probably the last time we will hear anybody in the Senate talking about it, particularly with regard to the tall ships event. I earnestly implore all members of the Parliament who can make the time available to go to Hobart to see one of the greatest events that will happen in 1988. I thank the Bicentennial Committee once again for the amount of work it has put into making this, hopefully, such a success.
