TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use the opportunity of this debate on the Appropriation Bills to look in some detail at the impact on women of government decisions in the last few years and of the current economic situation in particular. I do so in a spirit of generosity and helpfulness towards the Department of the Treasury since it seems to be unable to work out exactly what the impact has been and how it should assess these things. In fact, it seems to be unaware of the fact that decisions that have been made by Treasury, by the Department of Finance and by the Government generally have had quite a severe impact on women and their children in Australia over the last few years. At least that appears to be the case if the statement from Treasury in the Women's Budget Statement 1987-88 is any indication. On page 279 of the Budget document, under the heading `Impact on Women', we find the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Macroeconomic policies have a major impact on the living standards of all Australians, through, for example, policies which determine the overall level of Government spending or the level of interest rates.
The Treasury contribution to the Women's Budget Statement also states:

It is difficult however to determine a particular impact on women as there are no accurate means by which to measure the relative burdens and benefits of macro-economic decision on the basis of gender.

I would just like to add at this point that Treasury could actually try asking some women in the community what the impact has been of some of these macroeconomic decisions. If it does not want to do that, if that is too difficult, it could try reading some of the studies that have been brought forward by organisations, such as the Institute of Family Studies, that have looked at the relatively severe impact on women, families and children of government macroeconomic decisions over the years. The Treasury statement goes on:
Nevertheless, women as lower average wage earners pay less average income tax than men due to our progressive tax rate scales and tend to benefit less from tax concessions.

So I suppose in a way Treasury has acknowledged, somewhat indirectly, that some of the policy changes that it has made in the last few years have not had much benefit as far as women are concerned. Treasury finishes its contribution on the impact of budgetary measures on women by saying:
Women and their children will be the major beneficiaries of the new Child Support Agency in the Tax Office. And women will welcome improved price surveillance activities.

All I can say to that is `big deal'. It is certainly little enough to make up for some of the dramatic impacts on women that have occurred recently through government policy decisions. I think we need to get an acknowledgment from Treasury, not that women will welcome improved price surveillance activities or that they will be major beneficiaries of the new Child Support Agency in the Australian Taxation Office, but that a little direct help is necessary instead of Treasury and the Department of Finance still depending on the outmoded, discredited, trickle-down theory to improve the lot of women and their children in Australia-direct assistance of the sort given, for example, to the banks and the oil companies a year or so ago when they claimed that they were being affected by national and international economic events and policy decisions. If it is possible for Treasury to take direct action to help some of the wealthiest companies in this country get over some of the real or imagined problems they are facing as a consequence of economic conditions, both nationally and internationally, it ought to be possible, even for Treasury, to come up with some decisions that will not have an adverse dramatic impact on women and their children in Australia.

The fact is, of course, that the economic problems facing women and their children are not new in this country. Historically, this group has suffered disproportionately when there has been an economic crisis and, again, it takes longer to recover when an upturn occurs. The reason, of course, is fairly obvious. That group essentially is powerless and voiceless, unlike the wealthy and well-known entrepreneurs in the community who can command headlines apparently at will and therefore are in a position to bully governments into increasing corporate welfare expenditure at the expense of social welfare expenditure. Whenever times become hard, or whenever they appear to be so for one of the better-off, more powerful sections of the community, the newspapers carry headlines quoting some corporate giant or another calling for a reduction in government expenditure. Now what they mean by a cut in government expenditure, of course, is cuts to supporting parent benefits, cuts to health care-and they generally include in that total the abolition of Medicare-cuts to education funding and so on.

Needless to say, if all these things were implemented they would have a direct impact on the quality of life of women and children. It is equally needless to say that we never hear these same people calling for the removal of negative gearing provisions, accelerated depreciation allowances, or the tax free status of the big life and superannuation funds. All are elements that affect men far more than they affect women, and companies more than they affect individuals.

The lack of interest in the income and the economic well-being of women and their children is clearly indicated by the fact that, in the decade between 1975 and 1985, the real value of the family allowance fell while, at the same time, the real value of the dependent spouse rebate increased. It is no surprise to anybody that the major recipients of the family allowance are women and the major beneficiaries of the dependent spouse rebate are the male members of the community. This disparity caused some problems for many women for whom the family allowance was their only source of independent income.

Since 1985, in general terms, the situation for women has not improved either. After an initial flurry of things such as the Sex Discrimination Act, affirmative action legislation and some tax reform measures, which Treasury admits have benefited men more than they have women, the Government settled into implementing a range of policies that I would have thought would more usually be seen on the agenda of conservative governments. Almost all of those policy decisions and almost all of that legislation impacted badly on women and children. So it was with some considerable amusement that I noted recently the complaint by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that there is a perception in the community-he seems to believe that it is an unfair perception-that this Labor Government no longer supports the working classes. I think he is probably right; there is that perception in the community. I do not think it is an unfair perception unless the Treasurer, by referring to the working classes, is referring to people of the same class as the Alan Bonds and the John Spalvins of this world because certainly those working classes have been significantly assisted by government policy and government actions through legislation.

Certainly the Treasurer cannot have been serious if he was arguing in any way at all that low income earners, the working classes that are on average weekly earnings or less, have been supported by this Labor Government in the last few years in particular. However, what is more important-the Treasurer did not comment on this at all-is that this Government no longer supports the needs of the non-working classes, again another group that it has traditionally claimed to be the champion of. It has not supported the needs of aged pensioners; it has not supported the needs of supporting parents; it has not attended to the needs of secondary and tertiary students; and it has not attended to the needs of long and short-term unemployed people, male and female, of all age brackets. Government strategies towards those people have essentially reduced assistance to those groups. In doing so, the Government has reduced their standards of living; it has reduced their disposable incomes; and it has increased the number of people living in poverty; and that has had repercussions in the retail and small business sector which have seriously affected trading.

I made a number of comments in that regard when, last year, this Government, with the support, I might add, of the Liberal and National parties in this place, delayed the normal November consumer price index increases to pensioners and beneficiaries. The impact of that was felt very severely by the retail sector right across the country. The Government, of course, has taken those actions in the name of fiscal responsibility, and because those policies have been so ultraconservative, the Government has done so with the support of the Liberal and National parties.

The Government has reintroduced tertiary fees, although it has tried to get around that policy anomaly by calling them administration fees. They have had a dramatic impact on the participation of women, particularly from low income families, in post-secondary education. A quick look at any of the university statistics before and after the introduction of administration fees will indicate the number of women who are now not proceeding with post-secondary education. That will inevitably affect the future employment prospects of those women and, hence, their earning potential.

The Government moved to eliminate Austudy payments to families on low incomes with a 15-year-old student in year 11 or 12 of secondary school, and that has had a dramatic impact on a lot of families. It has not only reduced the income of low income families by up to $2,000 a year but also meant that fewer young people and young women in particular, were finishing secondary school. I was appalled by Senator Ryan's statement during the committee stage of the debate on the Austudy cuts that the 15-year-old students in South Australia and Western Australia-the two States most affected-should get part time jobs. I do not know whether she thinks jobs pop up on demand, but it is not only extremely difficult for 15-year-old boys and girls to get part time work but also not something I would have thought any Minister for education would recommend, particularly for those students having difficulty at school since working part time would only reduce their study capacity and thereby have a deleterious effect on the work they are doing. Taken in conjunction with the $30m cut to technical and further education funding that came at the same time, the impact of those measures on young people has been quite dramatic. The prospects of their being adequately trained to survive an economic decline is pretty limited as a result of those measures.

Sole parents, mainly women, have also been economically hard hit by changes to eligibility for a Class A widow's pension, for example. That pension now cuts out when the youngest child turns 16, leaving the mother to face the prospect of job hunting or collecting unemployment benefits. A number of issues I have just mentioned were implemented after pressure from the New Right in this country for governments to cut expenditure and, in particular, to reduce the amount of funding put towards social welfare. I wonder how many of those businessmen who were party to the calls for cuts are likely to employ a woman of 40 or more who has been out of the work force for the last 10 or 20 years. Certainly, none of them is prepared to accept the skills and qualifications of a woman who has raised and cared for children, run a home and budgeted, often on a very small income, the money that has been coming in for 10 or 20 years. Those skills are rarely acknowledged by business people. The chances of those women getting jobs are next to nothing. They are then faced with the prospect of fronting up to the Commonwealth Employment Service on a weekly or fortnightly basis, being turned down and suffering a considerable loss of self-esteem as a consequence.

All of these measures undertaken by this so-called Labor Government were taken prior to what is quaintly called by the media, the recent stock market meltdown. I find it rather odd that they have used a nuclear expression to describe what has happened in that freest of all free market systems. In any event, it was a meltdown which was made worse in Australia by the number of foreign investors buying into our local companies, real estate and so on, as well as the fact that negative gearing has encouraged many individuals, from yuppies to billionaires, to borrow heavily to play the market. When those people panicked-the people involved were almost entirely well off men-and the drop began in earnest, those people started selling shares foolishly and too quickly in order to cover losses and bank loans. They then claimed that the downturn means that Australia can no longer afford a $7 a week pay rise. Strangely enough, I do not think I or anyone else heard them 12 months ago when the market was booming offer a pay rise or claiming that now the market is up, it is time to spread the largesse around the community generally.

Yet again, it seems that the poor will be punished for the greed and foolishness of the rich. If they succeed in the claims they are currently making to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, additional pressures will be placed on women in the home in trying to balance diminishingly effective housekeeping budgets, as well as pressures being placed on women in the work force whose disposable incomes will purchase less. It is still too early to see, of course, exactly what will be the effect of the stock market crash on our economy. However, no serious economist can ignore the possibility that this country will experience another significant economic downturn. That, of course, brings out of the woodwork all of the people claiming that there should be Budget surpluses and that these have to come from cutting the Public Service, cutting Government expenditure and putting the unemployed, pensioners, the less well off, into the laps of their families, who can ill afford to look after them, and the community generally which does not know what to do with them anyway.

Balanced budgets, reduced government expenditure, deregulation and all the things promised by the Treasurer and endorsed by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) under pressure from the New Right are not, in fact, the policies that should be pursued in the 1980s. Reducing Government expenditure means that benefits and services must be taken away from some individuals. They are usually taken away from those people who can least help themselves and who most need government assistance. Provision for social goals, like equal employment opportunity, affirmative action, equality of educational opportunities, consumer protection, health standards, and conservation of the environment-all these things, claim the proponents of the New Right, can be scrapped. According to deregulators, they can be scrapped because they represent an interference with the rights of an entrepreneur to produce whatever he can make money from and to do it in any way that he can.

I suggest that public spending cuts for their own sake and further deregulation will not automatically solve our economic problems. In fact, they will not assist women and their children in any way. Economic and social changes in the last decade have already produced large pockets of poverty in what is otherwise an affluent society. To exacerbate that problem is foolhardiness on the part of this or any other government. There is an increasing disparity between the rich and the poor in Australia, and the Government needs to attend to that before it starts propping up companies that have speculated on the market and claim, on the one hand, that further deregulation is needed while, on the other hand, further protection is needed in order for them to survive.

Accumulation of personal wealth by the very rich in Australia has jumped in recent years. There are said to be more than 30,000 millionaires in Australia; one per cent of our adult population owns almost 25 per cent of private wealth in the country, while the top 10 per cent of the population owns 50 per cent of the wealth. That leaves 40 per cent of private wealth in the hands of 90 per cent of the population. If the Government considers that a sensible distribution of wealth and assets in this country, it is very much mistaken.

Most studies show that poverty in Australia has also increased significantly in the same decade that saw a dramatic jump in the number of millionaires in this country and, until the stock market crash, billionaires. In the period between 1981-82 and 1985-86, an extra 100,000 families and single income earners have slipped into poverty. More than 650,000 households now live in poverty. The biggest losers over this period were families with four or more dependent children. That is the very group that we, as members of parliament, and government, in particular, ought to be looking at protecting and assisting because it is from within those families that the future work force and productive capacity of the country will come. If children are not properly educated and brought up in a reasonably equitable society, their chances of fulfilling that capacity are somewhere between Buckley's and none.

Women suffer especially from economic in- equalities. It is not hard to argue that the history of women is a history of economic disadvantage. There is nothing new about the fact that women are likely to suffer most during a period of economic decline. After all, even in times of economic prosperity, whatever the relative improvement of their circumstances may be, women rarely enjoy personal affluence comparable to that of men. The economic disadvantages experienced by women relate to all areas of public policy: education, employment, child care, housing, and health care. Women continue to be discriminated against in each of those spheres, and the effects of inadequate education and housing, for example, play a part in perpetuating a vicious cycle of disadvantage.

By any indicator one cares to name, women in Australia are still bearing a disproportionate share of economic inequality. Women generally and women with dependent children in particular are consistently left out in the cold, economically as well as sometimes literally, by governments and decision makers. Not only are the economic needs of women generally ignored while the economic demands of well-to-do men, like the Alan Bonds and John Elliotts of the world, are pandered to, but the contribution women make to the economy, both in the work force and in the home, is generally either disregarded by economic analysts or overlooked. Equal pay might be given to men and women who do the same job, but there is still not equal pay for work of equal value for the simple reason that the powers that be do not regard work traditionally done by women, either in the home or in the work force, as being as highly useful, profitable and important as work traditionally done by men.

Choices for women might seem on the surface to be better than they have been, but women are still, by and large, economically worse off than men. The bulk of families living in poverty are still headed by women. Female headed income units are still five times more likely to be very poor in comparison with income units headed by men. Of all very poor families with children, 45 per cent were single parent families headed by women. Despite all the apparent advances that we have seen in the past 10 to 15 years, women are still clustered in the lowest paid jobs, are still regarded as unstable and unsuitable employees by some employers, and are still not appropriately educated to vie for and get the better paid jobs with prospects that have been the sole province of men for so long.

A recent article in the Sydney Morning Herald states that women still face significant job discrimination. This morning's Sydney Morning Herald carried a report of a study that was undertaken by Monash University, which study shows that approximately 40 per cent more discrimination exists against women than exists against men. The study involved sending in bogus job applications, supposedly from men and women with exactly the same qualifications. In certain areas, women were simply disregarded from among the list of applicants, although on paper no difference existed between the women's qualifications, skills and experience and those of the bogus male applicants. The study showed three times more discrimination against women than men in response to applications for work as gardeners and computer analysts/programmers. Despite affirmative action legislation, sex discrimination legislation and, in a number of States, equal opportunity legislation, both the public and the private sectors are circumventing this by simply ignoring applications by women in a number of areas which are regarded as traditional male areas of work.

No wonder Australia has the worst record of all countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in equality in the work force. No wonder men still earn significantly more than women in Australia. In the middle of this year, total average weekly earnings for men were $446.30 and for women were only $287.60. No wonder the minute there appears to be an economic downturn or there is one, the areas from which women receive their incomes are hardest hit. Stores put off counter staff, not managerial staff, and part timers before full timers. Women fit into the first two categories more frequently than men. That is a fairly nasty application of the women and children first syndrome. Women suffer significantly from the impact of government policies and from economic downturns.

To make matters worse, women are still disproportionately represented in industries in which many positions will be made superfluous by technological change. Conversely, women are not well represented in industries in which growth is expected to exceed national productivity growth over the next five years-areas such as finance and business, electricity, transport, storage, communication, and mining. Therefore, women's prospects in the future, as business and industry change in this country, appear to be even worse. This sort of prospect means that a dramatic change in government policy towards education and development patterns for women is necessary if women are not to be disproportionately disadvantaged by economic circumstances. As I said earlier, over the past few years government action has resulted in the reverse; it has exacerbated the problems faced by women and their children-especially in the social welfare, education, health, and child care areas-rather than significantly improving them.

While the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) which indicates the spending priorities of the Government, is being addressed, it is about time the Government recognised that women and their children have unique needs. It is about time Treasury was able to make a more positive statement about the Budget's impact on women in the Women's Budget Statement 1987-88. It is time that representatives of the Treasury and the Department of Finance spoke to women's groups, the Institute of Family Studies and individual women in the community to ascertain what the past impact has been and what policy measures and legislation should be implemented by the Government to offset those problems.

This Government appointed the first woman ever to the High Court of Australia, Justice Gaudron.
—Don't go on about that.

—Senator Stone said we should not go on about that. There are no problems with this Government going on about an appointment which has been received, as it properly should have been, very well throughout the community.
—You are not saying she did not get there on merit, are you?

—Of course not. As Senator Haines says, she very much got there on merit. Any suggestion otherwise from anywhere else in the chamber is to be rebutted. The other matter that should be mentioned is affirmative action. The legislation that enabled that to come in was brought forward by this Government. Senator Haines properly supported that as, indeed, did members of the Opposition.
—Not the Nationals.

—The National Party of Australia did not support that. As Senator McGauran says, the Nationals have never supported legislation to enable women not to get priority over men but simply to get an equal status with men. That is what that legislation was about. The National Party refused to pass legislation which would simply give women an equal opportunity-not a better or greater opportunity and not, as it were, a free kick on the football field. The Nationals denied them that. Senator Haines has to be congratulated for supporting the Government in its initiative in that area. This was historic legislation and it will go down as such in future years.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Haines that women still are not afforded the opportunity to hold the positions that they ought to have in society. But their position has been much redressed under this Government and as a result of the actions that the labour movement has taken part in over the years. Their position now is much better than it would have been had there been an alternative government in office. The course has now been set to enable women to achieve their proper place in the work force and elsewhere. Senator Haines is absolutely right-in terms of their dignity and their ability to look after themselves and their children, work and the proper work, is the way to go.

Senator Haines spoke about and criticised the trickle down effect. I again agree with her. A proposition which says that people, particularly women and children, ought in some way sit around and wait for a trickling down effect to occur in a patriarchal society is quite wrong. In any society where justice prevails, conditions should be such that everybody, irrespective of their sex, colour or age-of course, I am talking in terms of working age-ought to be given an opportunity to get work of a proper nature, work that allows them to exercise with dignity their skills, whether physical or intellectual. That sort of society is the proper society we should look to achieve.

Senator Haines criticised the Government because of its concentration, as it were, on economic matters. It is true to say that the debate in this Parliament, and in the two parliaments before it, has been very much directed to the economy, to how to get it right, because the logic is that if the economy is right there is a bigger slice of the cake for everybody and some cake for all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell me how introducing negative gearing for property speculators gets the economy right.

—Senator Haines has asked how negative gearing for property helps. In the time available I do not want to go into that specific matter, but clearly that is an economic question. Senator Haines in her question to me quite properly concentrates on economic issues. Senator Haines talked about how the cake should be shared out and the proper facilities that should be available in this community for women and children. Those issues must be talked about in the context of the overall necessity of having an economy which provides enough money and the wherewithal for this to happen. It is one thing simply to go about creating an economy for the sake, as it were, of getting some macroeconomic machinery into place so we can sit back and say, `Is that not a magnificent piece of machinery? We have an economic model that works beautifully'. To simply look at the economy and say that it is beautiful is like our having a great big car that we never drive.
—That is the Heath Robinson model, is it?

— Senator Stone asks whether this is a particular model. I am concentrating not so much on the model but more on why we want an economy which functions well. We want that because it will provide the wherewithal, the money and the sinews to enable this society to function as it should, where justice is done to all. We want an economy that provides enough for all.
—Where is the justice in negative gearing?

—I agree with Senator Haines that there is always a danger when talking about the economy of forgetting the reasons why we want a good economy. Sometimes, particularly in recent times, we are carried away by the economic debate and we forget about the people in it who are affected by the changes that take place and who, often, are asked to make sacrifices in the interests of some other section of the community. That is the point Senator Haines was making. It was fair to say that there ought to be a sharing of the burden, that there ought to be equity in the sharing of the sacrifices that have to be made as there should be equity in the sharing of whatever is produced by this economy which this Government, to be fair to it, has got into better shape than anybody else could have. The economy is now in better shape than it was when we came to office.
—I would hate to think it was in worse shape.

—Of course, everybody would hate to think the economy would be in worse shape. That is a very negative approach. The approach that should be taken is to consider the positives the Government has achieved, and there are many of them. It has achieved a great deal in the social area. I turn to some of its achievements now. There are always two considerations-economic and social-and a proper balance has to be achieved between getting the economy right and making sure that the citizens of this country are not ground down and tortured by the lack of wherewithal to live, by poverty.
—Which citizens are you talking about?

—I hope I am talking about every citizen in Australia. I do not want to create a class war such as Senator Haines referred to when she talked about the rich and the poor and the two-country approach of Benjamin Disraeli; I am talking about Australia as a whole. I shall go through some of the programs that this Government has introduced and which it is now developing. It has been mentioned that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) the other day said that concern ought to be expressed for the traditional Labor voters. I understood him to say that that concern has always been there but that it should be better expressed. This very day the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) launched a policy which indicates that this Government has great concern for those areas in society which are deprived. He launched the Aboriginal employment development policy. Senator Haines and Senator Stone are here. I was a little disappointed that they were not at the launching but I am sure they were both there in spirit. This policy of the Government will help what is conceded to be one of the poorer sections, if not the poorest section, of this society.
—All on borrowed money.

—Senator Stone's interjection indicates the Opposition's approach to this whole question. The Opposition's approach, as expressed by Senator Stone, is that no matter how downtrodden people might be, no matter how deprived they might be, no matter how bereft of income they might be, if the economic model which is a figment of the imagination of the Opposition is in any way prejudiced by social considerations it is the social considerations that should surrender, according to the Opposition, and not the economic considerations. That is the real problem. Opposition members have no heart. I do not say that lightly but whenever a piece of social reform is introduced by the Government-and there have been many of them over the life of the Government-the Opposition invariably says that we cannot afford it as if economics is the only consideration instead of one of the major considerations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal employment development policy seeks to give economic independence to the Aborigines. It arises out of a report by Mr Mick Miller. I think he is to be congratulated on his report, which points out a situation which should have been observed earlier. If Aborigines are to enter the work force in jobs that are commensurate with the dignity of any worker, they themselves should make decisions on this matter. They themselves should be able to choose the areas in which they are to be educated and in the areas in which they are to undertake their efforts. It is interesting to note that half the Aboriginal population of Australia lives in cities and towns. In those areas the Aboriginal employment development policy offers training that leads to job assistance and assistance to establish Aboriginal businesses. Careful planning is needed to create real employment opportunities in industry and in the public sector. That policy was launched this morning by the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —But under this Government there are more Aborigines out of work today than ever.

—I do not want to insult Senator Stone but it would be interesting to see the statistics on that. If that is the situation-and there have been hard economic times-this Government, in contrast to the Opposition, has a plan, has an Aboriginal person in Mr Mick Miller to develop a report and has done something about it. That has been welcomed by the Aboriginal community. It is a very positive policy; it is a very positive program which will lead the Aborigines, hopefully, into playing a greater role in this community and which will for years to come direct their endeavours in a way which will give them dignity and take them out of the social security system. They do not want to be attached to that system. The policy will give them the sort of status they deserve.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the family package program that this Government has brought forward. It is in contrast to the Opposition's election promises on the family, which demonstrated a very scattergun approach. According to the Opposition policy which was read out during the election campaign, it would introduce a care allowance of $800 per annum for a child paid through the Australian Taxation Office as a tax credit or a cash payment to the primary carer. In contrast to that sort of policy, which did not target those most in need and which as it were did not try to identify where the real hardship lay, this Government has brought forward a family package. I have some background material here from the office of Brian Howe, the Minister for Social Security, which I think makes interesting reading. The Budget announced a $500m family package in fulfilment of an election commitment made to the people of Australia by the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Financed with more borrowed money.

—The Prime Minister was then elected again, in the light of that promise, to a further term of government. Senator Stone says it was on borrowed money. Does Senator Stone say that people should not be helped, that the economy should not sustain people who are in need? Does he say that people should be thrown on the scrapheap forever, or does he want to do what this program does? The main part of the family package is the family allowance supplement. The new family allowance supplement pays $22 a week for each child. If the children are 13, 14 or 15 years of age, the payment for each child is $28 a week. Families on a gross wage of $300 a week or less can get full payment if they have one child. The bigger the family is the more money that it can earn while still getting some payment.

SPEECH.PARA: Because the family allowance supplement is tax free it is better than a pay rise. This was acknowledged by Bill Kelty, Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He said that this family package represented an advance for the workers of Australia which would otherwise have taken something like half a century to achieve. A family on $400 a week with two teenagers and paying rent will get $27 extra a week. Because it is tax free, the family allowance supplement is equal to a pay rise for that family of $45 a week or 11.25 per cent. That is a major achievement in that area and an indication that this Government is targeting areas of need. It does have compassion, which sometimes it is alleged it does not have, for those who are in need. For example, the same family on $350 a week will get an extra $5 to add on to its wage-equivalent to a pay rise of $86 a week or almost 25 per cent. That is worth emphasising because it is, I think, quite amazing.

The family package promises to help all children in low income families to make ends meet. Senator Haines talked about people in receipt of social security benefits. Certainly, those who are in need of social security support are the people who should, and do, get our attention. Parents on social security get a child payment of $17 a week for each child. That payment is called an additional pension for people on pensions, and an additional benefit for people on unemployment benefit, sickness benefit or other benefits paid by Social Security. Those child payments for people on social security will go up automatically in December. People do not have to apply for the increase. It will lift their payment of $17 a week by $5 for children under 13, and add $11 a week for 13-, 14- and 15-year-olds.

The family package means that lower income parents will get the same child payments if they are on social security or working-there is no difference. In the next financial year the family package is expected to help about one million children across Australia. That is a great achievement for a government that has been criticised by Senator Haines and others as being unfeeling, as being, as it were, in a straitjacket of economic considerations and nothing else. It is evidence that the description given by Senator Haines and others is inaccurate. As I said, in the next financial year the family package is expected to help about one million children across Australia-about 440,000 children in working families and another 740,000 children in families on social security.

The other thing that the Government has done since coming to office, and particularly since the last election, is to set benchmarks to ensure that children are lifted out of poverty. I think it is worth referring to those benchmarks. Children will be provided with income along these lines: 15 per cent of combined married pensions for children under 13, and 20 per cent of combined married pensions for 13- to 15-year olds.

Another point regarding the family package is that for the first time the Government will pay up to $15 a week in rent assistance for working families in private housing. Families on unemployment and sickness benefits will no longer have to serve a separate waiting period for rent assistance and will get help for housing from their first benefit payment. The Government will also introduce a new child disability allowance to replace the handicapped child's allowance. Some 27,000 severely disabled children will have their payments increased from $92 to $112 a month. It should be remembered that the Prime Minister has promised that no Australian child need live in poverty by 1990.

There is one other set of figures I would like to read out, regarding pensioners-the aged, invalids and widows. Fifty-seven per cent of social security payments are paid to pensioners who are aged, invalided or widowed. Measures are being brought forward by this Government to protect indexation for pensioners and to help them beat poverty traps by giving them the ability to earn income and to increase their income by those earnings. Until now, many pensioners have hesitated about taking casual jobs for fear of losing their one form of security-the pension. This Budget introduces a new earnings credit scheme from 1 November 1987 which will give pensioners the incentive to supplement their income. Under the earnings credit scheme eligible pensioners will be able to earn up to $1,000 each from casual jobs without losing their fringe benefits or having their pensions reduced. I will cite some specific figures for the aged: the next pension indexation is due in December. It will take the rate to $116.10 a week for single people and $96.75 each for couples. The maximum rent assistance for age and other pensioners will increase from $10 to $15 a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did more than that.

—That, no doubt, is a reference to the Fraser Government. It is interesting to note that the level of pensions under the Fraser Government was 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings. Under this Government it rose to 24.8 per cent in June 1987. One has to go through a fairly tortuous exercise in logic to agree with what Senator McGauran said. He said, by inference, that the Fraser Government-I presume he was talking about that Government-did more than this Government. The figures show that that is absolutely incorrect. We have heard interjections in the course of this address from Senator Stone who, in answer to every initiative that I have raised, in order to show what the Government has done for the more deprived sections of this community, said, in effect, that this country cannot afford it. Senator McGauran, by inference, has said that the coalition, including the Nationals, will do something for pensioners. How does he answer the Leader of this own Party who, every time the issue of social fairness is raised, says that the country cannot afford to give people in desperate need what they deserve?

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has maintained the balance, which it clearly understands needs to be maintained, between the realities of economic life in this world-the need to make sure that the economy is adjusted so as to take account of our overseas debt, the need to sell more overseas and to produce more-and the requirement and the crying need of people living in near poverty to live properly, as decent citizens of this country. In spite of what Senator Haines says, this Government will not lead this country into becoming two nations, comprising a rich group and a poor group. This Government wants to see everybody properly fed, properly housed, properly clothed, properly schooled, and able to live a decent, honest life amongst everybody else who, hopefully, have the same opportunities. In achieving that balance, according to some perceptions, at times the balance in terms of economic consideration has sunk or risen, depending on how one looks at it. That perception is wrong. There has been, throughout the life of this Government, a perception and a realisation that, ultimately, what matters are the people who elected it to this place for the third time in a row. There is an understanding of the reality that not only those people but Australians as a whole need to be looked after. Each person is entitled to be given proper regard. It is in the light of that context that this Government has brought forward this package and social security provisions and has, at the same time, managed the economy so well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I realise that I have only 10 minutes in which to speak before the Senate breaks for lunch and that it will not be until after lunch, even 3 o'clock, before I can finish my remarks on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88 and cognate Bills.
—There is to be an MPI. It will be about 6 o'clock.

—I understand from Senator Ray that it could be as late as 6 o'clock before I can resume my speech. However, what I have to say I will complete today. I will begin my remarks, before I actually address matters relating to the 1987-88 Budget, by taking the opportunity to mention my good colleague Senator Boswell, who has allowed me to take his place on the speakers list today because he has had to return to his home State of Queensland to accept a very prestigious award-the Fisherman of the Year award. I do not know whether the award is just for Queensland or whether it is a national award, but certainly Senator Boswell deserves it. Although he gave me very late notice about taking his place on the list, I thank him very much for the opportunity. I congratulate him on becoming the Fisherman of the Year. I know that he is very proud of that achievement.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who knows Senator Boswell knows that he is a very hardworking man and that certainly he is a man of the people. In particular, Senator Boswell is a man who concentrates on the forgotten people in society. Nothing is more needed in political life than a man such as Senator Boswell when the Government has handed down a Budget of the sort it has. Senator Boswell is a very compassionate man. He is a man who has compassionate words for the forgotten Australians. Certainly, though, he is a man who has damning words for those who will not listen and act. Again, on behalf of my National Party of Australia colleagues, I congratulate Senator Boswell.

I now turn my attention to the Budget. I, like others on the long list of my colleagues who have done so, condemn the Government's 1987-88 Budget. The Budget has been a false document, in terms of its assessment and predictions, from the time it was handed down. It is false in its presentation as a balanced Budget. It is false in its predictions in regard to present economic conditions. It is false in its predictions for the economic conditions which will face the nation in 1988. The Budget's credibility now lies in tatters in the wake of the economic realities that have hit the financial and stock markets like a massive earthquake and which have left the Government's Ministers stunned like rabbits under a spotlight, too frightened to move and waiting for the death shot from the dark. Surely that death shot will come from the dark. We can expect several more shock waves in the near future, in the New Year. We can expect several more twists and turns in the stock market situation and in regard to the Australian dollar. We can expect these to come in our bicentennial year-a year for celebration. Really, that will be a year of very unfortunate stocktaking in this country.

Every assumption that was made in the Budget when it was handed down no longer applies. Indeed, such assumptions never were soundly based. In 1988 we will have higher inflation than was predicted in the Budget. We will have higher interest rates, a greater depreciation of the Australian dollar, and a higher debt level. So it goes on. Just about every economic indicator cited in the Budget Papers is now worthless. Sadly, the Government knows that but does nothing.

We are now preparing to enter our bicentennial year. As I said before, it is a year in which to celebrate this nation's great achievements and to confirm our traditional beliefs. However, after 200 years of carving out a very proud history and a very high standard of living, as a result of which we were once known as the lucky country, we have now had all this smashed by an incompetent government. I ask that for the sake of this nation, for the sake of the working men and women, the farmer and the small business person, the Government act now to turn back the tide of recession and that it stop its lies to this nation. I ask the Government to return the rewards for work to the people, to the real contributors to Australia, who now more than ever need to be able to rely on a government that is capable of administering the country's finances.

It is ironic that in the wake of the collapse of this nation's economy, the Australian Labor Party has indulged in a bitter debate as to whether the Whitlam Government was a truer Labor government than the Hawke Government. My answer to this very useless question and debate is that both governments will leave the same legacy to this nation. History will judge both governments as incompetent economic managers. Their legacy is a legacy that all Labor governments have left this nation. Let us look at the Scullin Government when it was in office in 1929, the year of the famous share market collapse. At the next election in 1931 it was thrown out of government. The Whitlam Government, in particular, will be remembered for its high interest rates. If it is possible for me to pluck one thing out of the air in regard to what the Whitlam Government should be remembered for, it is its presiding over probably the first of the great interest rate rises in this country. Interest rates on 90-day bank bills reached an extraordinary 22 per cent and beyond. If it is possible to pluck out of the air one particular aspect for which the Hawke Government should be remembered, that would be the great debts it has imposed on the working men and women of this country. The overseas debt stands at $110 billion-increasing at $1 billion per month. Those figures have been cited many times in this chamber.

From this debate will come the conviction that the Labor Party never has been and never will be a competent manager of the economy. Members of the Labor Party have not got it in them to be competent managers. Regardless of the fact that the Labor Party is running our country into the ground, we still live in a great country. Australia is still a very lucky country. It is a great nation and it is very hard to kill off a nation that has such great resources. Today we still have some of the world's greatest resources holding the economy together-albeit that the economy is a little threadbare.

The five major exports of this country are coal, wool, beef, gold and wheat. Three of our major exports are from the agricultural sector and earn in excess of $8 billion in export revenue. Be it as a result of ignorance or politics, this Government over its term in office has given scant acknowledgment to rural Australia as the real contributor to this nation's standard of living. More particularly, rural Australia is the real contributor to resolving the balance of payments crisis. If only this Government understood that! However, this Budget has decreased the outlays on pastoral and agricultural industries by $56m. Since the Budget, the Government has set about directly increasing the costs of production applying to such industries. That has taken place since the Budget was brought down and since the share market crash and the fall in the Australian dollar. The Government has set about increasing costs applying to our most valuable exports. I will go through those.

The wheat industry brings some $1.7 billion in export revenue to the country. This is at a time when, as reported in the Press today, the increase in our balance of payments debt was greater than $1 billion. The Government has decided to increase costs by way of lifting the export insurance premiums. I have asked the relevant Minister several questions concerning the lifting of the export insurance premiums. I got no satisfactory answer. The only answer I really got from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, was that the Government has a fine relationship with the Australian Wheat Board. I will quote from an article to show what the Wheat Board thinks of this Government's decision. That article refers to statements of Mr Clinton Condon, who is Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board.
