QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Acting Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health with a brief explanation. The International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation (ICGFI) was established on 9 May 1984 to promote further international discussion on this important question. Australia, along with nearly 30 other countries, was a founding member and attended the 1985 and 1986 meetings. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that at the meeting of the ICGFI in November 1986, the then Department of Health pledged $US5,000 as Australia's contribution to the 1987 year? Is it a fact that this pledge was withdrawn after the then Minister for Health refused to sign the cheque, with the result that Australia will not be represented at this year's meeting in December? Why did the Minister refuse to sign the cheque, thus denying Australia a role in discussions about a process described by the Minister for Transport and Communications in this place on 17 February? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The technique is at the stage where it is thought generally to be appropriate for implementation on an industrial scale.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to have to say that, flipping through the brief provided to me, I can find nothing on that topic, and I am unable to give the comprehensive answer that I am sure the Minister would wish to give. I shall pass the question on to the Minister and ask him to make a response.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Has the Minister had a chance to examine further allegations that a member of his staff advocated in 1986 ecological sabotage techniques? If so, what is the Minister's response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of fact, I have had a chance to examine further the allegations that were made yesterday by Senator Puplick. I can only say that, upon further examination, I am more outraged than I was yesterday because either Senator Puplick deliberately misquoted and misrepresented what Simon Balderstone wrote, or the senator was given false information that he did not check. If it is the case of the former, he stands condemned--
—He tabled the article. What are you talking about?

—Senator Puplick tabled it yesterday, and I shall get on to that in a moment, Senator Chaney. Be patient, and we shall get there. Senator Puplick said that the article analyses a series of techniques, including monkeywrenching, `ecotage' and tree spiking in detail. The first thing to say is that it does not. Nowhere in the article does anything like that appear. Senator Puplick also said that the article contained `a very explicit guide of how one goes about the process of tree spiking'. It does not. In the article, tree spiking is mentioned only once, and that is only in a quote from a book. Putting bolts in trees is mentioned, but to say that it is rare in Australia. There is a comment on it, but that is all. Senator Puplick also claimed that Simon Balderstone said:

ANSWER.PARA: Lobbying often fails, and more drastic measures have to be taken.

This time, Senator Puplick got it right. Simon Balderstone said that. The article goes on to explain just what direct action means in this context. Senator Puplick has not only advocated direct action in the environment but also participated at Terania Creek, where he was in there trying to stop the logging. I congratulate him on that. I do not know what the views of the National Party of Australia are on this, but that is where he was. He was over in Canada trying to stop the seal hunt. Good on him-that is direct action. If it is good enough for Senator Puplick to participate in it, why is it not good enough for Simon Balderstone to write about?

Senator Puplick went on to allege that the article mentioned that `a silent and cordless drill should be used' to spike trees, that it was `better to use ceramic rods' and that it was very important to use silicone to conceal the spike. These are extraordinary and incredible allegations from Senator Puplick when one considers that such phrases are contained in a cartoon story placed in the magazine in the middle of Simon Balderstone's article-a cartoon story that he did not write and did not know about. Further, Senator Puplick tabled some other writings that were not Simon Balderstone's, including one giving information on monkeywrenching and how to go about it. Senator Puplick has tabled in the Senate words that he attributes to Simon Balderstone, words that Simon Balderstone never wrote. What I said yesterday stands true. At no stage did Simon Balderstone ever advocate any action that would cause harm to the person. He has been deliberately misrepresented by Senator Puplick and, as I said yesterday, Simon Balderstone deserves an apology. Senator Puplick is in enough trouble already with the environment movement because he will not stand up on World Heritage listings. He will be in a lot more trouble if he will not act honourably in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, refers to a recent item in the Australian newspaper which states that cattlemen fear that the gamba grass seed is a disease risk. Will there be stringent testing of the 3,000-bag consignment of gamba grass which is to come into Australia from Brazil shortly? Is the Minister aware that cattle producers believe that this consignment poses a serious threat of foot and mouth disease being introduced to Australia as it could contain fungal diseases already known here? Will the Minister ask Mr Kerin to ensure that stringent testing of this gamba grass seed is carried out?

—I do not know anything about this. Indeed, I had never heard of gamba grass before. Whatever the normal quarantine and testing arrangements are, I assume that they will apply to this grass seed importation and I will get the details of it as soon as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the remarks of Senator Lewis yesterday regarding manufacturing, production, employment and investment contained in the 1986-87 annual report of his Department? Does the Minister accept the picture of the Australian manufacturing sector depicted in the senator's remarks? Does he agree with Senator Lewis that trends in activity during the past year are `fascinating in the light of all that Senator Button has been saying in relation to manufacturing'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis's remarks have been drawn to my attention. As I recall, it was Senator Childs who did so. I want to make a brief comment about some of the things that he said, because it is unfortunate that Senator Lewis reached only the summary pages of the prefix to the report. Had he gone a little further, he might have developed a slightly different view. I want to make the general observation that Senator Lewis is quite right to draw attention to the fact that a number of things happened in a year when the economy was fairly screwed down.
—As distinct from screwed up.
—I am not concerned about the interjections of those for whom those words have only one connotation.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw attention to the fact that there was relatively static production overall in the manufacturing sector and a small decline in employment in the manufacturing sector over 1986-87. This is not surprising. But significant changes are occurring across Australian manufacturing industry and focusing on the last year ignores some of those fundamental changes in industry performance and export activity. Recent indicators suggest that the Australian manufacturing industry is adapting to the new tougher world economic environment and is responding positively to incentives provided by the Government. Increasingly, firms face competitive pressures and, as they do so, they are not rushing to governments for higher tariffs and other protection as was the practice in the past. Instead, they are actively seeking means of raising their internal competitiveness through cost reductions, increased efficiency, improved product quality and better marketing.

I think Senator Lewis would also be pleased to know that the export orientation of local manufactures is growing strongly. In 1986-87 exports of manufactures grew by 25 per cent in nominal terms and 14 per cent in real terms. That compares with the real average annual growth rate of only 4.9 per cent between 1977-78 and 1983-84. Importantly, imports of high value added manufactures grew at a stronger rate of 30 per cent in nominal terms during the last year. So Senator Lewis's attention might have been better diverted to the table showing export performance of selected manufactures during the last few years. That is located in the appendix rather than the prefix to the report, which is what I suspect Senator Lewis read.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister's Department holding an Australian International Development Assistance Bureau file on Mr Rod Kelly? Does the file record an investigation into Mr Rod Kelly? What conclusions did this investigation reach? When did Mr Hayden become aware of the file? Is there any evidence that Mr Kelly was involved with the Alliance Party and/or coup and/or military leaders in Fiji in the time leading up to the coup in that country? Is it true that the report canvassed the possibility that Mr Kelly was receiving funds from foreign intelligence sources? What is and has been Mr Kelly's relation to Mr Hawke and others in the Centre Unity faction of the Australian Labor Party (ALP)? What positions, if any, has Mr Kelly held in the ALP and what input has he had to ALP policy? What action does the Minister intend to take in relation to the activities of Mr Kelly in Fiji?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said the other day in relation to a question from Senator Sanders, `Another day, another conspiracy'. Here we are again with the Australian Democrats. Senator Coulter did give me some short notice of this, which did enable me to check with Mr Hayden, and I am advised as follows: Mr Kelly came to the attention of the Australian High Commission in Suva in 1986 in relation to commercial aspects of an aid project then under discussion with the Fiji authorities concerning a Fiji fisheries project. Inquiries into Mr Kelly's commercial background were instituted through normal commercial channels. Those inquiries were inconclusive. The High Commissioner was aware that Mr Kelly was in contact with some members of the then Fiji Government, but there was no suggestion that these contracts had other than commercial purposes. There was gossip at the time in Fiji which associated Mr Kelly with foreign commercial organisations, but there was no suggestion of any links with foreign intelligence services.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of Mr Kelly's supposed links with the Australian Labor Party in Victoria, I have no particular knowledge of the subject and have very considerable doubts as to its relevance, particularly in the light of the answer that I have just given. I do know that he was involved for a time rather publicly or conspicuously, in trade union affairs in Victoria. He was a member of the Labor Party; whether he still is, I do not know. I do not think I have ever heard of him playing any active, let alone any influential, role in relation to policy formulation. That is the prerogative of a rather small and select group in the Victorian ALP. I did ask the Prime Minister a few minutes before Question Time, the question having been explicitly raised by Senator Coulter, whether he knew Mr Kelly. He told me that he did, but he had had no close association with him.

As to the final part of the question-what action does the Minister intend to take in relation to the activities of Mr Kelly in Fiji? I think in the light of the answer I have given it should be self-evident that it would not appear that any further action of any kind is justified.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR THE ENVIRONMENT AND THE ARTS: RAVENSHOE VISIT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. I ask: has the Minister seen the Police Complaints Tribunal report tabled by the Deputy Premier of Queensland, Mr Bill Gunn, exonerating the Queensland Police of any blame for the ugly incident that occurred during the Minister's visit to Ravenshoe on 4 September? Are the conclusions in the report accurate? Further, does the Minister agree with Mr Gunn's personal attack and supplementary comments that Senator Richardson is, indeed, a raw prawn?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of fact, the Police Complaints Tribunal report has been drawn to my attention. I only wish the Police Tribunal had been drawn to my attention when it was conducting its inquiries. I have been criticised in the Queensland Parliament for having the temerity not to have presented evidence to the inquiry. Honourable senators will find it is always a bit difficult when one does not know the inquiry is on, when the Tribunal does not divulge when or where it is meeting and does not make any inquiries to see whether a person wants to give evidence. There was a little more to this report than just that. We are accustomed to Queensland whitewashes; we are not accustomed to whitewashes of such massive dimension. Let me go through just a few of them.

ANSWER.PARA: The first is the finding of the Police Tribunal that no acts of actual violence occurred. One wonders how to describe an act of actual violence in Queensland. I would have thought that being kicked and punched and having one's hair pulled was, indeed, an act of violence. In Queensland it may be an act of love, but everywhere else in this country we all know exactly what it is. The only time that anyone in my party engaged in an act approaching violence was when one of these gentlemen had a strong grip upon my hair and when I was being kicked and punched one member of my staff did actively discourage the gentleman holding my hair from continuing to hang on.

The next comment I would like to make on some of these extraordinary findings, which make pretty comical reading, is that great play has been made of the fact that I used a taxi to pick me up from the helicopter. The police expected me to be in an official limousine. Well, I did not bother to ring the Minister for Administrative Services to see how big the Commonwealth garage was in Ravenshoe. I just assumed we were a bit light on for limousines that day and did what I thought was the only thing I could do; that is, ring for a taxi. I will go into the taxi driver's comments later. She has had a bit to say as well.

The police also said that they could not actually get to me on my arrival, even though they tried. The Queensland Police Force is a pretty intrepid bunch. When we came in in the helicopter we did a couple of circuits of the course around the town and then landed at the golf course, which is three minutes away from where the demonstration occurred but they could not find that, that was all a bit tough. When we arrived I got into the taxi and off I went happily into the main street. As we were driving along, honourable senators will not be too surprised to learn, there was some consternation. The locals began screaming, yelling and hurling abuse. The police said they did not know I was coming until the taxi had gone past them. Who the hell do they think the crowd was screaming at?

Let me go on, because there is more. The police said that there was no neglect of police duty in failing to provide adequate protection. Let us examine this `no neglect of duty'. There I was on Government business driving along the street peacefully in a taxi, driven by a Queensland citizen, when we were rather rudely set upon. The first thing that happened was that the taxi got rocked to the point where it was about to go over. The taxi was abandoned by me and the staff. We did not have much choice. We were not going anywhere in it, given that someone had already pinched the keys. We got out of the taxi and we were prevented from going to the town hall where the meeting was supposed to be held by a group of fairly angry people. They blocked our way and pushed us to the truck. The police at this stage of the game were some 50 to 60 yards away leaning against the police car. They were in animated conversation. That was the only animated thing they were doing at the time.

After an hour on the truck, where proceedings were a little difficult, I announced my intention to leave and proceeded to get off the back of the truck. This is where I found the whole Queensland report really too stupid for words because when we got off the back of the truck a great number of the crowd had managed to station themselves between me and the getaway car. In attempting to approach the getaway car we were then attacked. At this stage of the game the police still watched. I want to make it clear that at the time I said publicly-I repeat it now-that I wanted to forget the incident. I chose to have a go at no one in the Queensland Police Force. The main reason was that one Queensland policeman showed great courage. Leaving his five colleagues still leaning on the car, he barged into the middle of the crowd, took on the ringleaders by screaming some unparliamentary language at them and encouraged them to get out of the road. That bought us enough time to get to the car. The Queensland Police report, however, congratulates the police for being smart enough to have me get away in the police car and not in the taxi. This was a very clever move, except that it was organised by my senior private secretary, David Tierney. Even after he had arranged for the police car to be parked in the right spot, after he had gone and asked them to move it there, the police still tried to put us in the taxi. Fortunately we managed to persuade them at the time that they ought to move us.

I think this wonderful police tribunal, this great investigation, this great example of Queensland justice, needs to be exposed. I would have thought that all honourable senators would be interested in anyone among their number being attacked, given that yesterday we were expressing concerns about harm to persons. The main finding really exposes-and this then becomes not a matter of opinion-the paucity of investigation by this Tribunal, as revealed in the statement that the Queensland Police were never told that I was coming. Of course, that is wrong. They were told.

I think this investigation was conducted by somebody called Judge Pratt. Honourable senators may have heard of him in recent times. If the gentleman had had a look he would have known that the Protective Security Co-ordination Centre, administered by my colleague Senator Tate, had given a couple of weeks notice, by telex, to the Queensland Special Branch. I am happy to table this telex; it goes through my itinerary in great detail. What sort of an inquiry could not find that out?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your itinerary for tomorrow?

—I will discuss it with the honourable senator later. I will be in Port Douglas and Cairns, if the honourable senator is interested, trying to do what Senator Puplick and the honourable senator's Party will not do-that is, save the rainforests. This telex was sent weeks in advance.
—We are not interested.

—Senator MacGibbon is not interested in the fact that the report of a police tribunal in Queensland is so abysmal. Does he support it? I always thought that the Liberal Party in Queensland was trying to distance itself, but Senator MacGibbon is right in there and he is welcome to be. Having exposed this telex, which I table for the information of honourable senators, might I say that even local citizens such as Joan Bailey, the taxi driver, were entitled to be consulted because they were outraged by what they saw. Millions of people saw it on television. It staggers me that the Liberal Party is willing to go along with the National Party of Australia in this sort of disgraceful cover-up.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the Government's decision to establish the Aviation Central Training College in the Australian Capital Territory. I ask: Will the college be constructed in the Australian Capital Territory as recommended by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Works? Why has the appointment of a successful tenderer for the construction of the simulator wing of the college not yet been announced and construction not yet commenced at the college site? Will the simulator be completed in Canberra on schedule? If so, when will construction commence?

—That matter is being dealt with-very competently, I might add-by my colleague Mr Duncan and I am not up to date with the latest developments in relation to the tendering process and the timetable that is envisaged. The future of the training college is the subject of some further internal discussion at the moment. If that discussion leads to any change of direction or intention from that which has previously been foreshadowed I will make sure that an announcement to that effect is immediately made.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The thrust of my question was: Will the college be constructed in Canberra, in accordance with the Government's decision? Does the answer that the Minister has just given indicate that there is some risk that the college may now not be built in the national capital and may be built in some other place?
—I have answered the question to the best of my ability. I have nothing further to add.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, refers to the resignation from the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) in the first four months of this financial year of 75 pilots compared with the annual graduation of 55 to 60 pilots. Is it a fact that Air Vice-Marshal Ray Funnell has directed that flying training be given priority although the rate of pilot training is governed by the retention of qualified flying instructors? Is it not also a fact that the RAAF has a scheme whereby projects can be progressed and some positions filled on a temporary basis by employing suitably qualified and experienced officers from the Reserve, but that this does not apply so far as pilots and flying instructors are concerned? Is it not a fact that the great majority of experienced pilots and qualified flying instructors who have left the permanent Air Force are in the Reserve by their own choice? Would it not be a good idea for the RAAF to utilise flying instructors from the Reserve to assist with training as an interim measure until experienced levels within the permanent Air Force increase?

—As Senator Harradine would be aware, the question of separation rates in the RAAF has been raised on several occasions in this chamber and also explored in some depth at Estimates Committee E. I think at some stage the honourable senator may have referred to this concept in casual conversation. I have not yet had a chance to raise this matter with the Minister for Defence. I will undertake to do so and get a detailed response as to the feasibility of the honourable senator's suggestion, hopefully by the end of the week.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that, for the 1987-88 financial year, single age pensioners in receipt of income other than their pensions amounting to anything above $192 a year will be forced to lodge a taxation return? Is the Minister aware that this is in contrast with the position in 1984 when the effective tax free threshold was $984 per annum? Does the Minister not agree that it is an impost on the pensioners and an uneconomic exercise for officers of the Australian Taxation Office to process returns for such small amounts? Would it not be a more sensible approach to raise the pensioner rebate for single pensioners from $250 to $450 so that single age pensioners would need to be in receipt of more than $1,000 to be affected by taxation?

—Somebody on the Opposition side was sufficient of a hypocrite to say `Hear, hear' when the question was finished. I do not know the revenue cost of the proposal; I will find that out. But in general, pensioners should count themselves extremely lucky that the Opposition was not returned to government because a number of people in the Opposition were advocating the non-indexation of pensions-just letting inflation erode the value of the pension itself. Of course, that would be very much more difficult for pensioners to cope with than paying some taxation if they have income over and above their pension income.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from the Minister's reply that he thinks pensioners are very well off now. Is that correct?
—No. I certainly did not say what Senator Brownhill apparently believes I said. I said that pensioners would be immeasurably worse off if the lot opposite had won the election.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, and it is on the subject of housing. Is the Minister aware of claims by Mr Porter, shadow Minister for housing and public administration, that home ownership in his electorate of Barker in South Australia has not changed in recent years? Are Mr Porter's claims correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to claims by Mr Porter along the lines suggested in the question by Senator Maguire. I have a response provided by the Special Minister of State. The 1986 census shows 34,925 households in Barker. Of these, 23,342 householders were owners or purchasers. The percentage of owner-occupier households was, therefore, 66.8 per cent. At the 1981 census, home ownership in the Barker electorate was as follows: of the 32,301 dwellings in the redefined Barker electorate, 12,300 were owned outright and 7,971 were being purchased; 20,879 dwellings were owner-occupied, or 64.6 per cent of the total. Consequently, home ownership in Barker has risen from 64.6 per cent to 66.8 per cent, or by 2.2 percentage points, despite the claims of Mr Porter that `the percentage has not changed since the 1981 census'.

ANSWER.PARA: It seems that Mr Porter has bungled by not allowing for the change in his electoral boundaries in 1984 following the increase in the size of the House of Representatives. It appears that Mr Porter, for the 1981 census, has used figures for the old and much larger boundaries of his electorate, and has compared them with the 1986 census figures collected within the new and smaller boundaries.

I also add that the current forecasts for the housing industry augur well for construction throughout Australia, including the electorate of Barker. The Indicative Planning Council recently estimated dwelling commencements for 1987-88 as between 126,000 and 130,000. The Council has since advised that the actual commencements will be the maximum forecast. That is an increase over the past two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Is it a fact that the Budget Papers predict that Australia's gross domestic product (GDP) will grow by 2 3/4 per cent during the current financial year? Is it also a fact that the Budget Papers predict that our current account deficit will amount to 4 per cent of our gross domestic product during the current financial year? Does it therefore follow that, even if the Budget forecasts are correct, the growth in Australia's economy will be slower than the rate of increase in our international indebtedness? Why are the Prime Minister and the Treasurer so smug about our present economic position when we are accumulating external debt faster than our capacity to repay it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I remember correctly, the Budget forecast for the current account deficit was $11.5 billion, which is, if not precisely 4 per cent of the forecast GDP, very close to it. It follows axiomatically, therefore, that with a growth rate of 2 3/4 per cent, and if all those forecasts are realised, debt as a proportion of GDP will increase. The cumulative deficit on the current account for the first four months of this financial year is about $1 billion lower than it was in the same four months of the preceding year, suggesting that the Budget forecast for the current account deficit for the year is on track and there is perhaps some mild reason for optimism that it might come in somewhat lower than that.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not sure what the purpose of the question is except to have the figures and the arithmetic confirmed. It is no secret that debt, as a proportion of GDP, will continue to rise, and it takes time to wind back these things, unless one is willing to take the option of plunging the economy into a catastrophic recession. One could close the current account deficit in that way, but it is highly speculative what the unemployment rate required to do that would be; it would probably be somewhere between 20 and 30 per cent. That is not the sort of option the Government is willing to take.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen a report in yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser reporting an address to the real estate marketing group, the Real Estate Professionals, by the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, self-styled New Right activist, long-time hopeful for Liberal Party of Australia pre-selection in the seat of Higgins, and extraparliamentary pretender for the Liberal Party leadership, Mr Andrew Hay, in which he called for a five-year program to reduce the component of the work force in the public sector to 30 per cent from 43 per cent? Does the Minister agree that 30 per cent is an appropriate target for the proportion of public sector employees within the total labour force? Will the Government establish a five-year plan to achieve that objective?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government certainly will not be establishing a five-year plan to achieve the objective of having 30 per cent of the work force in public employment, because just over 24 per cent of the work force is now in public employment-24.7 per cent to be precise. The Government has no intention of establishing a five-year plan, a 10-year plan or a 100-year plan to lift that percentage to 30 per cent, which Mr Hay believes would be an appropriate target.

ANSWER.PARA: If one wants more precision on the figures, I shall provide it: for the 1987 June quarter, total employment in Australia stood at 7,094,000, of which 1,752,000 were employed in the public sector, that is, local, State and Commonwealth government. It would seem that Mr Hay is still practising the skills he learned when he helped prepare Phillip Lynch's rubbery Budget in 1977. His figures are about as reliable as they were then. However, it demonstrates, apart from the pig ignorance of Mr Hay, the philosophical prejudices of the extreme Right, which keeps making assertions that have no basis in fact. If that is a fair measure of the standard of performance that can be expected from one of the would-be high-fliers of the Liberal Party, Roger Shipton should be quite safe in his seat for a very long time to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I ask: In regard to the business migration category, how many people have been allowed to enter Australia under this program in each of the last five years? What follow-up procedures are in place to ensure that those migrants who enter the country under that category do, in fact, remain the beneficial owners of their claimed half a million dollars and do not repatriate or repay all or part of that money to other parties?

—I thank Senator MacGibbon for his question, but I am afraid it is rather detailed in nature. I will have to ask him to place it on notice and I will get a response from the Minister as soon as possible.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister at all familiar with the program?

—I am certainly familiar with the program, but Senator MacGibbon asked me specific details over five years, and I do not have that material with me. I shall ask Minister Young to provide it as quickly as possible.

—My question is to the Acting Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women and for the Bicentenary, who I understand is Senator Button. Is the Minister aware of the great contributions made by Sir Paul E. Strzelecki, including being the first to discover gold and silver in Australia; leading the exploration of Gippsland, which led to subsequent settlement; climbing and naming Australia's tallest mountain, Mount Kosciusko; and publishing the first systematic account of the geography and geology of Tasmania? Is the Minister also aware that Sir Paul received his knighthood from a grateful Queen Victoria for his efforts in the relief of the great Irish famine of 1847-48? Is he further aware that the only recognition of Sir Paul's contribution is a small plaque on Mount Kosciusko, in spite of the fact that Pope John Paul II praised Strzelecki as perhaps the most famous Polish Australian?
—What about the Strzelecki Ranges?

—Does he also realise that the Polish Government has already indicated its willingness to pay $60,000 towards the cost of a proper monument and that the Australian Government has refused to match the offer? Why does his Government continue to maintain that the contributions of Sir Paul E. Strzelecki do not warrant the construction of a fitting and proper monument during the bicentennial celebrations of the country which Sir Paul did so much to help establish? Will the Minister take steps immediately to see that the monument is funded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the Government's decision not to contribute towards the cost of a monument to Sir Paul Strzelecki. It is not based on any lack of regard for his considerable achievements. Senator Ray pointed out, by way of interjection, that the Strzelecki Ranges are the most beautiful monument for which one could perhaps have wished. As Senator Sanders pointed out in his question, there is a plaque on Mount Kosciusko that would be good for people to see-good for the people rather than the plaque.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has no problem with the proposal for a further monument and would be happy if it were realised. The Government would welcome a contribution from the Polish Government towards erecting such a monument or even a donation from the Vatican. However, it is not the Government's role--

TALK.START.PARA: —Just lay off!

—Senator Sanders asked a question about the views expressed by His Holiness about this matter. It is not the Government's role to fund directly bicentennial community projects like the proposed monument. The Government established the Bicentenary Authority for the purpose of managing and co-ordinating the national celebration of the Bicentenary, including the disbursement of funds in response to applications from community groups. The Strzelecki monument proposal was considered by the national office of the Bicentenary Authority and the New South Wales State Council of the Authority and both bodies decided that the monument should not be supported. Under those circumstances and given the current economic climate, it would not be appropriate for a special allocation to be made to fund the proposal. However, in light of Senator Sanders's interest in the matter, I shall bring his question to the attention of the Bicentenary Authority.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR THE ENVIRONMENT AND THE ARTS: RAVENSHOE VISIT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. I refer the Minister to his response to Senator Jones earlier as to his description of the treatment he claimed he received at the hands of the people in far north Queensland and his subsequent back door escape. Can the Minister explain the difference between that alleged treatment and the gracious and hospitable treatment offered by the people of far north Queensland to John Howard and Senator Puplick, on three occasions, and other Liberal senators and members? Is it because of the authoritarian style jack-booted approach of a heavy-handed government to the real concerns of ordinary, decent Australians who are genuinely concerned about their future and those of their children and their communities?

—My treatment was even worse than Senator Parer thinks. When they took me into the forest I was given only a sandwich. Senator Puplick was given a barbecued steak. I have to tell honourable senators why Senator Puplick got a barbecued steak.
—Because they were too busy grilling you.

—Oh, the wit of the man from Tasmania! I think he used to be on the front bench. I remember going back to Queensland about two months ago and I can recall being asked, while I was in Ravenshoe and speaking from a truck, where the Liberal Party stands on this issue. I said to the people of Ravenshoe, `I do not know. You will have to ask them'. They have been asking that question for a long time and so has the rest of Australia, and none of us has received an answer. The reason those Liberals were treated better is that presumably they and Senator Parer are prepared to go along with Senator Boswell, Senator MacGibbon and the rednecks to ensure the rainforests are destroyed. We want to save them.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to a report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald that the Liberal Party President, John Elliott, had told a Liberal Party lunch in Adelaide yesterday that the Australian dollar should be more properly valued at about US61c. Does the Government agree with Mr Elliott that Australia's exchange rate should be targeted at US61c to improve our competitiveness and trade performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report in the Sydney Morning Herald. If the exchange rate were around US61c or US62c, no doubt, in the short term, Australian industry would be more internationally competitive. Whether it would be in the longer term depends upon a number of other variables which may well be affected by the lower exchange rate. I was asked whether the Government has any intention of targeting that rate. The answer is no. The Government does not have any intention of targeting that or any other rate for that matter. That sort of policy went out the window when the Australian dollar was floated nearly four years ago.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Opposition had won the election in July and had introduced its Budget built on supply-side voodoo, there is little doubt that Mr Elliott would have had the very much lower exchange rate that he wants, because that sort of Budget would have touched off such a panic in the financial market that he might well have got an exchange rate of half that, in the end, and a commensurate inflation rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—`Rubbish', says Senator Stone. Had it won the election, the Opposition would have been committed to implementing an irresponsible Budget, loaded, as I said, built on supply-side voodoo-the very policy that has got the United States into its present position. It is worth noting that this is the second time this week that Mr Elliott has publicly commented on fundamental questions of economic policy, despite the assurance that he was apparently required to give to the parliamentary leadership-such as it is-that he would not be making public comments on economic policy. This week not only have we heard two comments from Mr Elliott, but also that other extraparliamentary pretender to Liberal Party leadership, Andrew Hay, commented about economic policy. I mentioned that earlier in Question Time. It is worth noting that on the steps of Parliament House this morning Mr Howard stated the following in response to a question about this matter:

ANSWER.PARA: I don't make it a practice, nor does the Liberal Party, of nominating a particular level-
that is, a particular level for the dollar.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. I ask whether she is aware of the urgency motion which was passed unanimously by the Australian Council of Local Government Associations at its annual conference on 11 November 1987 and which read:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. That this Conference involving representatives of the 836 Local Government Councils in Australia expresses its abhorrence at the recommendation of the Goran Report that elected democracy be removed from the central area of the City of Sydney and replaced by a State Government appointed Authority.

2. That Australian Local Government calls on the New South Wales Government to adhere to the International Declaration of local Self Government, adopted by the International Union of Local Authorities and supported by the Australian Government, and immediately restore elected Local Government to the City of Sydney, with elections to be held prior to 1 January 1988.

Does the Minister intend to speak with the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Unsworth, to ensure that democracy is restored to the city of Sydney? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Government still condones the action of the New South Wales Labor Government in removing a democratically elected city council for its own political expedience?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Calvert for the question. Yes, I am aware of the motion passed by the Australian Council of Local Government Associations. I have already indicated publicly that I am very concerned about the implications of the recommendation that has been made to the New South Wales Government. I have communicated my concern about the principle to Mr Unsworth's office and I have also spoken to the office of the New South Wales Minister for Local Government. Local government bodies are established and have powers devolved to them by State and Territory legislation. In answer to the second part of Senator Calvert's question, the dismissal of the Sydney City Council is essentially a matter for the State Government.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I have considerable concern in regard to State government-and I speak generally about all State governments in Australia-relationships with local government. For this reason I am quite happy to speak publicly about the issue. There is a very delicate balance between a State government taking arbitrary decisions and acting responsibly in protecting the people of that State. It is not for the Federal Government to intervene in that regard. I am sure that honourable senators on the other side who are always preaching to the Federal Government about States rights would agree totally with that principle. The replacement of a council, as recommended-and I stress that this is only a recommendation at this stage which I am sure will be given very full and detailed consideration by the New South Wales Government-by a semi-autonomous non-elected commission is of very considerable concern. It is certainly of concern to me as Federal Minister for Local Government and I know that it is of great concern to the Australian Council of Local Government Association, which has passed a resolution in this respect.

A recommendation which does not allow communities to have a say over the preferred direction of the development of their areas strikes at the very heart of democratic accountability. The residents of Ultimo, Pyrmont and the Rocks in New South Wales effectively would be disenfranchised with respect to local government if this recommendation were accepted. Let us remember that the debate about control of the central business districts is current not just in New South Wales. In my home State, the Queensland Government is dictating to the Brisbane City Council about the type and height of buildings in the central business district of Brisbane. There are similar debates in Victoria and Western Australia.

I hope that with calm and rational consultation and communication, and a genuine acceptance that local government is part of our three spheres of government and public policy planning, these issues can be resolved in a sensible and democratic way. I feel sure that this will be possible. This is one of the reasons why I am a strong advocate of constitutional recognition of local government. It is not that I want to place local government in any special or privileged position vis-a-vis State or Federal governments. I simply want to see local government recognised as a major policy-maker in the governmental process. It is vital that Federal, State and local governments communicate, consult and make the best possible decisions, as elected members, for the benefit of the people of Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STRATEGIC DEFENCE INITIATIVE PROGRAM: X-RAY LASER

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Australian Financial Review of 22 September 1987 which reports the presentation of the IR100 award in Chicago on 17 September to Queensland Science and Technology Ltd for its development of an X-ray laser for the United States (US) Department of Energy (DOE). I ask the Minister: Is the US Department of Energy the department responsible for US nuclear weapons production for research into certain directed energy weapons? Is not the DOE deeply involved in the strategic defence initiative (SDI) program? Can the Minister give an assurance, in line with the Government's opposition to the US SDI program, that the X-ray laser developed by Queensland Science and Technology Ltd will not contribute in any way to the SDI program and particularly to the SDI X-ray laser, which is to be powered by nuclear detonations in space in violation of a treaty between the super-powers? —I cannot give any assurances about any parts of that question because, although Senator Vallentine kindly passed this question to my office at 10.45 today, responsibility for preparing an answer runs across a number of portfolios. —My question is directed to the Acting Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. —I am afraid that, once again, without the benefit of some short prior notice of the questions coming from the other side, in the brief available to me I have nothing on the question which I know has been the subject of a lot of investigation at Estimates committee hearings. —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications, relates to the decision of Telecom Australia to centralise its country operations in Western Australia. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
