DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Minister for Transport and Communications to accept the draft report of the Departmental review team recommending substantial deregulation of the telecommunications industry and his capitulation to naked political pressures.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In bringing before the Senate this matter of public importance I seek to draw the attention of the Australian community to what is happening in the telecommunications industry. Despite the fact that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) made a very good announcement in September of this year in establishing a high-powered departmental review team to determine the future of the telecommunications industry-indeed, at that time he hoped that he would be able to make a significant public announcement on the future of that industry before Christmas-unfortunately there has been a slippage to the extent that the Minister is now saying that he does not expect to be able to make any such statement before February or March of next year. What is of much greater concern to the Australian community is the reason why there has been such slippage and the likely outcome of the deliberations and negotiations that are presently going on. I have to report that, sadly, the Minister's supposedly new-found verve and enthusiasm for deregulation have been sacrificed on the altar of political expediency. He has become a captive of union pressures and he is in the process of selling out the future of the telecommunications industry in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Those who had the good fortune to read a speech of the Minister delivered on Monday in relation to the privatisation debate would have been under no illusions about this loss of pristine beauty because the Minister said in his opening paragraph at a conference:

I hope you will forgive me for saying that the only privatisation debate that really matters in Australia at the moment is the one that will take place within the Australian Labor Party in the run-up to the next national conference in June 1988.

Apart from being monumental arrogance, it is also a very stark admission that the national interest of this country is subordinate and entirely subservient to the wishes and dictates of the Labor Party and its organisational wing. In other words, we are no longer concerned about what is in the best interests of the country, we are no longer concerned about how we can devise an efficient telecommunications industry or indeed the whole range of public trading enterprises that are in need of such drastic reform and massive injections of capital.

The Minister says that Government members are concerned to ensure that the party is on side and if it is not that is the end of the game. So the only debate in town, according to the Minister, is the internal machinations of the Labor Party. That is dead right as an explanation for why there has been a sell-out to date. In recent times a Telecom watchdog committee has been established inside Caucus comprising three members, two of whom are former Telecom Australia employees. The reason that that came about is that there was a proposal to perpetuate the Telecom monopoly in all of its present glory. The Minister's compromise involved establishing that committee on the basis that it would be entitled to have access to bureaucrats and Ministers: in other words, to lean on them to ensure that they were made acutely aware of the `political realities'. That is a tragedy. It is a tragedy not just for good government but a tragedy for what one would have hoped was a recognition that telecommunications is an expanding industry which has unlimited potential and which provides great opportunities for Australia if we are prepared to grasp them.

Unfortunately, the Minister's attitude was brought to the attention of the public on page 1 of the Australian Financial Review only a matter of a week or so back. In what I understand to be a very accurate description of the process it is indicated that the Minister had been presented with a series of policy options. Of those, some were highly deregulatory. The Minister made it clear that he was not going to wear that sort of suggestion and in effect sent the proposals back to the drawing board. That certainly is not the way in which the Minister ought to have gone about his task. It is necessary for any report, when it is ultimately forthcoming, to go before the structural adjustment committee of Cabinet for final decision. The Minister is capitulating in advance, pre-empting the debate and ensuring, in effect, that Cabinet does not have the full range of options before it.

What I do not think has been revealed to the Australian community to date is the real reason for such capitulation. The sad reality is that this is about the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association (ATEA) exercising industrial muscle, making it patently clear to the Minister that there will be massive industrial action unless and until he is prepared to bring pressure to bear on Telecom to negotiate redundancy packages that are, no doubt, extraordinarily generous. The fact is that there is no need for any such redundancy arrangements. There may well need to be transitional arrangements if the high water mark of the monopoly position at the moment-in other words, customer premises equipment, the installation of the first phone and the subsequent wiring and maintenance of customer premises-is deregulated.

At the moment there is a massive oversupply of labour. There are people who work about a five-hour day when they could well be working much harder and earning much more if they were in the private sector. There is little doubt that when the time comes, as it should, for that sector of the market to be opened up to competition those employees will be stampeding in their desire to exit from the public sector. They will be more than happy to form their own corporate arrangements and to set up maintenance and installation companies. One has only to look at the 1982 report of the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia and the proposal for teletricians, as they were called. It was clear to the Davidson Committee that, subject to setting satisfactory standards and monitoring adherence to them, there was absolutely no reason why this needed to be an area of monopoly. Yet five years have gone by. There was a four-year period in lotus land before the Minister made his announcement of the need for a fundamental review. What we are now seeing are the advanced stages of the total sell-out.

The tragedy will be that ultimately some minor concessions will be made, such as in regard to the installation of the first phone handset. At the moment the Telecom rental charge is about $120 a year. Telecom imputes a manufacturing cost in that charge of $40 per annum when, in reality, the cost of manufacturing plastic moulding of that sort is about $15. So there would be absolutely no concession in opening up that section of the industry. We desperately need much more extensive deregulation in that area. I fear that all the signs are adverse.

The ATEA has put it on the line to the Minister. It is no doubt acutely aware that the jobs of 3,000 to 4,000 of its members would be at risk. Indeed, in the article in the Australian Financial Review to which I referred there is even a suggestion that 23,000 Telecom jobs would be lost. That, of course, is the total number of technicians in the area, together with about 8,000 administrative staff most of whom would be rendered unnecessary in the event of deregulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only risk they would be subject to is that they would no longer be members of the union.

—Of course that is the union's concern. One would be justified in saying that the workers, at the end of the day, might see the light and realise that there is much money to be made out there in the real world. Of course, the union will not have a bar of it. It is trying to force the Minister to arrange union coverage, so that even if the employees are in the private sector they will still remain in the ATEA.
—Slave labour!

—Absolutely. One could understand why that union is wanting to exercise that sort of muscle, but it is totally unnecessary. There has been a very low attrition rate to date. I suspect that there could well be an almost total departure of those people. The important thing is that they would not lose jobs. There is excessive demand for the work that is carried out by those electricians and trades assistants and they would be well and better employed in the private sector. I make it clear that there is absolutely no justification for any forms of golden parachutes with which the unions might be hitting the Minister over the head at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Telecom's costs in that area are completely out of line with private sector reality-probably 50 to 60 per cent higher than necessary. There are vast opportunities within the customer access network for productivity gains. Again, it is very sad that the business and service manual which Telecom put out recently conceded that even Telecom's private target of one per cent productivity growth was inadequate. It is clear that everyone realises that there are vast gains to be made if only the Government will bite the bullet. Of course, it does not require much more than political will to do that.

Another example that I will give relates to cellular radio. Telecom presently charges about $5,000 for this equipment. That price is achieved because Telecom regulates the standards to be applied in the manufacture of all such equipment, so the price is always at about the same level as that of the Telecom article. There is little doubt that if Telecom were not the regulator of its own equipment and the approver of its competitors' equipment, the great demand for those products would mean very significant falls in cost, probably down to about $1,500. There are any number of examples around the world of the explosion of demand for cellular radios. Yet at the moment Telecom is insisting that this equipment remain within its monopoly province.

Again, I challenge the Minister to tell the Senate and the community whether Australian consumers will be as ill-served as they have been to date by current arrangements or whether the very high usage fees, which include connection charges, will be maintained as a sole Telecom preserve. At present, STD rates operate in regard to the use of cellular radios in the metropolitan area. There is absolutely no justification for that. Similarly, there is no justification for the imposition of a fixed charge maintenance fee of about $50. I therefore ask why cellular radios cannot be regarded as part of the network. At the moment they are not. They are not treated, as a form of value added service (VAS) and therefore they remain not subject to Telecom's own value added services policy. But one could well ask for the justification for that policy. There is much to be said for freeing up the market completely in that VAS area.

The third area I wanted to touch on relates to Aussat Pty Ltd. It is clearly not viable at present. Its annual report discloses its latest loss, and it is clear that it is not able to make a profit because of the undue influence that Telecom has brought to bear on it. It should be allowed either to be taken over by a broadcaster or to diversify its services. At present, it is able to do neither. It could provide switched services at a much lower cost, if given the opportunity. It could give some of its capacity to Telecom to enable it to provide switched network services but at the moment, of course, it is hidebound and hamstrung by Telecom's very limiting arrangements. The end result is that there is very little opportunity to use Aussat services. Many major corporations would welcome the opportunity to make use of leased lines from Aussat, as back-up capacity for data and voice transmission, but at the moment they are simply not able to because of those restrictive arrangements.

I submit that at present the Minister is determined not to make the concessions which he recognises are necessary. He is not prepared to acknowledge the many exciting opportunities that lie ahead if only we can regard the telecommunications industry as market driven, no longer technology driven and certainly not union driven. We have to be prepared to take account of some of the very real capital problems that will confront Telecom. It is not just a capital intensive industry; it has about 90,000 employees. Of course in many ways they constitute part of the problem. There is a lot of obsolete equipment in the system that needs to be replaced but, of course, Telecom is exempt from any privatisation discussion, by the Minister's own definition.

Many inefficiencies in the service relate not only to the customer premises equipment area but also to the maintenance of PABXs and key systems, such as the Commander system. Those private exchanges have been a Telecom monopoly for very many years. Telecom has recently been forced to approve two-line PBXs which are much cheaper, provide much greater billing information and much more effective software updates and have bearer facilities. Yet, Telecom has only very recently allowed those PBX systems to become competitive with its own system. Therefore, there is a very desperate need also in the key systems area for increased competition.

In the customer premises equipment (CPE) area which occupies, as I said, about a quarter of the work force, it is already clear from a recent trade practices decision that the Telecom monopoly is not sustainable. The Minister and the Government have done nothing to respond to that decision, which is more than 12 months old. I know for a fact that there are submissions that have gone to the Government spelling out some much more severe limitations on that monopoly and which, in fact, make it clear that Telecom is achieving and maintaining its monopoly position as a result of bluff. There are many ways in which the cross-subsidisation arrangements could be made more effective, by which there could be regard to capacity to pay. Means testing could be introduced to ensure that proper pricing charges are arrived at. If there is a booming tourist industry in this country, and we hope there is, there is no justification for rural and remote tourist operators to be getting the same sorts of massive subsidies as might operate in regard to those on lower incomes. These are just some of the very many opportunities that are going begging at present.

As a comparative example, in the United States in the customer premises equipment area, which is something like 35 times the size of the Australian market, there would need to be a work force of 2.4 million if it were to be equated with the Australian arrangement, whereas at the moment it is currently below one million and falling. In other words, if one were to translate those figures into the CPE work force in Australia it could effectively be halved, despite the fact that the United States has higher maintenance costs.

There are many growth areas that Telecom would do well in if allowed to compete on a level playing field with others in the market-place. At the moment the Minister shows all the signs of doing the Australian community a great disservice by not being prepared to embark on the sorts of deregulation that in his more unguarded moments he has been prepared to acknowledge have validity. It would seem that the pressures from Caucus, the trade union movement and the vested interests around the country are likely to ensure that there will be very little and, at best, incremental, change. Even the Managing Director of Telecom acknowledges the justification for having an independent regulatory authority. Yet, we have not even heard much about that to date. What we have heard is a campaign of disinformation, the sorts of Caucus pre-emptive strikes that, no doubt, have put fear into the heart of the Minister. The end sufferer in all these machinations is the Australian consumer, and Telecom subscribers in particular.

I conclude by saying that I regret the fact that the Minister has not been prepared to take on board all those options, including the more deregulatory ones; that he has been so timid in his approach in this area that he has sent that review committee away to tailor its final recommendations. I hope that it is not too late for him to recant and that he will acknowledge that there are very many deregulatory opportunities that must be embraced. There are transitional arrangements that will need to be put in place but the last thing the Australian community wants or deserves is golden handshakes and union driven telecommunications industries in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess to a certain disappointment with Senator Alston. Once upon a time I thought that he was a very sound, sensible sort of fellow, a good mainstream Missenite Victorian wet, resisting the Huns and Visigoths of the Right Wing down there and generally being an all-round Liberal of a kind that one could reasonably deal with and could reasonably take into account. He is now drying out before our eyes. He is entranced by the prospect of becoming a sort of Young Lochinvar of privatisation and deregulation. He is entranced, I suppose, by the prospect of making his way within an allegedly dry Liberal Party of Australia these days by taking the high ground and smiting all around him with an array of propositions which, as I will demonstrate in a moment, are palpably nonsensical. He seems to have succumbed in the process. I do not know whether it is the tutelage of Senator Puplick or Senator Michael Baume, regrettably neither of whom was here today to hear his pupil. But he has succumbed to the kind of lurid, vulgar grandstanding that I really previously did not think he was capable of. No doubt it is a function of the frustration of opposition-the impotence of opposition. Some of that is becoming evident in the kind of language he is using. I see that the matter of public importance talks about `nakedness'. He talks elsewhere about the need for me to `cool my ardour'. I can understand the frustration he is feeling. I can appreciate the impotence and the awfulness of it all over there on those Opposition benches. But really that is no excuse for the kind of nonsense that is being peddled in the terms of this alleged matter of public importance before us today. I remind the Senate of it. What Senator Alston is asking us to take seriously is a proposition in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Minister for Transport and Communications-
that is me-
to accept the draft report of the Departmental review team recommending substantial deregulation of the telecommunications industry and his capitulation to naked political pressures.

I just say that that is based on a series of premises. It is based on the premise that there was a draft report recommending substantial deregulation of telecommunications. It is based on the premise that I failed to accept that report. It is based on the premise that there was political pressure brought to bear, `naked' in character-whatever that means. It is based on the premise that I capitulated to the said `naked' political pressure. Might I say that every one of those premises is wrong. There was no draft report to which I responded by way of acceptance, rejection, modification or otherwise, so the question of political pressure-naked or otherwise-simply does not arise; nor does the question of my capitulation to that pressure. However, I make the point for the record that there was and has been no political pressure, of which I am aware, that remotely succumbs to that sort of description. There are always people bashing particular drums when major policy matters of moment are being debated, discussed, analysed and considered within government. Of course there has been plenty of that in the context of the telecommunications review. But it is not the sort of thing which Senator Alston's highly coloured view of the world has led him to articulate in the terms of this matter of public importance.

The spurious character of the language he has employed as an excuse for getting himself before an unsuspecting Senate today is, I think, made particularly clear when one compares it with the language in a letter that he wrote to me just a few days ago, on 12 November, when he said to me, amongst other reasonably amiable pleasantries:
I trust that media reports that you have rejected the preliminary report of the Telecom Review Group are incorrect. It would be very disappointing if your initial ardour-
here we go again-
for extensive competition and deregulation in this vital industry has been cooled, if not frozen, by naked-
here we go yet again-
threats of industrial action.

I draw attention to the character of that particular prose. It is inquiring, questioning and trusting. It is taking the view that media reports may well be inaccurate, highly coloured and have an ardour of their own. Senator Alston is asking in that letter whether it is the case. However, today by contrast we have in terms of this particular matter of public importance, simply, as I said, lurid, vulgar assertions being made, making claims that matters of fact have in fact occurred and been the case, and not allowing any room for questioning of that. As I have said, those assertions are quite unfounded. Senator Alston should be-whether he will be or not is another question-contrite for the way in which he has brought this matter forward.

Let me describe what has been happening. The telecommunications review exercise was set in train by me in a speech to the International Institute of Communications in Sydney on 3 September when I identified four large questions and a number of sub-questions which I believed then, and still believe now, needed to be comprehensively, systematically and honestly addressed. Let me show, for the record, what those questions are, because essentially they are the framework within which the present tele- communications review is proceeding. My speech went as follows:
1. What should be the nature and extent of the monopoly powers granted to our telecommunications carriers?
Included here are such questions as:

What precisely are the community service and cross-subsidy obligations that an organisation like Telecom should have, and to what extent are monopoly powers necessary for such obligations to be honoured?
What other national or public interests are served by the retention of the various existing monopoly rights?
Where precisely should the boundary lines between monopoly and competition be drawn in the provision of Basic Network, Value Added Services and Customer Premises Equipment.
2. To what extent should private sector involvement in the provision of telecommunications equipment and services be allowed or encouraged?
Included here are such questions as:
In areas where the telecommunications carriers have no legislative monopoly, are there nonetheless barriers to effective private sector competition which should be lowered or removed?
Should any private equity be sought for any part of the carriers' operations, and if so to what extent?

3. To what extent should the telecommunications carriers be restructured or relieved of Government constraints to enable them to perform their functions more effectively, and in particular compete effectively in open commercial markets?
Included here are such questions as:
Should the relationship between Telecom, OTC, and Aussat be changed or clarified?

Which, if any, of the constraints imposed by the Government in relation to superannuation policy, borrowing, public service employment, industrial relations handling, tendering practices, contract approval and the like should continue to apply?
4. How should the industry be economically and technically regulated?
Included here are such questions as:
To what extent would more precise definition of the boundaries of competition and monopoly reduce the weight of the argument in favour of independent regulation?
Which if any of Telecom's present regulatory functions should be handled independently, and if so by what kind of agency?

Those questions, which Senator Alston was kind enough to acknowledge in his speech were the right questions, are still the questions that are being asked, every one of them, and answered, every one of them, in the review that is now proceeding. There is no question of backing away from the scope of that inquiry, or from the consequences of where that particular analysis leads us. It has been made clear by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and me in various speeches over the past couple of months that we are not in the business of privatising Telecom Australia or, for that matter, Australia Post, in the sense of selling it off in whole or in part. To the extent that one might have thought that an option of that kind was subsumed in possible answers to one or more of those questions-I do not think it was, but one could have thought that-that option has been explicitly ruled out, for reasons that have been stated by me and the Prime Minister elsewhere. Certainly, all the other questions that are at issue here, including those very sensitive questions about first telephone monopolies and PABX maintenance monopolies, and so on, are very much on the table and very much open to questions, and they are being addressed by the Government with an open mind.

It is the case that I have established, to consider these questions, in the first instance, a Department-based task force headed by First Assistant Secretary Mike Hutchinson, with as consultants to it Professor Henry Ergas and a number of other people including representatives from Telecom, and Telecom is closely involved in the whole process. That particular departmental task is working with a wider interdepartmental group of officials preparing material for the Structural Adjustment Committee of Cabinet. It is not focusing on drafting recommendations for Cabinet at this stage, and perhaps will not ever do so.

The essence of the exercise is to outline the issues, identify the problems and certainly to identify some broad possible approaches to those problems, but it is not in the nature of a familiar report writing exercise generating recommendations for acceptance or rejection. It is a misconception of the nature of the analytical process that is presently going on. Not only was there no draft report in existence at the time that Senator Alston's highly coloured imagination seems to have worked upon-no doubt aided by some equally highly coloured imagination of the Press-for either me or Cabinet, other than in the form of half-completed papers around the place, to which I had no particular access, but also no draft report has been completed even yet, as I understand it, and it is not proposed to lodge it before the Cabinet until the end of this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that you have not been given a series of options?

—What I am saying is that I obviously talked, on an ad hoc basis, with particular members of my departmental task force and, when I sat down with them for a substantial part of the day on 22 October to talk about the issues in a systematic way, I did so in order to identify and understand what the issues were, and to look carefully in particular at issues like the nature and scale of community service obligations, how they could be quantified, options for continuing to finance such obligations, and a series of other extremely complex issues. Of course questions arose as to different ways that one could go down in responding to the nature of the problems thus identified and thus, where appropriate, quantified, but it was not then, and has not yet been, a matter of choosing between particular options or limiting lines of inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly expressed some views as to what may or may not be realistically achievable in some of those areas. I do not propose to share those views with Senator Alston or anyone else publicly, much to his disappointment, no doubt. However, the point that I am making is that an inquiry of this kind must necessarily, by its very nature, be one that is genuinely approached in a spirit of open-minded inquiry and a willingness to understand the issues and appreciate what the implications of different possible courses of actions are. It is quite absurd and inaccurate to suppose that consideration of any of the basic issues that I outlined, or threw up in the form of questions in that speech back in September, or the answers to any of those questions, have been foreclosed.

The Caucus itself, which seems to have so infuriated Senator Alston by its involvement in this exercise, did not become involved until a number of days after the meeting which seems to have generated some of this leakage to which I have referred. The Caucus did not become involved until 27 October, following a motion that I moved myself in the party room to establish a working group to liaise more closely with both me and the interdepartmental committee, and in particular with my departmental task force, for the duration of the exercise. I appreciate that the Liberal Party of Australia and its representatives are always very unhappy about the notion of consultative processes. They have always operated on the Fuhrer principle in terms of their party organisation, where some particular line either springs full-blown into the mind of the leader and is passed down to the unsuspecting and uncomplaining ranks below, or, at best, a series of limited options are thrown up by a compliant bureaucracy to a particular Minister who will choose between them-sometimes, I suspect, by the turn of a knife on a table-and then, having made that decision, force his will downwards again on the rest of the system. Woe betide, notwithstanding all the ideology to the contrary, anyone who chooses to question the party line thus imposed.

We do not operate that way in terms of our choice of Ministers or our approach to input in the policy-making process from the movement or the party at large. We do not operate that way in terms of the way in which we relate to our own rank and file parliamentary party members whose views we respect, and who are intelligent human beings in their own right, elected as such and conscious of the mood and sentiments of the nation at large and keen to contribute in that process. They are views we fully take into account in any decision-making in which we engage, because if we do not we will have to suffer the consequences: but that is an aspect of the matter I shall not dwell on at any great length on this occasion.

What we have in this particular instance is not some large Monty Python ministerial foot stamping on the ranks of the backbenchers who might have views to the contrary. We have participation in the policy making process by the Party as a whole through its representatives. If they can bring some accumulated experience to bear in terms of their previous incarnations in industry, government or business enterprises, or come what may, that is all to the good and the skills and contributions that they make are very much appreciated.

There are very real issues involved in this particular matter. Of course, it is primarily about getting efficiency and effectiveness into our nation's infrastructure and the industry policy that is associated with that. But it is also a matter of coming to grips with some quite fundamental issues about cross subsidies and about the human implications-the employment implications certainly-both of people working directly in the industry and, of course, of people working indirectly with Telecom Australia by virtue of their role in supplying manufactured components and so on to it. Of course they are issues which have to be understood. We have to understand the implications of any particular path one might go down, as well as just being entranced by all the high technology whiz-bangery of it all which has so excited Senator Alston.

It is not a matter of succumbing to anybody's pressure; that is a crude and vulgar caricature of the situation. Rather, it is a recognition that there are complex issues involved and that they require sensible balancing. That is the approach that I have adopted to privatisation and I expect similar support and involvement from the Party as we work our way through that particular complex set of issues. I make no apology whatsoever, notwithstanding what Senator Alston had to say, for saying, as I did on Monday, that the only debate that matters about privatisation in this country in the next six months is the one that is taking place within the Labor Party. That simply reflects the reality which Senator Alston and his ilk have not yet quite come to grips with-that it happens to be the Labor Party that is governing this country at the moment. However much Senator Alston may huff and puff and fulminate and carry on, however much he may debate the issue in his own ranks and however much kudos he might generate for himself by demonstrating that he is ahead of the field and drier than anybody else in sight, it is not going to make a hap'orth of difference to the particular kinds of policy conclusions we reach because we, regrettably as those opposite might regard it, but triumphantly as we do, happen to be running the country at the moment and it is what we have sorted out in our own ranks that is going to determine the outcome. What happens after that is in the lap of the gods and history and so on, but it is just simply a statement of the obvious.

I make no apology for the approach that I have adopted to this matter. I am not proposing to spend any time telling honourable senators where we are at in terms of the kinds of conclusions that tentatively some of us might be beginning to reach about the answers to some of these problems. So far as I am concerned, I approach and I continue to approach all these things with a totally open mind. I will weigh, I will balance the arguments and I will make my recommendations to the Cabinet accordingly and I believe that the Cabinet will respond in the same way.

I repeat what I said at the Australian Information Industry Association last week in what Senator Alston was gracious enough to refer to, in conversation with me yesterday, as a very boring speech. I think he is probably right about that. I, in fact, told him that that is the secret of ministerial success. It is far more sensible to make boring speeches than to make the other kind. I have learnt by hard experience. But be that as it may, I might finish up by quoting one paragraph of that speech which I think bears repetition. I said:

. . . the outcome we arrive at will not be the result of any ideological biases, but rather a result born of the desire to see services improved and delivered more efficiently and in a way which is acceptable to the whole Australian community. We are not in the business of taking enormous risks to pursue benefits whose existence depends on accepting some mystic faith, and whose size is dubious.

What I am saying-what I was saying in that speech and what I am saying now-is that we approach these very complex and difficult policy issues with an open mind, tempered with a healthy sense of realism. It is an approach that I commend to Senator Alston and the Opposition.

In regard to the issue of means testing which was raised by Senator Alston, I wonder what his colleague Senator McGauran, and other people like that whose capital assets would be enormous and who would obviously be wanting telephones in remote areas, would think about that.

These are policies which are designed to win the approval of bankers and businessmen. They are policies which the previous Fraser Government flirted with in theory by not in practice. We often see Opposition senators salivating on the Opposition benches when the Government takes action attempting to push them along just a little further. They are policies that are based on the assumption that it is simply bad for a government to own public enterprises, to regulate, to spend or to borrow to achieve socially desirable aims and conversely, that private ownership and private borrowing with little or no government regulation is automatically good. Shades of Dickensian England come to mind in that kind of assumption which is not based on fact or rationality. I think it is fortunate that at this stage at least there do not appear to be the numbers on the Government side for those gung ho Cabinet heavies who would really like to go down the road which Senator Alston continues to point out to them.

I noted in a recent industry publication that the Australian Telecom Users Group-a misnamed group if ever there were one-which represents only the very large Telecom corporate users and a group which apparently has no regard for the service to domestic subscribers, has been very pleased with the way its 20-page submission to the review task force was received and it was optimistic that the views it expressed would be reflected in the recommendations of the task force. When I read something like that I wonder what is worrying Senator Alston. It was conveniently not mentioned by the Minister when he talked about the capital requirements of publicly-owned enterprises. The Minister, in his speech this week on privatisation in Australia, said that at the end of the day the crunch problem is the need to periodically inject public enterprises with large funds from the Budget. That issue really needs to be addressed. However, in the case of Telecom it is not necessarily a valid excuse for moving down the privatisation road. Another area that has not been looked at is the high level of local purchasing by Telecom. Ninety per cent of high technology purchases are of Australian products and, of course, there are employment ramifications from some of the options that are available. For example, the removal of the terminal monopoly would result in the loss of 10,000 to 12,000 jobs. I am sure that it would not take Senator Walsh long to estimate the economic cost of that in retrenchments, let alone the social cost.

I think it is worth spending a few minutes talking about how the domestic and small business consumers will be affected by some of the options being floated, because up until now their interests have been universally ignored in the political debate about the future of telecommunications. There is no doubt that, if the deregulation of Telecom takes place along the lines that have been suggested, there will be a dramatic increase in costs for ordinary Australians-not just those Australians living outside the capital cities-and an equally dramatic decline in services, particularly for rural subscribers. DEBATE.TITLE: GUIDELINES FOR THE PREPARATION OF DEPARTMENTAL ANNUAL REPORTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to speak to the guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports. It is important to point out that until 1982 there was no requirement on Federal Government departments to produce annual reports and then table them in Parliament. After 82 years of Federal government, that is extraordinary. It is also extraordinary that it has taken a further five years for guidelines to be produced for the preparation of departmental annual reports. I would have thought it was very important that statutory authorities and government departments make as full a report to the nation as they possibly can, outlining the discharge of their duties and the expenditure of public funds. Nevertheless, until recent years they have not been compelled to do so. Until now, no guidelines have been laid down, as I understand it, for the preparation of annual reports.

I do not intend to go into the detail of the guidelines because they are very detailed and they look to me as though they cover the area thoroughly. However, I draw attention to general principle No. 8 which states:

Reports should be prepared on a financial year basis and be available for the estimates debates in the Budget Sittings. When reports are not available in time, departments should provide an interim statement in A4 duplicated form (not including financial statements which have yet to be audited) for the information of the Parliament.
General principle 8 continues:
In any case, reports should be available within 6 months of the end of the reporting period.

Quite clearly, they should be available before that six months is up unless extraordinary circumstances exist. Some departments are trying very hard to get annual reports to the Estimates committees in time for proper consideration to be given to them before the committees conduct their hearings. In that regard, I must pay tribute to the Attorney-General's Department, which provided a draft report to Estimates Committee E. However, I also note that in the three weeks since the Estimates committees have completed their hearings 28 annual reports have been tabled in Parliament. By the nature of things, those 28 annual reports must have been available in draft form at the time the Estimates committees were sitting. They include reports which were of particular interest to me, including the annual report of the Australian Federal Police and the Defence Report.

I also draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that annual reports in the list provided to me by the Clerks date back to 1985 and 1986. I refer to the National Health and Medical Research Council which, on 29 October, tabled its 1985 report as well as its 1986 report. That is just not good enough. That is not the only body that has been so slow in producing annual reports for the Parliament. I know that the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has a list of statutory bodies that do not provide Parliament with up to date reports. The Opposition is not suggesting that these should be exercises in self-aggrandisement; it is not suggesting the reports need to be glossy publications or very expensive. But it is important that information be provided to Parliament and to the public.

Government departments need to be accountable, and I draw the attention of the Senate to the reports of Estimates Committee E and Estimates Committee A, both of which criticised the lack of availability of departmental reports, including reports from the Department of Defence and the Parliament House Construction Authority. To that end I refer honourable senators to page 9 of the report of Estimates Committee E. I also draw the attention of honourable senators to a quotation at page 13 of the report of Estimates Committee A, which includes the following warning delivered by the President of the Senate, President Sibraa:

It might be that the search for style is delaying the delivery of substance . . . Form should not obstruct, delay or hide substance, which can be prepared economically and must be presented in a timely way.

I believe we require early access to the text of reports, to the basic contents, as distinct from form. Parliament is entitled to information on what is being undertaken by the Federal departments, as are the people of Australia. I welcome these guidelines and I shall keep a close watch to see how much better the departments can perform in producing reports to Estimates committees next year.

At the outset I make the comment that this will probably be the second last report of the River Murray Commission because legislation currently before the Parliament-the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987-will replace the River Murray Commission with the new Murray-Darling Basin Commission. Historically, various bodies and governments involved with the River Murray have taken a narrow, single issue approach, focusing on water quantity-water quality issues were added to the brief of the River Murray Commission only in 1983-and water supplies for irrigation, and urban and industrial use.

This approach has failed. It has failed to take into account the interconnectedness of the river system with other natural resources in the area, such as wetland areas, forests, agricultural land, and natural bushland. The Australian Democrats are very pleased to see that the new River Murray legislation provides for an holistic approach to basin resource management and will address itself to water, land, and environmental management practices.

The Australian Democrats believe that this approach, the total catchment management approach, is of fundamental importance and is most desirable, and is the only approach that is likely to be effective in this particular type of environment, especially in the delicate environment that we have on this most arid continent in the world. This approach has been promoted for a number of years by many people, including the Australian Democrats. It has been a matter of policy of the Democrats for its full 10 years of existence. I specifically mention the Catchment Education Trust, which was led by the venerable Ernest Jackson, who is now based in Albury, a town which is recognised by the annual report of the River Murray Commission as the largest population centre on the River Murray.

The total catchment management approach is, I am pleased to say, now part of the national conservation strategy. A recent paper from the New South Wales Soil Conservation Service, entitled Total Catchment Management, shows that the approach has become umbrella policy under which other land resource policies will fit in that State. In Victoria also, catchment management has become the recognised process.

Put simply, total catchment management involves the co-ordinated use and management of land, water, vegetation and other natural resources on a catchment basis. Its implementation seeks to balance resource utilisation and resource conservation through the minimisation of land and soil degradation and the maintenance of water yield and quality. The New South Wales Soil Conservation Service document, Total Catchment Management, states:

Catchments are a logical unit for natural resource planning and management as they are natural systems of interdependent components (of land, water and vegetation) whose boundaries are readily identifiable.
The scope of Total Catchment Management is wide, and includes the full range of land uses-conservation, forestry, agriculture, recreation, urban and industrial and infrastructure development.
The same document also states:

Total Catchment Management will be achieved by various means including development of greater interdepartmental co-operation, an increased community awareness of a land conservation ethic through education and participation in programs and the development of TCM strategies for each of the major river and lake catchments in New South Wales.

As I have said, it is a most desirable system, a system which, if it had been implemented many years ago, would have enabled the River Murray Commission to have been more effective than it has been. I note from the report this comment:
. . . salinity of River Murray waters generally remained at acceptable levels during the irrigation season.

I suggest that for many people, particularly those in the Kerang area, that is an arguable point. What are acceptable levels of salinity in one area certainly are not acceptable in another. I believe quite strongly that under the new system of looking at the Murray-Darling Basin in totality, we will be able to see some redress for the severe environmental problems in that area.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourteenth report of 1987 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, concerning the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987, the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987 (No. 2), the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Horticultural Export Charge Bill 1987, the Horticultural Levy Bill 1987, the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Bill 1987, the Horticultural Levy Collection Bill 1987, and the Horticultural Policy Council Bill 1987, and I also present the annual report of the Committee for 1986-87.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Committee I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 15 dated 18 November 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave, Mr Deputy President, to make a statement relating to the annual report.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report of the Standing Committee again highlights the important function the Senate serves as a House of review, particularly of legislation presented to the Parliament for its consideration. The continuing work of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has greatly reinforced and focused this role. The report contains a general overview and comment on the Committee's work during the year, and deals in particular with a number of matters which have been of particular concern to the Committee. Foremost among these concerns is the question of legislation by Press release, where a media announcement of intended legislation is made and the legislation, subsequently passed, is made retrospective to the date of the announcement. The Committee has continually drawn the attention of the Senate to such legislation by Press release. The Committee has indicated in the past that it recognises the special conventions associated with retrospective legislation making changes to the taxation laws where these changes are announced to the Parliament in the Budget or in similar statements and the necessary legislation is retrospective to the date of that announcement, the reason for such retrospectivity being that taxpayers might otherwise take advantage of the foreknowledge provided by the announcement. The Committee has also indicated that there may be a case for retrospective legislation where an announcement is made that a particular avenue for tax minimisation which has been abused is to be closed off and the subsequent legislation is backdated to the day of that announcement. Even in such circumstances the retrospectivity involved should, in the Committee's view, be kept to the minimum necessary to prepare the relevant legislation. The Committee would, as a matter of course, draw the retrospectivity to the attention of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The attempt to introduce the practice of legislation by Press release in areas other than taxation, such as the area of broadcasting ownership and control legislation, has also been noted by the Committee. The Committee has pointed out that, in its view, to extend this method of changing the law appears to have problems. The Committee has noted that its objection is not to the announcement of governmental decisions to alter the law being made at the earliest opportunity, but to the retrospective application of legislation to the date of such announcements.

The practice of legislation by Press release raises two major concerns in the Committee's view. The first is that by indicating that the legislation implementing the changes in the ownership rules would, when introduced, be retrospective, the Minister's announcement creates uncertainty as to the state of the law during the period between the date of the announcement and the passage of the necessary legislation by the Parliament. Secondly, by the time it comes to consider the Bill the Parliament is placed in the invidious position of either agreeing to the legislation prepared by the Government without major amendment or upsetting the many transactions which have taken place in the industry during the intervening period in reliance on the Minister's announcement.

During the year the Committee has continued to consolidate its representation, both in and outside Parliament, as an important and helpful adjunct to the legislative process. There continues to be prompt and considered responses to the Committee's comments by Ministers and consistent reference to the Committee's Alert Digests and reports during debate on Bills on which it has commented. It is particularly worth noting that a number of amendments, based on the Committee's comments, were successfully moved during the year.

In the long term, as the Committee has noted in the annual report, it appears that the measure of the Committee's effectiveness will not be so much an increased awareness on the part of senators of the sorts of concerns the Committee raises as an increased awareness of those concerns among the officers of executive departments responsible for the formulation of legislation. There is already substantial evidence of the internalisation of certain of the Committee's concerns in the process of legislative development and the Committee has been prepared to facilitate this process by taking a pragmatic approach in relation to matters such as the removal of the privilege against self-incrimination and the reversal of the onus of proof.

In conclusion, I believe a strong note of thanks is due by the Committee and the Senate to the former chairpersons of the Committee, Senator Michael Tate and Senator Rosemary Crowley, whom I succeed as Committee Chairman. The thanks of the members of the Committee must also go to Giles Short, who, as Secretary to the Committee during the last Parliament, made such a conscientious contribution to the Committee's work. I remark on the efforts and work put into this Committee by Senator Tate, Senator Crowley and Mr Short in the past. I commend the reading of the annual report to all honourable senators.
