TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was addressing my remarks to this Government's 1987-88 Budget. I outlined the complete incompetence not only of the Hawke Government but also of the Whitlam Government and, further back, the Scullin Government. I concluded that history will always show Labor governments as incompetent economic managers. Further to that, I was speaking about the great primary industries, the five great exporting contributors to Australia. In particular, I pointed out that the pastoral and agricultural industries have received a reduction of $56m in government outlays in this Budget. I began to outline-this is where I pick up my address-that since the Budget this Government has steamrolled on to increase the costs of all those industries. For example, the wheat industry brings in some $1.7 billion of export revenue yearly. At a time when our balance of payments is at its usual $1 billion a month deficit, the Government decided to increase costs to the industry by way of lifting export insurance premiums. I refer to the article by the Australian Wheat Board Chairman which condemns this decision by the Government. The Chairman said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government have failed to acknowledge the extremely competitive credit arrangements offered by governments of competing wheat exporting nations and wheat growers will no doubt find it difficult to understand why after two years of extremely depressed market conditions and financial returns the Government have imposed these costs.

I recall asking the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) a question on this very matter on 5 November. I asked him what actions the Government was intending to take. At that time he said that whatever decision the Government made would be in total agreement with the Australian Wheat Board. That is absolute rubbish. As I have just said, the Chairman of the Wheat Board condemned that decision by the Government and I would like Senator Button to explain away the answer he gave to me in this House. Or is he just going to join the already long list of Ministers who cannot shoot straight when it comes to economic and financial matters?

The beef industry contributes $2.2 billion of export revenue yearly. Since handing down the Budget, the Government has set about increasing this industry's costs also. It has increased the maximum slaughter levy to some $18 per head and in doing so has broken a commitment to meet 50 per cent of all export inspection charges. Because of the breaking of this commitment, the industry now has to take the full brunt of the inspection charges brought on by the chemical residue incident, which is estimated at around $35m.

The gold industry contributes about $2.5 billion a year-of course, this is ever increasing-to our export revenue. In the last few days the member for Burke in Victoria, Mr O'Keefe, has called for a return of the gold tax. Surely that must send shivers up the spine of the gold industry. The Government made a commitment prior to the election not to have a gold tax and not to consider one. Now one of the leading members on the Government's rural committee is calling for a return of this tax. The gold industry has every right to believe now that the Government has not put aside the idea of a gold tax.

Of course, the reasons given by Mr O'Keefe for the reintroduction of the tax are nothing short of envy and spite towards this industry. I refer to an article in which Mr O'Keefe publicly comes out and calls for a return to the gold tax. Mr O'Keefe said that he would be approaching the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as a member of the rural task force as early as possible to call for the return of the gold tax.

Burke, I believe, is the most gerrymandered seat in Victoria. The greater proportion of that seat is rural-based yet it has been cleverly or cunningly cut into the suburbs of outer Melbourne. Although the suburb of Broadmeadows makes up more than 40 per cent of the population of that seat, it is a very small part of it in terms of size and that is how Mr O'Keefe wins in elections. If he were to make those comments about a return of a gold tax in a seat which contains towns such as Ballarat and Bendigo-we all know the great traditions that those two townships have in gold mining-without the security of this gerrymander, he would be thrown out on his neck. I only hope that Senator Ray, in his considerations of redrawing the boundaries before the next election, takes this into consideration. I believe that the seat of Burke will be redistributed and I hope that this member is redistributed out of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a lot to learn, sonny boy. The boundaries are drawn by an independent commission. We have no hand in drawing the boundaries; you should know that. It is a purely independent commission.

—I will pick up that interjection to say that Senator Ray has no hand in drawing up the boundaries. All this simply goes to show that the industries that we so badly rely on at the moment are not being supported by this Government in any way whatsoever. Yet the problem does not stop there. This Government has allowed the coal industry-a primary export industry which contributes over $5 billion to our exports-to be driven into the ground by the union movement. Thankfully, in the last few days this industry has received a package of $40m to bail it out to subsidise-I believe the term `subsidise' is correct-the freight charges. This cynical move, of course, is totally based on the New South Wales election. That seems to be one of the main motivations of this Government whenever it makes economic decisions. Those decisions are all political; they are an attempt to save Federal or State seats. New South Wales is the finest example of this.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I am clearly making is that our five major export industries are not getting the attention of this Government. This Government has had a false belief that the so-called sunrise industries could quickly replace our farm industries. It is time that this Government realised the futility of assisting the high technology industries, trying to pick winners amongst these industries and giving them exclusive support at the cost of the rural industry in the hope that the winners will one day replace rural exports as the basis of this nation's foreign earnings. This Government thought it was witnessing the death throes of our farmer produce as an export strength. How wrong it was. In this false belief it has applied excessive assistance to the so-called sunrise industries while at the same time indicating that the rural industries have to go it alone, that they will be getting less assistance. I am proud to say that the agricultural sector has adjusted and has maintained its productivity, which is twice the level for the industry generally.

In these sombre times of stock market crashes and Australian dollar freefalls, it is worthy to reflect on the contributions that primary industry makes to our living standards. It is a far more substantial and enduring contribution than that provided by the current set of high-fliers and paper shufflers in the stock market that we have had to endure over the last 4 1/2 years. The farmers of Australia are not paper shufflers; they are true workers, just like the blue collar workers. They face the cruel elements of the Australian environment-droughts, floods, bushfires and Labor governments. Farmers are very much small business people, too, who have to adapt to changing world markets, changing technology and changing consumer demands.

The men and women of rural Australia in so many ways have been, and still are, the backbone of this country's economic welfare. As this nation faces its greatest economic challenge-and that cannot be denied-it is time once again to turn our eyes to rural Australia. The National Party of Australia, unlike the Australian Labor Party, which has drifted far and wide from its traditional base and is now trying to crawl back to its traditional base, can stand up and be counted as having always stood by its traditional followers. It has never drifted far and wide, as the Labor Party has. The Labor Party has clearly admitted that it has drifted, and it is now trying to crawl back to those suburbs. Well, it is not on.

The National Party's great strength has always rested with its commitment to Australia's productive industries, consistently maintaining its conservative values, and our conviction that the rural people of Australia deserve a party that owes its loyalty to them. These have been our strengths. We should not flinch from the message that we are a conservative party with a firm belief in traditional Australia and rural Australia.

Because of this established history, I would like to direct my remarks, as a National Party senator from Victoria, to the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association. I believe that because of our rural tradition and history, such federations should get off the barbed wire fence and give greater recognition to a rural based party such as the National Party. The Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association is well organised and has a very large membership. But the reality is that the Labor Government gives no priority to rural Victoria; rather, it gives a great deal more priority to its constituents in the city. The Victorian branch of the National Party is a soundly based rural party which holds all of its parliamentary seats in rural Victoria. The Association, by channelling its energies and resources towards the Victorian National Party, will give a stronger and more distinct voice to its concerns.

The trade union movement clearly has the loyalty of the Labor Party. It clearly funds the Party and influences Party policy. It owes its loyalty to the Labor Party, and the Labor Party owes loyalty to it. It has never prevented a conservative government from having the good sense to recognise the trade union movement's value and its contribution to the overall policy debate. I believe the reverse is true: the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association should place itself squarely behind the rural policies of the Victorian National Party and, indeed, the coalition's policies.

There is no doubt that the single issue that has dominated the term of this Government is the economic welfare of Australia. People are continually being blinded by the very highfalutin economic language and the snowballing tactics of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Australians have often witnessed a blinding competition between the economists and Government Ministers over not only the real state of the economy but also the use of the best economic terms that have not yet been invented. So it is right to say that some of the debate has been lost on the people because of an inability to explain the facts clearly.

If I can get one single message through the mass of economic language that is used in this place to highlight one single issue in this debate, to sum up the real problem as directly and as simply as possible, it is the level of this country's overseas debt. This is the crux of the economic debate. It influences our economic indicators, such as interest rates and our inflation rate. Those rates directly influence the household of every Australian. When Labor came to government in 1983, Australia's gross foreign debt was $35 billion. Now, in 1987, it stands at greater than $100 billion and is increasing at the rate of $1 billion per month. The point is that it took 200 years for Australia to achieve a debt of only $35 billion and just 4 1/2 years to achieve a debt of greater than $100 billion. As we prepare to enter our bicentennial year, this is a very pitiful legacy that the Hawke Government will leave for the generations that follow.

There are several ways of placing the size of the Australian debt into some relative perspective. Any debt should be related to the size of the economy. One measure of this is the net debt to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio. Another is to look at the cost to our external accounts of servicing that debt-for example, the ratio of net interest payments to export earnings. However one looks at it, these are how the figures stack up: Australia's gross foreign debt stood at almost 42 per cent of GDP at the end of June 1987. The interest payments on this debt are equivalent to 21 per cent of Australia's export earnings, compared with the 1982 figure of 8 per cent. With regard to the balance of payments, we are continuing to run deficits on the balance of goods and services, which means that we are borrowing just to pay interest on our foreign debt. Interest upon interest-that is the situation to which this Government has led us.

It is important to understand that these ratios are not just academic exercises. They form an important part of an analysis undertaken by international banks and investors in assessing whether to invest funds in Australia. It is clear that Australia has well and truly reached the point where it is now subject to an intensive, critical and even cruel assessment by the world financial markets. It will not be too long before world bankers will insist that Australia must pay the interest bill on its debt without resorting to further borrowings.

In conclusion, no one in Australia should be led to believe anything but that this country is on the decline, is in crisis and is being poorly managed. I do not believe anyone in Australia should be led to believe anything but that in 1988 we will see more waves and falls in the share market and the Australian dollar. As each month goes by, Australia is running a deficit account. Today's papers show how great that deficit will be. If the debate is about how great the deficit will be, the king has no clothes; the king is naked.

As Australia enters its bicentennial year I have great hope that the traditions and spirits passed on through the generations will enable those who serve this Parliament to have some courage and will to take the right steps to save this nation. Above all, what is called for, in regard to this courage and will to take the right steps, is leadership, and that is exactly what we are lacking. We are looking for leadership that will replace political opportunism with integrity; leadership that will replace political careerism with courage and will; and, above all, leadership that will inspire the young and quicken their heartfelt dreams. Sadly, we do not have that leadership today in government. I commend the coalition's second reading amendment in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget to which the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88 and cognate Bills relate is in my opinion, and I am sure in the opinion of most senators on this side of the House as well as most Australians, an absolute sham. We are told that it is a balanced Budget. However, in reality it is some $2.6 billion in the red. We are told that it will lead us up the path to economic recovery. However, for the last two months the balance of payments has been $1.38 billion and $1.11 billion in the red. That means that we have more money going out of our country than is coming into it. We all know the consequences for any household that lives in that manner and does nothing about it. We are told that the Government's policies are working. However, our annual inflation rate is announced to be some 9.3 per cent. By any economic account Australia is not faring well. Our prospects for recovery are not much brighter. Our balance of trade position is dreadful. The fact that a balance of payments deficit of $1,180m is considered good is an indication of how dangerous a road this Government is taking.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has been talking about this for some three years. It has been talking about options for recovery. We have stressed time and time again how important an increase in exports is. We have seen that in the short term manufacturing will not provide that export income. It is doubtful that, even in the long term, manufacturing is the answer. However, we will still subsidise the motor vehicle industry to the extent of some $500m over the next five years while our rural sector will receive only some $35m in assistance. It is generally agreed that we must improve our export performance, and certainly our rural commodities offer the only real choice. Senator McGauran alluded to this matter when he spoke just before me.

When we talk to our exporters of meat, fruit and vegetables we find that they are trying to be competitive, they are trying to export but they cannot get freight flights out of Australia. There is no point finding markets for our commodities if we cannot guarantee a reliable delivery. The problem is definitely well and truly recognised by the airlines. The latest annual report for Qantas Airways Ltd states:
Qantas currently provides 38 per cent of air freight capacity into Australia and 41 per cent out of Australia. In the last six years air cargo capacity has doubled.
Primary produce made up 70 per cent of the Qantas uplift of goods from Australia in 1986-87 with as much as 95 per cent of Perth's uplift falling into this category.

Exporters from Australia benefit from some of the cheapest freight rates in the world. . . . Whilst these very low outbound rates have clear short-term benefits they have brought longer-term problems. The principal problem is the lack of capacity, particularly in the peak season, because rates are so low. The rates are insufficient for airlines to provide capacity. Increases in the rates are essential for the introduction of a new capacity.

I accept what Qantas is saying. Air freight rates out of Australia have been very favourable to the exporter, although because of a 38 per cent increase in Australia's horticultural exports last financial year there has been increased competition for freight space and rates have risen. Air freighted fruit and vegetable exports have increased from about one per cent to 13 per cent of total agricultural exports over the past decade. Austrade estimates a potential increase in horticultural exports next year of some 25 per cent, but only if the airline operators earn adequate returns.

Qantas is not renowned for loyalty to the Australian horticultural industry. It has a reputation for making hard-nosed business decisions which sometimes have left Australian produce rotting on the tarmac. Obviously some accommodation must be reached over freight rates to overcome this problem so that we can help our balance of trade. However the Government, which is the body we are talking about in this place, must also act responsibly. Airlines have applied for routes; they have been knocked back. There has been protection of Qantas routes. As Qantas itself says, it carries a large share of the inbound and outbound freight. Something has to be done about that. If the Government is going to continue that line, it is important that Qantas provide the service. It has already been announced that air freight capacity to the Middle East and Europe could be reduced next year as a result of Qantas's 747-400 series Jumbos flying direct to London with only one stop. These one-stop flights could cut services through the Middle East and Europe; however, Qantas has not indicated how it intends to restructure. Will the Middle East carriers be allowed access now? That is the question I ask the Government. The Government's charter policy review has the capacity to free up space by making charter more attractive. The industry is expecting a more relaxed policy. If this Government is serious about helping our exports it will provide that extra capacity.

The complete botch up of the air freight of perishable exports is yet another example to which my colleague Senator Stone referred in his speech yesterday. The lack of commitment by this Government to rural exports is part of the continuing pattern of failure of this Government to look at our balance of trade problem. The Government's head in the sand policy might have worked in the short term, but we have now had four years of the Hawke-Keating Labor Government and decisions must be made. This Government simply is not making those decisions which are necessary.

The Government's handling of the pesticides scare is yet another example of this. When all else fails and the Government cannot think of anyone else to blame it pushes the blame and the cost on to the rural sector. The Government has ignored the fact that the problem is not the fault of the beef producers, that is not a problem simply for the rural sector. If blame must be apportioned, State and Federal governments must take the lion's share. It is the State and Federal governments that provide the permits and the authorisation for chemicals to be available for sale. Certainly farmers have used those chemicals over the years but they have done so in good faith. The farmers also provided beef for export in good faith; they did not willingly send contaminated meat to the market. They did not knowingly allow their cattle to feed on contaminated pastures and grain. Of even more relevance than blame, however, is the responsibility for the problem in the aftermath of its discovery. It really does not matter who caused the problem or how it arose. The fact remains that the problem is here. The problem is ours and we all will suffer if Australia loses its export industries.

During this debate I wish to direct some remarks to the present quite alarmingly depleted staffing situation in the Bureau of Rural Science (BRS). No doubt public servants are quite used to and have adjusted to successive governments splitting departments, giving them new names and transferring functions. One such area is the Bureau of Rural Science, which was established in 1986. I quote from the preface of the Bureau's Budget estimates, which states that one of the Bureau's objectives is:
To assist the development of efficient primary industries in Australia, able to compete in domestic and international markets.

The Bureau addresses the cost-price squeeze being experienced by the rural sector which without substantial Government support relies upon increasing productivity through innovation, the conservation and management of agricultural, pastoral, forestry and fisheries resources. It is also responsible for the efficient and effective management of certain operational activities which provide for the protection and improvement of animal health, production and welfare. One of its other functions is the co-ordination of the clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. It will do all of those things this year with a budget of some $34m. That is what the Budget estimates tell us. The coming year will be a most vital one for the Bureau, given the immediate problems of chemical residue testing and the quarantining of properties, the supervision of live sheep exports to various countries and the rundown to completion date for the tuberculosis and brucellosis eradication campaign. Yet, in the last year, there has been an enormous number of staff resignations from the Bureau, which was known as the Bureau of Animal Health and is now amalgamated into the BRS. The most senior and experienced veterinary officers appear to have left or to be leaving. Other positions have been advertised and there has been some difficulty in finding suitable replacements or, indeed, any replacement for some positions.

The Bureau is accumulating economic and administrative expertise, but it is not doing the same with its veterinary trained staff, and I ask the Government another question: Why is this happening? I know that people within the Bureau are concerned and those who have left are concerned. I am concerned that this situation is occurring at a most critical time, when the Federal Government needs qualified veterinary opinion on tap. I have no idea whether the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, is aware of the situation, or, if he is, what he is doing about it. Is it a mere coincidence that so many officers have left? I doubt it. I intend to put questions to the Minister and I hope that the answers that I get will not be just a fob-off. That is why I have raised this subject now, because this Parliament must be kept informed, and the people who serve it must have the ability to provide that information.

As I have said, the question of chemical pesticide residues is a vital one for Australia and its export industries. The Government mouths platitudes and talks about the importance of export markets and the need to reduce expenditure, but in reality, it slugs the producer for the cost of increased testing while continuing to dole our money for women's surfboards and dubious grants to minority groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you like women?
—I love them. I think that they are a necessary part of our environment and that they are equal to all males in the community. That was an unnecessary remark for a Minister to make.

SPEECH.PARA: People out in the real world are fed up with the rhetoric that comes out of this place. They get fed up listening, day after day, to the Government blaming everyone but itself. This Government has blamed overseas forces, the weather and previous coalition governments for Australia's economic ills-it blames everyone except itself, and that is where the blame lies. It is this Government that has allowed export markets to be lost because of trade union militancy, that has forced companies into submitting to union pressure because business knows that it will not get Government support if it takes on the unions. It is this Government that has abrogated its responsibilities. It has fiddled around with the economy to such an extent that we are relieved when the balance of payments comes in at under $2 billion, and when inflation is only two or three times higher than that of our trading partners. We are all expected to breathe a sigh of relief when our stock market falls by only 44 per cent, even though stock markets in the rest of the world fall by less than that. Before I finish, I wish to make a few comments directly related to the running of the Estimates committees and some specific responses from departments. This was mentioned earlier by Senators Newman, Alston and Michael Baume. I think that what I say will support what they have said. I find it is practically impossible for senators properly to analyse the explanatory memoranda for the Estimates committees when those documents are received only shortly before the committees are due to sit. There has been a general failure on the part of departments to answer questions promptly. That is one of the points that were made clearly by Senator Michael Baume. It is not good enough to get replies back only just before the appropriation debate.

I hope that the departmental officers who have had to attend these hearings for hours, and at times days on end, do not feel that any answer is good enough just so long as they give a response. I have a couple of specific issues that I wish to raise. I probably mention soil conservation too much in this place, but I will continue to do so until the Government does something about it. I have continually attempted to raise the profile of the soil conservation issue, which does not seem to enjoy the popularity of other environmental issues, such as rainforests, with this current Government. Following a recent debate in this chamber on soil conservation, Chris Watson from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Division of Soils sent me details of a scheme currently operating in the United States. It is not a matter of handouts or subsidies but of protecting our resources. But of course what we get from this Government is nothing that it cannot perceive a vote in. So, we will continue to see attention to rainforests; indeed, as I understand it, Senator Richardson will be back up in the Daintree yet again tomorrow. But we will still see nothing for soil conservation. I will start to believe this Government's sincerity when it puts its money and its Minister where its mouth is. The Government and the Minister talk big about soil conservation but it is not the salt ravaged areas of the Murray to which the Minister is going tomorrow, and on which a paper has already been presented this afternoon. He is going to the rainforests yet again, for the third or fourth time in almost as many weeks. When will the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Government do something about this?

There were also questions about the rural adjustment scheme in the Estimates committee hearings. It was stated that there was a $5m shortfall in expenditure from the amount appropriated in 1986-87. The reason offered for this shortfall was that funds had been available but the circumstances of 1986-87 were such that these funds were not picked up. It seems extraordinary to me that, given the rural crisis in various sectors of the industry, such sorely needed funds were not picked up. It seems to me that there is a lack of communication between the Department and the industry, and this needs looking into. So I ask the Government: Why did this happen?

In the Estimates committee there was considerable comment regarding bias in the media, particularly in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). Through the Estimates Committee I was given access to the complaints sheets from the ABC switchboards. The documents themselves make very interesting reading. However, I will quote one assertion from the senior publicity officer for the ABC in Tasmania, which sums up the position regarding perceived bias on the part of the ABC. He said:
I estimate that more than 90% of callers accused ABC-TV of bias in favour of the ALP.

I think the evidence speaks for itself. As I have already said, this Government has presided over the highest taxing and highest spending we have ever seen. Economists have said it must stop; the man in the street knows it should; but the Government continues to believe it knows better than all the best economic advice. I support the foreshadowed amendment to be moved by Senator Stone for the Opposition. I will repeat the second part of the amendment, which states:

this failure by the Government to face up to its responsibilities has heightened Australia's vulnerability and exposure to changes in world economic conditions and has resulted in our being more adversely affected by the recent and continuing crisis on world financial markets . . .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats must draw the attention of the Senate to a glaring inadequacy of the Government's Budget in relation to the sum allotted to veterans' affairs. The Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) fail to anticipate recommendations of Mr Bob Hogg which are now before the Cabinet; indeed, they are very significant recommendations. As honourable senators will be aware, Mr Hogg, at the commissioning of the Cabinet, has reached conclusions which, if acted upon, must add substantially to expenditure. Moreover, other recommendations have implications for expenditure beyond veterans' affairs in the areas of public investigation, scientific investigation and public health. Mr Hogg also reports some serious inadequacies in the way in which public moneys have already been expended.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats are, as are all senators, concerned that Australians get value for money spent. That is precisely what this debate is all about. We are gravely concerned, therefore, that the recent expenditure of public moneys on the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam was not money well spent. Indeed, the very opposite was the case. More and larger sums must now be expended because of the tragically grave inadequacies of the Commission-sums which are not anticipated in these appropriation Bills.

Honourable senators will recall that on 23 September I moved an urgency motion whereby the Senate called upon the Government to acknowledge and rectify the inadequacies of the Evatt Royal Commission into the effects of agent orange on Vietnam veterans. Honourable senators will recall also that the motion was rejected by the Senate. That urgency motion was not moved lightly; it was moved for important reasons. Let me cite only three of them. First of all, the Vietnam veterans had asked me to do so because they had serious reservations about the Commission's methods and findings. Secondly, the Government also had sufficient concern about these matters to appoint a special Cabinet consultant, Mr Bob Hogg, who, as honourable senators will be aware, is a former member of Mr Hawke's staff. He was appointed specifically to investigate and report to Cabinet on the adequacy of the Commission. The third reason that urgency motion was moved by me was that the scientific community at large had very serious reservations and had expressed those reservations about the Commission's methods and findings.

We believed that these were sufficient reasons to warrant the Senate's urgent attention. Mr Hogg has now reported and Cabinet will soon consider his confidential report. In the meantime, however, the Press has published substantial leaks from that report. I cite the Australian of 18 November, pages 1 and 2, and the Sydney Morning Herald, at page 8, which contain comprehensive statements from that confidential document, a document which has not yet been considered by Cabinet. Furthermore, I am in a position to inform the Senate of the most important aspects of the Hogg report, such as the nature of the leaks from this Cabinet. In fact, the recommendations of the Hogg report raise matters of profound public importance, some of which my colleagues and I will, in the public interest, explore in depth in the committee stage of the appropriations debate.

Before turning to the details of the Hogg report, I will remind the Senate of the most salient points of my urgency motion and some of the interesting responses from both sides of this chamber. Most of all, I claim that my urging of the Senate's concern has subsequently been vindicated by Mr Hogg's findings. They reveal not only matters of grave public importance but the gross waste of public moneys associated with the Evatt Royal Commission-a sum of $3.8m. The issue is a very serious one indeed. It is not only an issue of justice to veterans, but it raises vital questions regarding the quality of public investigation and it raises grave doubts about the protection of public health.

I am deeply conscious of the seriousness of what I am about to do. I will be quoting from a confidential public document which has already been leaked to the Press and has already been published in the Press this week. I have what I believe is an accurate transcript of parts of the Hogg report; that is, I believe I have in front of me the contents of a confidential Cabinet document that has not yet been considered by Cabinet, yet which has already been leaked to the Press and disclosed. I believe the transcript which I have to be an accurate one in substance, if not in precise wording. Only the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) will be able to confirm or deny the substantial validity or otherwise of what I tender here as fact. I acknowledge the presence in the chamber of Senator Reynolds, who is acting on behalf of the Minister. I call upon the Minister to affirm or deny its essential accuracy as soon as possible. I believe that that is a just request of the Minister. I will share its contents with the Senate because I sincerely believe that it is in the public interest to do so and I cannot be assured that this document will ever see the light of day-that is, any more than it has already, having been published in our Press three or four days ago.

I begin by making the observation that the very appointment of Mr Hogg as a special consultant to Cabinet to investigate the adequacy of a Royal Commission that had spent $3.8m of the Australian people's money is, in itself, an extraordinary thing. Clearly Senator Gietzelt, the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, must have had grave reservations about the adequacy of the Commission's work. He is to be commended for his appointing of Mr Hogg. Cabinet itself must have had serious misgivings for it to have taken this extraordinary step. So we are confronted with a situation where the Cabinet and the presiding Minister of the day had the gravest of misgivings about the findings and report of the Royal Commission that had cost $3.8m and taken two years to deliver.

In my speech to the Senate on 23 September, I presented the deep misgivings of some of the most respected scientists in the country and some of international repute. These misgivings related to the findings and methods of the Evatt Royal Commission. The Vietnam Veterans' Association believed that Mr Hogg's brief was restricting and that the restrictions had been spelled out in writing. This was denied by the previous Minister and the present Minister. It seems that the veterans' concern was justified. I believe that page 12 of the Hogg report quotes from a letter from the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to Senator Gietzelt. I believe that I am quoting the substance, if not the precise words, of that letter. This is my assumed quote:
The submission would essentially-
and the Prime Minister is referring to the submission required from the appointed consultants-
draw together but not seek to reopen issues or re-examine the work that has already been done in your Department, and the Department of Defence, as well as more recent work of the Attorney-General.
I see this as being the full extent of the task which the consultant is to be asked to undertake.
I would be particularly concerned to ensure that the consultancy was not drawn into the legal intricacies surrounding the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, in the light of that quotation, are you suggesting that subsequently Ministers have misled the Parliament in their description of the task given to Mr Hogg?

—I would prefer it if that question were asked later in my presentation. I will address myself to the honourable senator's concern in what I have to say later. I sense at least confusion. Both Ministers have denied the intention to whitewash. Both Ministers have denied intended constraint upon Mr Hogg. Their interpretation of these instructions differs greatly, certainly from my interpretation, from my colleagues' interpretations, from the interpretation of the Vietnam veterans and, I respectfully acknowledge, from Senator Stone's interpretation of the passage that I have just read to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats and the Vietnam veterans believe that Mr Hogg is to be congratulated. He has been fair, honest and courageous. I say `courageous' because he has stepped outside the constraints imposed upon him. He has delivered an honest statement to the Cabinet, despite the fact that these restraining terms of reference suggest that the Government did not want to hear any conclusion which disclosed the inadequacies and waste of the Evatt Royal Commission.

As commendable as Mr Hogg's work is, it has its limitations. He attempted to satisfy the demands of his constraining formal brief. One would suspect-I believe that Senator Stone joins me in this suspicion-that he was conforming with the demands of an even more constraining informal briefing. On the one hand he is attempting to fulfil those constraints and, on the other hand, he is attempting to fulfil the requirements of his own conscience in this matter. In doing so, unfortunately, I believe that he has fallen into contradictions and I will cite some of the contradictions inherent in the document. He advises Cabinet-and this is advice that Cabinet has not yet seen but which has been published in our national Press-to accept Evatt's conclusions, yet he provides damning condemnation of the Commission's methods and makes significant recommendations about the structuring of future royal commissions with a scientific orientation. So, on the one hand, he advises Cabinet to accept the conclusions and, on the other hand, he condemns the methods and findings.

The second observed contradiction is that he advises Cabinet to accept Evatt's conclusion that agent orange is innocent, yet he recommends that five further studies be undertaken and elaborates reasons why such a conclusion is unacceptable and why such further studies are necessary. I cite a third contradiction in what I refer to as a courageous and very beneficial report. Mr Hogg denies that the Commission is guilty of plagiarism and bias, yet he comprehensively cites examples of non-attributed material. Honourable senators will recall that, in my address to the Senate on 23 September, I said that international commentators have cited 360 pages of submissions to that Commission which were not attributed. So want it or not, Mr Hogg gave the Cabinet a damning condemnation of the Evatt Royal Commission.
I wish now to quote what I believe to be the substance of page 17 of the Hogg judgment of the Evatt Royal Commission report. I believe that Mr Hogg says on page 17:
Rather, its lack of credibility-
and he is referring to the report of the Evatt Royal Commission-
is the result of the manner of the conduct of the inquiry and the form of the reporting of its work.
The Commission defeated itself and in doing so let down the government, the veterans and the general community.
It has not enhanced the debate on the effect of chemicals used in Vietnam or generally in agriculture.
It has kept the issues alive in a way which will not be productive if pursued in the way the VVAA prefers.
I believe that I have quoted Mr Hogg's summary of the credibility of the Evatt Royal Commission report.

Bob Hogg has also been prepared to address the grave accusation of plagiarism levelled at the report of the Commission. Here Mr Hogg is caught in the dilemma imposed upon him by his constraining brief. On the one hand, in his conclusions, he rejects claims of bias and plagiarism but, on the other hand, I believe that on page 19 of his report he acknowledges the realities-again I believe that I am quoting from page 19 of Mr Hogg's confidential report to Cabinet-when he says in part:

The Commission recognised the sensitivity of veterans and others in many ways but then confirmed suspicions and fears by using large slabs of the writings of others such as Monsanto without adequate attribution.

To have used Monsanto's submission, in part or in full, in the sense of incorporating parts and agreeing with them was always a difficult approach to take, given the suspicions of this material, even if the inclusions were clearly and repeatedly attributed to the source.
To use their material without obvious attribution was, to put it kindly, sheer folly.
It is not possible to see how such an approach would breed confidence in the final conclusion and recommendations.
Rather than an expression of bias, its efforts were plainly clumsy.
I am confident the Commission on reaching its conclusions on the substantive questions tried to set about reassuring veterans.
Its execution of its intent demonstrably failed-its approach proved to be highly insensitive.
It departed from the process of clinically analysing and reporting and tried instead to put `ghosts' at rest.
It succeeded in doing the opposite.

Mr Hogg has been courageous enough to express reservations about the Commission's objectivity. He makes the following point about how the Commission handled evidence cited in arguing the innocence of agent orange. Once again I believe that I am quoting-this time from page 32-where he says:

But for the Commission to come to the point of putting on trial and making clear judgment on the honesty, integrity and accuracy of the environmental movement worldwide over the past 30 years, and to get to the point of giving a definitive analysis of the cultural and psychological mood of the veterans and general community at the time:
without calling evidence
without seeking learned opinion

without cross-examining those accused and to do it by lifting from the uncontested writings of a book presumably read by someone on the Commission simply demeans its own actual work and diminishes itself to the point of indefensibility.

I believe that to be a written statement from Mr Hogg to the Cabinet, as yet unreviewed by the Cabinet. Clearly it is imperative that the document in toto be made public in the near future. I call upon the Minister for an assurance that that will be the case. To deny Parliament, the Vietnam veterans and the public this document would be dishonest and irresponsible and it would confirm the public's worst suspicions about a cover-up, a cover-up which cost the Government $3.8m.

Members of the Australian Democrats congratulate Mr Hogg. At least in recent months it seems that the Cabinet and the Australian people, have, in our view-admittedly based on limited information-received good value for money, even though I do not know how much money. As a result of Mr Hogg's honest and courageous reporting, several vital public issues have been placed on the political agenda. The first of those issues is justice to veterans exposed to toxic chemicals in Vietnam and justice to their families. The second is the need to protect vigilantly the standards of public inquiry in this nation. The third is the need to evaluate, monitor and control in all contexts the use of chemicals in our society, especially the potently toxic herbicides, weedicides and insecticides. The fourth is the need for governments, especially the executive arm of governments, to be as open as possible in matters relating to justice and public health, indeed, all matters.

The recommendations of the Hogg report are especially fair and honest in relation to veterans' entitlements. Mr Hogg recommends the maintenance and extension of counselling services; he recommends ongoing studies into mortality and morbidity; he recommends a review and updating of data in relation to veterans' health; he recommends agricultural studies of 2,4-D and 2,4,5-T; he recommends birth defect studies of women exposed to 2,4-D and 2,4,5-T and the Dapstone study. Mr Hogg mentioned a cost of $30m over 15 years for ongoing studies alone. Such costs are not acknowledged in these appropriations. Of course, if one accepts the central role of adequate and comprehensive counselling in the health care of Vietnam veterans, then the projected expenditures of the Budget are extremely inadequate. Mr Hogg, the Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia and the Australian Democrats all argue that to be the case-the projected expenditures in this Budget are extremely inadequate.

In short, the appropriated sums in relation to veterans will, if the Government accepts Mr Hogg's recommendations, be very inadequate. The Australian Democrats draw the Senate's attention to this. Above all, however, we cite the broader relevance of this brief but significant document of Mr Bob Hogg. In drawing the Senate's attention to these inadequate appropriations, I call upon the Minister and the Government to do the following: firstly, advise us when and to whom the Hogg report will be released; secondly, clarify the Government's attitudes towards the counselling services considered so vital by the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia and independent evaluators-five of them in the past two years; thirdly, clarify the Government's attitude concerning important evidence ignored by the Evatt Royal Commission and subsequent important evidence in relation to agent orange. The Australian Democrats believe the Royal Commission was guilty of both things: it ignored existing evidence and, since then, there has been insignificant acknowledgment of subsequent evidence in relation to agent orange. Fourthly, the Australian Democrats require that the Minister advise the Senate of Cabinet's reaction to the Hogg report, and, fifthly, we seek advice as to how the Government intends to accommodate and rectify the acknowledged inadequacies of the Evatt Royal Commission, acknowledged not only in Mr Hogg's report but also over and again by commentators, indeed, international commentators, inside and outside of Parliament.

The Australian Democrats give notice of our intention at the committee stage of this debate to explore further four dimensions of the Evatt and Hogg reports, namely, questions relating to Prime Ministerial, ministerial and departmental attitudes towards and handling of these inquiries; matters relating to the adequacy of the veterans' services; questions of standards and value for money in public inquiry and major questions of public health flowing from the Evatt and Hogg reports and the inadequacies of their findings and recommendations. Of course, the Australian Democrats will also pursue these matters vigorously outside of these appropriations and outside of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to speak to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 I recall with amazement my reading of this morning's newspapers showing the Government's ecstasy that the trade deficit was a mere $1.18 billion and not as predicted as being somewhere between $1.3 billion and $1.8 billion. It is indeed remarkable that the Government can rejoice in an addition to Australia's growing debt. I am pleased to support Senator Stone's amendment that delineates the Government's shortcomings in the five opportunities it has had of bringing down Budgets. We have had five Budgets from the Hawke-Keating Government, four of which gave deficits and the last one of which purported to be a balanced Budget. Indeed, Mr Keating's opening words when he brought in that Budget, stating that the Budget for 1987-88 is in balance, go down with one of the other great phrases in the English language-a cheque is in the mail.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning's trade figures remind us that the total current account deficit for 1986-87 stood at $13.6 billion, or 5.1 per cent of gross domestic product. While the Government rejoices in the fact that the escalation of our debt is a bit less than was predicted it would be, in the words of Senator Stone's amendment, it takes away the ability to protect jobs, stop the prospective rise in unemployment, stem the continuing rise in numbers of Australians living in poverty or protect the position of families more generally. In other words, having lost the options available to the Government, Australia is now being buffeted by international forces and is left with very little choice.
Senator Walsh is often quoted in this place, and I shall quote what he said on 19 September 1987:

Certainly, if there was another commodity price slide, the International Monetary Fund will be knocking on the door again. A country which has a high level of foreign debt and a continuing large current account deficit is a country which has few options.

We have few options for the simple reason that the Government has destroyed the opportunities that it has had over the past five years. We are at risk. In a world where United States protection and isolationism is growing, where Japan and the European Economic Community (EEC) still keep protected markets in agriculture, Australia is indeed a country at risk. With 40 per cent of Australia's earnings coming from agriculture, 40 per cent from extractive industries and 20 per cent from the rest, the fact that the EEC and Japan still maintain highly protected markets is a problem for Australia. Senator Walsh was right when he said, `If the commodity prices slide again, trouble for us is at the door'.

The dominant issue for Australia from now until the year 2000 concerns just how Australia will integrate its trade, foreign affairs and defence policies. To my way of thinking, those policies must be integrated. Let us have a look at our own region. Let us have a look at the mess that we are in because we have not had policies that have paid heed one of the other. Australia's attitude to New Caledonia is that the Kanaks are a minority Melanesian group that should have independence. We move across to Fiji, where we have Colonel Rabuka's regime. Australia's view is that as it represents a minority, it is not entitled to be recognised.

In Vanuatu we see the Russian, Cuban and Libyan influence, yet if we had been perspicacious and paid attention to our own region perhaps we could have taken the initiatives which the Russians took when they came in with their fishing agreements. If we move across to Papua New Guinea, we see that it has already recognised the Rabuka Government. One sees the problems that arose in Papua New Guinea with our aid program. Papua New Guinea is the recipient of most of our aid and it has been, to our credit, untied aid. We have not tried to tell that government how it will spend the money that Australia has given it; we have given it in an untied form and said that it will be part of the budget of Papua New Guinea to spend as it will.

Several years ago, under the chairmanship of Sir John Crawford, an alteration to the sums given by way of aid was introduced. Subsequent to that and unilaterally, Mr Hayden decided to reduce part of that aid paid to Papua New Guinea. The disaster of the handling of that foreign affairs policy was that the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Mr Wingti, read about it in the newspaper. That is not the way one conducts foreign policy with one's nearest and closest neighbours.

The problems that we see on our own doorstep are largely the product of the fact that we have treated our region with benign neglect. Our relationships with Indonesia are at an all time low. We have postulated that Indonesia is a potential enemy. We have structured our defence policies so that now we are incapable of taking troops off the mainland to fight. They can fight nowhere but on our own homelands. The throw-away line that was given at the time of the coup in Fiji that perhaps Australia should send in troops was not only stupid for the reason that it was a silly thing to do but also an impossible thing to do. We have no way of taking troops to Fiji or, indeed, anywhere else in our region. Instead of regarding Indonesia as a most important trading partner, we look at Indonesia in terms of it being a future enemy. When I say that there is a need to integrate our foreign affairs, trade and defence policies, I can only hope that will force a change in attitude to our nearest neighbours.

The Pacific basin is no longer true to its name; it is no longer pacific, no longer tranquil. It is a place of change and challenge. The Russians now have their largest fleet in our ocean, in our region, at Cam Ranh Bay. We have not seen any Russian ships our side of the Equator; but that is what they have decided, as distinct from their not having the capability. Not so, however, with submarine activity. The extension of some of the fisheries agreements that have been negotiated does offer the Soviets the opportunity to increase activity in our region.

I do not raise these matters simply to try to raise up a spectre or to scaremonger, but simply to say that Australia must reassess its attitude to its own region. Australia has to know that if it is to maintain an influence in its region, the policies of benign neglect and the attitude that we could behave simply as a country that handed out pieces of charity to its near neighbours and expect them to be grateful for it, have come to an end. Therefore, to my way of thinking, the integration of trade, foreign affairs and defence is most important and high on the agenda for development from now until the turn of the century.

I shall revert to the Appropriation Bills themselves. Earlier I said that this Government has had the opportunity of bringing down five Budgets. In those five Budgets 17 new taxes have been introduced. That is an average of one new tax every three months since March 1983. Those taxes are enumerated as follows: capital gains tax; fringe benefits tax; 30 per cent lump sum superannuation tax; disallowance of entertainment expenditure; abolition of negative gearing, subsequently reinstated; increase in the corporate tax rate to 49 per cent; foreign tax credit system; abolition of concessional expenditure rebate; bureaucratic substantiation provisions; automatic excise of traditional excises; new sales taxes; wine tax; introduction of an increase in the Medicare levy and removal of the levy limit; large increases in excise on petrol; new excise on intermediate and new oil; resource rent tax; and an immigration clearance fee, which is the first tax in Australia's history ever to be placed on Australian citizens seeking to return to their own country as well as on every other passenger who might come as a tourist, a visitor or a potential migrant.

Concurrent with those new taxes and with the mismanagement of the economy, there are all time high rates in bankruptcies. They show the worst number of bankruptcies in this country's history. As was predicted in February, Australia has had the highest number of bankruptcies on record, with more than 8,000 businesses going to the wall under this Government's high interest rate, high tax and anti-incentive policies. Bankruptcy figures for the last quarter indicate that the situation could be even worse this year, with an estimated 9,900 bankruptcies in 1987-88. In other words, bankruptcies have increased 34.2 per cent in 1986-87 to a record high of 8,597.

The latest September quarter bankruptcy statistics are up 21 per cent over last year. The average annual level of bankruptcy and administration orders under this Government is 46 per cent higher than under the previous coalition government. The recent stock market crash can be expected only to exacerbate that situation. The Government does nothing but gloat that the trade deficit has not been quite as great as predicted. Yet again we are seeing the cargo cult economics that this Government likes to practise. Like Mr Micawber said, we just wait to see whether something turns up. At the time the Budget was brought down, Ross Gittins, who also likes a Dickensian turn of phrase, said:

I seem to be the only person in Australia with the temerity to be left unsatisfied by the perfection of the balanced Budget. I'm playing Oliver Sleezebag to Paul Keating's gruel-doling Mr Bumble, the beadle.

I would like to make one important point in a different area. It concerns the future of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Under the new management arrangements, the staff of the Public Accounts Committee is to be cut from 15 to five. The Public Accounts Committee is a statutory committee and a joint committee having responsibility both to the House of Representatives and to the Senate. It has been said in defence of the Government's proposal to more evenly distribute staff to the various committees that with the new House of Representatives committees work can be reallocated. The important differential to make is that those committees are just that: House of Representatives committees. They are not responsible to this half of the Parliament-the Senate; it has no voice. I do not think it is necessary to point out-although perhaps it is-that the Government controls the numbers in the House of Representatives; it does not control the numbers in the Senate. Therefore, the Senate's participation on that watch-dog Committee is most important.

I raise the matter because we are coming to the stage where these new staffing measures will be implemented. This is relevant to the Appropriation Bills. The Committee is willing to wear its share of cost cutting but to cut down by two-thirds the staff that has been allocated in previous years to carry out statutory requirements seems a bit beyond the pale, to put it mildly. The Public Accounts Committee is the Parliament's watch-dog. Therefore it is the people's watch-dog. The Committee is not particularly glamorous and does not particularly get the eye of the public through publicity stunts or having attention drawn to the work it does, but it is an important committee and it is important that the Senate's attention be drawn to the fact that its staff is to be cut by a massive two-thirds.

In concluding my remarks, I would like to quote again remarks by Ross Gittins because he made a most important point when he talked of how the media are now managed with regard to much of the information that is given on Budget matters. Senator Stone has pointed out in his foreshadowed amendment that it is simply not good enough for the Government to stand back and do nothing. He has itemised areas in which the Government should act. The quote from Mr Ross Gittins is as follows:

There is a subsidiary reason why the media and market reaction to the Budget was so approving. Mr Keating has converted the Budget lock-up from an aid to time-constrained journalists to an instrument of media management. Stage one was to exclude business economists from the lock-up . . . to cut journalists off from any source of independent professional analysis on Budget night.

Stage two was to fill this vacuum by supplementing the usual junior Treasury advisers in the lock-up with a bevy of deputy secretaries. These gents worked the tables assiduously-with opening gambits such as `there is not much to criticise, is there?'-trying to knock down objections before they got up. The subtlety of their technique seems to have stopped it working in my case.

As I said earlier, the Government seems to practice a variety of cargo cult economics. Like Mr Micawber, it keeps hoping that something will turn up. Senator Walsh knows that this is not so. He has pointed out that if something is not done the International Monetary Fund will come knocking on the door. It is the future of our country that we are talking about; the future of our children and our children's children that we are discussing. It is a matter of the gravest importance.
