I wish to support that amendment because it adequately summarises many of the concerns which the Opposition has been expressing, both in this debate and elsewhere, about our country's present position. We are used in this place-it is the same in the House of Representatives-to hearing Ministers focusing on isolated pockets of success to which they can point. I would like to point to some of the evidence of the deterioration of living standards in the lives of the people of Australia under this Government. That message has been widely understood in the community and the community is confused at the disparity between the rhetoric of this Government and the condition of the lives of the people.

I also want to refer to the enormous risk the Government has run with respect to the management of Australia, the great risk which is referred to in the foreshadowed amendment by Senator Stone, which relates to the enormous overhanging burden of debt which this Government has saddled us with. I also wish to refer to one of the most critical difficulties we face in getting out of our present problems; that is, the stagnant investment in Australia. If Australia were on the mend and about to burst out of the deficiencies which beset us at the moment, by now we would be seeing evidence of some of the investment the country so badly needs if we are to become a more productive nation. The figures are an appalling indictment of this Government and indicate that the country is not about to make the progress which is required.

I want to refer also to the trade union control of vital policy areas. That control is felt most, of course, in wages policy and with respect to the operations generally of trade unions. The movement seems to have a veto power over Government decisions. We saw that most recently in the May view of this Government that the present industrial arbitration system was defective because it was one-sided. The rules applied to employers. They could not successfully be applied to trade unions which did not wish to abide by the rules. We saw an attempt by the Government, through Minister Willis, to introduce legislation which would put effective enforcement provisions into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. We saw the Government back down on that issue very quickly. Post-election, we saw Mr Crean pronounce publicly that if the Government were to introduce legislation, it could not contain provisions which would improve the compliance provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The Government has backed down and accepted that direction-another indication of our perilous position.

Finally, I wish to refer to the fact that the country is living beyond its means in the sense that at both the personal and the government level we are spending at a greater rate than we can afford. That, of course, is the cause of our growing indebtedness at the personal and national level. Some frightening figures are now being produced about the level of personal and private indebtedness in this country. I note with alarm the fact that the Government's Budget suggests that there is no sign of the sort of productivity lift which would enable us to be confident that we will fight our way out of our present difficulties.

I return to the national debt or the nation's debts. I think the figure is widely understood in the community but it is worth referring to it again. On 30 June 1983, shortly after the Government came to office, the external debt was slightly in excess of $35 billion or slightly over 21 per cent of our gross domestic product (GDP). By 1987 the figure is just over $110 billion or 41.6 per cent of our gross domestic product. The growth in our net foreign debt is even more frightening. It is the debt which we owe, offset by our holdings of foreign currency. From June 1982 to June 1987 net foreign debt increased by more than five times. To go back to the date that I used for comparison originally, from the end of June 1983, after this Government took office, until June 1987, our net foreign debt grew by more than 3.6 times. That is a quite terrifying growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to analyse that for us?

—I am sure that the Leader of the Government in the Senate would like to analyse that. Perhaps he can tell us at what point he thinks that debt will stabilise. The simple point I wish to make is that the Government has allowed us to move to a perilous position under a series of Budgets in which it has increased the discretionary expenditure of government. The first two Budgets of this Government greatly increased expenditure. The Government failed to take action which could have been taken by a government without any great difficulty at that time to reverse some of the trends of that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to business investment, a matter which is of great concern to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. Private investment in plant and equipment has fallen in real terms over the last two financial years by 5.7 per cent in 1985-86 and by 3.9 per cent in 1986-87. Investment in non-dwelling construction has been much stronger, up by 22.8 per cent in 1985-86 and 15 per cent in 1986-87, but this has not been strong enough to boost total and business investment significantly. In 1985-86 and 1986-87 business investment grew by only 0.2 per cent and 0.9 per cent in real terms respectively and business investment as a share of our gross domestic product declined to a low of 9.7 per cent in 1986-87.

I would hope that the Minister at the table will take part in this debate. I think he would agree that if we are to solve Australia's current economic problems we need greatly increased investment in new industry in this country. The pattern so far is not one on which he could gain satisfaction or which points to the solution of our problems.

The main area which I wish to canvass in my contribution to this debate is the enormous difficulties which have been imposed on the Australian people during the term of this Government's office. It is very hard to relate the policy approaches of the Labor Party in Opposition and the promises that it made to the various sectors of the Australian economy with what has actually happened. I wish to refer to some of the areas which impinge upon the daily life of every man, woman and child in Australia and which mark the deterioration during the term of this Government. We find, for example, that real wages are declining under this Government. The Government will point to all sorts of reasons for that but the simple reality is that wage and salary earners are receiving increases in their incomes which are less than the increase in the cost of living. That may well be-the Government will say that this is-a necessary condition for Australia in 1987. That is a very glib answer and it ignores the responsibility of the Government for achieving that economic position. We have declining real wages in circumstances where the expenses of families are rapidly increasing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you devoted half of your Question Time to in the past few years?

—I am glad to see that the Leader of the Government is getting a little agitated. Well he might. The reality is that the Leader of the Government in the Senate has presided over a situation where there have been enormous difficulties for many people in Australia. Their housing interest rates have gone up, their house payments have gone up and their access to public housing has been restricted. I have made the point in the Senate before, and I am happy to make it again, that a government which came to office promising to solve the enormous housing problems which it had described as existing under the Fraser Government came to office with over 100,000 people waiting for public housing and today has a record number of over 160,000 people on the public housing lists. In other words, under this Government there are about an additional 50 per cent, another 50,000 to 60,000 Australians, who are seeking public housing and who cannot get it. They are seeking public housing because of the failures of policy of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sure that you were one of the members of this place who welcomed, when you came to government, the fact that the Government threw a good deal of taxpayers' money into the public housing pool in the 1983-84 Budget and 1984-85 Budget. That greatly increased expenditure, which the Government has sharply cut back in the Budget which is before the Parliament at the moment, did not solve the public housing problem because the Government's other policies forced more people on to the public housing lists because those people were unable to afford private housing. Over the last year we saw not only record high interest rates but also the lowest number of housing starts on record, with the number of starts falling 30,000 below the predicted demand. In 1987-88 housing starts are expected to fall up to 42,000 houses short of demand. It is very easy to roll off those figures, Madam Acting Deputy President, but I am sure you will agree that there is a human dimension to those figures, that what those figures mean is that there are 42,000 families who are seeking housing and who are unable to get it. In other words, under the policies of this Government of which these Appropriation Bills are a part, because they represent part of the fiscal failure of this Government, there are 42,000 families who would like to obtain a house but who will be unable to do so. They are part of the 160,000 Australians who are waiting on the public housing lists and who are unable to get a house through that means also. Home owners are paying up to 17 per cent more of their income on mortgage repayments than they were a decade ago-again, an absolute indictment of this Government's management of the economy and a very severe impact on the living standards of the men and women of Australia.

I will refer very quickly to some of the other matters which have been very much influenced by this Government and which have impacted on the living standards of Australians, and again these Appropriation Bills represent one element only of this Government's failure. When we left office in March 1983, the average rate of tax for a family on average weekly earnings was 17.5 per cent. The figure for the same family today, after the supposed tax cuts delivered by Mr Keating and by the Labor Government, is an average rate of 20.5 per cent. In other words, we have declining wages but we have an increasing share of those wages being taken by the Government in taxation. The weekly disposable income of an Australian family has been estimated to have declined by 31 per cent since the election of the Hawke Government. That is the human face of this Budget. The reality is that Australian families have seen a significant reduction of their incomes.

As to what they can buy with their incomes, it is not merely taxation which has affected them; the purchase of a car has become something which is more expensive by a factor of between 30 and 50 per cent. In other words, the normal family sedan has increased in price by between 30 and 60 per cent under this Government according to the make or model. The cost of petrol, an important part of the family budget, was promised to be reduced. Madam Acting Deputy President, do you remember that the Treasurer was going to reduce the price of fuel by 3c a litre? He has not done that. In fact, he has continually increased the taxation on fuel during a period of declining world oil prices and the result has been that we have gone from an average price over the last three months of the Fraser Government of 44c a litre to 55c a litre in the last three months of 1986. The figure, of course is now even higher. By dint of increased Government taxation to support this Government's endless enthusiasm for government expenditure, we have had a massive increase in that other element of individuals' budgets.

All of these areas have a massive impact on the living standards of the men and women of Australia. Health insurance is able to be afforded by a declining proportion of Australians. Again, this is an area of enormous change by the Hawke Labor Government, yet there are 100,000 Australians waiting in hospital queues. There is the need in this Budget to appropriate tens of millions of extra dollars to try to remove queues which did not previously exist. There has been a failure of the public hospital system, occasioned by the excessive burdens put on the public sector of the health care system by this Government. That is another area of failure. In regard to those Australian families that have sought to escape this area of failure by maintaining private insurance, there is a diminishing capacity to insure privately because of the sharp increase in medical insurance costs because of the policy changes of the Hawke Labor Government. These are the simple factual realities that Australian families face under the Hawke Government. More of the same is being imposed by the Appropriation Bills which we are debating at the moment.

The Government has now had to move to try to rectify the situation of the most desperate in the community by adding to one of the Fraser Government's social security initiatives, the family income supplement, by calling it a new family allowance for lower income families. Roughly 30 per cent of Australian families will get relief under this Budget through supplementary payments which will be paid to individual families on low incomes to relieve their desperate situation. I make the point that there is nothing in this Budget to ease the position of the 70 per cent of Australian families who do not fit the tight income tests of the new family assistance scheme. There has been a 30 per cent deterioration in the value of the family allowance received by 70 per cent of Australian families who face increased costs of mortgage payments, petrol, the cars that they buy to put the petrol into, and so on. All of these are increased costs, yet they see a diminution in the family allowance.

I find the attitude of the Government, as is evidenced by these Appropriation Bills and this Budget, towards Australian families astounding. The attitude is pathetic and wrong. The attitude has been adopted that those families which are not in real hardship do not warrant any assistance or any differentiation from the great mass of people in the community who do not have dependants. Yet the Institute of Family Studies has told the Government that a family with three children and on an income of more than $50,000 a year is no better off in terms of disposable income than a single person on average weekly earnings.

I make that point because families with children and on what are seen as relatively high incomes are being penalised by this Government. For example, some of them are having their family allowance taken away. Many Australians sit back and say, `Well, that doesn't matter, they're high income earners'. The simple reality is that those families are struggling, even on an income of $50,000 a year, to maintain the standard of living of a person without dependants who has an income of about $24,000 a year. The Budget and Appropriation Bills are not just economically chaotic documents; there is a socially chaotic approach, because 70 per cent of Australians with dependants are continually being squeezed more tightly by the failure of the Government to make any allowance for them.

The situation is one of declining real wages, high interest rates, costly and elusive housing, housing authorities that are unable to meet the demands of those on low incomes, queues at the hospitals, and the high cost of private insurance. I ask: what excuses can the Government offer? I sometimes hear Government senators suggest that the excuse is that the Government has concentrated its attention on the poor. I want to devote a couple of minutes to that suggestion. The simple reality is this: if one looks at the tests that were applied by Labor senators when the Fraser Government was in office, one will remember the speeches that were made continuously by people such as ex-Senator Grimes and present Government senators who were so supportive of the need to help the less well off in the community. Remember all of the attempts that were made to ram home to the Fraser Government the number of people who were living below the Henderson poverty line? The sad fact is that under the Labor Government the number of people who are living under the Henderson poverty line has increased. It has continually increased under this Government, and present estimates are that there are over two million people living below the poverty line, of whom 20 per cent are children.

There are 60,000 people who are homeless or very ill-housed, with 40,000 sleeping in the open or in refuges. Twenty-eight per cent of people living below the poverty line have mortgages, and they have been further crippled by the high interest rate policies of the Hawke Government. Of course, we have seen occasional breakouts by Ministers like Brian Howe and Gerry Hand, who have been critical of the growth in poverty under the Hawke Government. But when I make my assessment of the Budget, the Appropriation Bills and the matters that we debate in this Budget session of the Parliament, I am appalled at the fact that never has a single Labor senator come out in defence of the interests that they were so keen to embrace and for which they claimed to be the champions when they were in opposition. It is as plain as the nose on my face that there is an enormous problem for many poor people in this country. I note how long it is since I heard a Labor senator come out in defence of the poor.

Throughout this debate, of course, the Government's technique has been to blame the United States and, indeed, to lecture the United States on the fact that we in Australia are successful whilst the United States is the cause of our problems and is a failure. That is one of the thinnest arguments I have ever heard. Indeed, it is a very bold argument when one looks at the comparative statistics relating to Australia and the United States. It is true that if one accepts at face value the Government's Budget deficit, the Government can claim that it is outperforming the United States. The United States Budget deficit, in terms of its gross domestic product, is larger than Australia's Budget deficit. The Opposition welcomes that comparison. We think that it is very good that we have a lower deficit. But to suggest that in some way we are in a more secure position than the United States is to ignore the truth and reality.

Our foreign debt is about 40 per cent of our gross domestic product. Our foreign debt is becoming increasingly difficult for us to service, given our export performance. The United States has a foreign debt which is about 13 per cent of its gross domestic product. So if one compares the two economies, Australia is about three times worse off than the United States with respect to foreign debt. Business interest rates in Australia are about 13 to 14 per cent, whilst in the United States they are somewhat below 9 per cent. Inflation in Australia is running at over 8 per cent and in America it is a little over 4 per cent. Unemployment in Australia is over 8 per cent, as against under 6 per cent in the United States. Annual wages growth in Australia is about 6 per cent-double that of the United States.

When I talk about wages growth, I am not talking about growth in real wages. Real wages under the Labor Government are declining because inflation is higher than nominal wages growth. But that is part of our problem. We keep paying ourselves money, increasing wages, before we have earned the capacity to pay, thereby adding to our inflation. Our problem is about twice that of the United States in that area. In terms of purchasing power of individuals, the United States stands at the head of the queue and we are No. 9. I wonder how long Government Ministers will keep up this tirade of blame against the United States. I certainly accept that there are real difficulties which relate to the operation of the United States economy. I accept that the United States Government, like other governments in the world, does have to take remedial action. However, the suggestion by Labor Ministers that we in Australia have shown the way when we have so many bad marks against us is quite absurd. I believe that it is time that that canard was laid to rest. The fact of the matter is that our current account deficit is higher than that of the United States; it is estimated that it will be higher than that for the United States in the coming year. All of the basic economic indicators, other than that of our fiscal deficit, are really worse than those of the United States.

When the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, left this chamber he was showing some irritation. I think that in part that irritation related to the fact that he does not like being reminded that under his Government there has been a deterioration in the position of many Australians, not least those who are least well off.

In the few minutes that remain I turn to the positive proposals which the Opposition has consistently been putting forward. Those proposals were dealt with at greater length by my colleague Senator Stone who foreshadowed the amendment to be moved on behalf of the Opposition. We have been saying for the last two years at least that there are fundamental changes which have to be made by the Government. We say that the Government must reduce and restructure taxes. That can be done only through reducing government spending. In other words, we totally reject the sort of nonsense in which Senator Walsh indulges. We do not favour reductions of taxes without reductions of expenditure. We say that reductions in taxes are conditional upon there being reductions in government spending. We say that there must be reduced and less costly regulation of business activity. We say that there must be the restoration of law in industrial relations and a flexible labour market. We say that there has to be a rigorous control and reduction of business input costs, especially government taxes and charges.

I touch very briefly on the question of industrial relations reform. There is in fact an acceptable way out of Australia's current economic difficulties. There is a way to ensure that we can get back on to a path of increased living standards. There is a way whereby we can be more generous with the poor, both here in Australia and abroad. The only way that that can be done is to increase our national productivity. Reform of the labour market is an important element in achieving that. I make very brief reference to the confrontation at Robe River. In industrial relations terms that would be seen as a very negative confrontation. It is important to note that since the reform of work practices at Robe River output has gone up by over 100 per cent. In other words, the productivity of that enterprise has increased in terms of the output per person employed by more than 100 per cent. It has more than doubled. There are other less dramatic examples. I refer to the old Repco bearing plant in Launceston where employee share ownership is one of the various reforms that have been instituted since the change in ownership. Output has gone up by about 40 per cent. Who would deny that in many industries in Australia substantial productivity gains are possible.

I would like to conclude my remarks by saying that the essential task which faces this Government and which is not faced in the Appropriation Bills or in the Budget is in holding back the burdens of government but, at the same time, doing everything possible to increase the productivity of Australian enterprise and the Australian work force. It is only in that way that we will have less gloomy debates on these gloomy Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to speak to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88 and cognate Bills. I support the amendment which was foreshadowed by Senator Stone when he spoke in this debate. I also want to adopt the remarks of Senator Chaney, who has just finished speaking, when he put in context, as he did in some detail, the effects of this Government's policies on families in Australia. There have been wasted opportunities in the past two years. This Government has lived on borrowed money so that now the external debt represents about $25,000 for each Australian family. However, in the Budget Speech this year the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told the Parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's policy response-
to the economy-
has been innovative, strong and, most of all, right.
He went on to say:
. . . our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.

I want us to look at the fruit that in fact has been borne of this strategy. Under Labor the average unemployment rate has been 9 per cent in the time it has been in office compared with a rate of 6 per cent over the previous Liberal Government years. Of course, we should not forget that included in those figures is the very high youth unemployment. Youth unemployment is especially high in many areas of the country in which there are virtually no opportunities for young people to obtain employment, to get on with their lives, to get careers and to get some satisfaction out of being part of this community.

A great deal of money has been spent on make work schemes. I refer to Priority One: Young Australia and other schemes. About $1,500m has been spent on these schemes since 1983. That amount will be almost $2 billion by the end of this year. Sometimes, of course, we hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talk about the number of jobs that have been created. Of course, jobs are necessary. However, at the same time, it is very easy to talk about the jobs created and totally forget about those people who are being left behind. I refer to young people who are not able to get jobs and who do not have opportunities to get jobs and, perhaps even worse in many instances, those middle-aged people who lose their jobs and have no prospect of getting anything in the future.

Interest rates remain unacceptably high. Anybody who is paying off a mortgage will know what I am talking about without the necessity of my having to go into great detail. Health care cover has just about become a joke, except of course for those people who are sick. The Medicare levy has gone up, private health insurance rates have risen and, yet, there is less and less available from Medicare for those who are sick and more and more which people have to pay themselves. People who have had members of their families who have been ill can state only too well exactly how little one gets from the health care system that is in operation now compared with what was available in the very good health service when we were in government-a system in which people were able to get health care when they needed it. We never had a waiting list of over 100,000 people wanting surgery. Of course, the greater insult in that regard is that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) refers to those waiting lists as `booking lists'. I cannot think of anyone in this country who is on a waiting list for surgery who would not prefer not to be on that waiting list. However, that is how the waiting lists are referred to; as though surgery is something that one chooses, rather than something that is necessary.

There are over 160,000 families waiting for public housing. That is an all-time record. It has risen by over 60,000 in the past four years. There are many people living in caravan parks. Many people do not have accommodation at all. This is the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless. Not much seems to have been done really to take care of those people who have nowhere to live.

Inflation has been eating away at living standards. The cost of many of the quite basic items that people need has risen. The family assistance package has been referred to already in this debate. It was promoted again only today as something of which the Australian Labor Party is particularly proud. In looking at the raw figures one might think that some families would be substantially better off with this package. However, it totally ignores the number of families in need. I refer to the number of families in my electorate who have lost their family allowance and who are now trying to make ends meet on a lower income than they had before but with higher expenses. Senator Chaney just referred to the decline in the value of real wages and the extent to which taxation has risen-from 17.5 per cent of average weekly earnings when this Government was first elected to 20.5 per cent of average weekly earnings now.

When we take away the family allowance that people have we can get some idea of their situation. For those people who will get the family allowance it is nothing like what they have been led to believe. The reality is that they will be paying higher rates of taxation and they will be paying the increased costs of living, not to mention the erosion in living standards which has occurred prior to this package over the last few years. Many families now have a much lower standard of living than they had when we were in government and before Labor in fact had that responsibility.

This Budget is promoted as the first for Canberra-the Australian Capital Territory's own Budget. I agree that that is necessary, and I welcome it. However, I challenge some of the Government's stated objectives, not only nationally but in relation to the Territory as well. I remind the chamber that in Canberra the Federal Parliament has sole responsibility for local government. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and the Territories (Mr John Brown) is the only person who has responsibility. He is not accountable here, of course, but he has the responsibility. There is no local government or State government. We have been told that we must pay our way and that we must pay taxes similar to those in New South Wales and other States, but there have been some intriguing increases in taxation and revenue raising in this Budget as far as we are concerned, and it is to them that I wish to refer, under the heading of challenging the priorities of this Government.

We used to have various means of communicating with the Government. There was a House of Assembly. Certainly it did not have any legislative powers, but it was able to hold inquiries and communicate with the Government. The people of Canberra were able to put in submissions to the inquiries that it held and it could then make recommendations to the Government. That system, of course, has been abolished and not replaced. But other things have been abolished in this Budget. The Budget was used for this purpose under the rather cute guise of suggesting that some of these actions were saving money. They could save a few dollars, perhaps, but nothing significant. Having listened for so many years to the rhetoric of consensus and consultation, we have now come to the stage of having a dictator running the town. He was referred to as a benevolent dictator by one of the representatives of the Australian Labor Party in the ACT-perhaps he was just trying to be polite. There is not much consensus or consultation. I hear from many constituents that it is pretty difficult to get a reply from the Minister to letters and that they have asked for appointments to see him to discuss matters that they regard as important, but have not been able to get them.

Other bodies have been abolished, such as the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority Council. It was a council of members of this community, appointed in various ways, who were able to meet and convey views from this community to the Schools Authority on matters that are important in the development of educational policy and the way that our schools are being run. It was abolished in the Budget. I have heard from many citizens, and I have certainly heard from most parents and citizens associations, that they are displeased to have this means of communicating with the Government and of being able to say what they think about education taken away from them. The Police Advisory Committee has been abolished, as have the two health boards. They were set up only comparatively recently in the restructuring of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority. They existed for less than 18 months. These were boards which could discuss matters that were relevant to health in the ACT as well as the views of citizens, so that the Health Authority would know something about what the people of Canberra were thinking.

Another important means of communicating with Government was the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, set up in 1957. This Parliament has responsibility for the city plan of Canberra, and for making variations to that city plan and approving them. In 1957, Parliament set up a joint committee to inquire into proposals to vary the city plan of Canberra and report to the Parliament, and it is my belief that the Parliament has always accepted the recommendations of that committee and acted upon them. It was an efficient way for the Parliament to find out, for example, whether various changes to the road system of Canberra had to take place. In fact, the Joint Committee did more than that. It also conducted a number of inquiries of importance into the hospitality and tourism industries, energy, the metropolitan plan of Canberra, and into the Murrumbidgee River and the impact on it of this large community situated on the banks of that river.

The Committee's inquiries into the variations of the road system also enabled the citizens of Canberra to put in submissions about the changes being made and to put in submissions that related to the precise planning that was effected by the road system at which it was looking. It was not simply a question of roads going from A to B. The Committee was able to look at why a road was being put in or taken out or altered, to examine the purpose of the proposal. By that means, the people of Canberra were able to have a say in some of the planning decisions. I believe that the Committee undertook some significant inquiries, the most recent being the section 38 development in Civic, in that area adjacent to David Jones which is now to be a large shopping centre and office complex, and the parking structures that will go across there. That inquiry enabled many people who were very concerned about the way parking has developed in Civic and the way parking has spread into suburbs of Reid, Braddon and Turner, to express their view about the lead levels as a consequence of the traffic flows that have resulted from the developments in Civic. The Committee was able to make recommendations to the National Capital Development Commission about what it felt should be done in this area. But now that Committee has gone.

The Committee was initially replaced by the Infrastructure Committee of the House of Representatives. It was to look at variations to the city plan of Canberra and make recommendations to the Parliament. However, that meant that the Senate had to either rubber-stamp what came from that House of Representatives committee or set up an inquiry into the variations itself. That was impractical. The Senate moved that it should look at the city plan variations, and there is a proposal that the two Infrastructure Committees will sit together as a joint committee to look at variations to the city plan of Canberra. One might think that that goes back to what we had previously, but I suggest that it does not because the Infrastructure Committees have the prime responsibility of looking at relevant matters in the important areas of transport and communications. They will no doubt look at variations, but I suggest that they will have neither the time nor the ability to look at them in the same way as the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the ACT. This community has lost significantly by not having this means of communicating with Government, given that the Minister is the government in Canberra.

Senator Bishop referred to the 17 new taxes-one for every three months-that have been introduced since the Government came into office. However, there are quite significant revenue raising measures in the Budget that affect the ACT. They are certainly significant in the way they will affect the families involved in paying the fees. They certainly have significance to many in Canberra who are on low incomes and I think that they need to be specifically referred to, although they are not large sums compared to some of the Budget and expenditure items in these Appropriation Bills.

I refer first to the Government's decision to sell the Belconnen and Fyshwick markets. The Budget Papers tell us that they are worth $2m and it is interesting to note that the stallholders at the markets have offered to buy them from the Government for that sum of money, but they have been rejected. The Government believes, in spite of what it has put in the Budget Papers, that it will receive more than $2m from the auction of these sites, and it is after the money no matter what the consequences.

The reason we have these markets is that some years ago people in Canberra were not able to get fruit and vegetables at reasonable prices. A number of roadside stalls sprang up. Trucks would come particularly on Fridays and at the weekend and would sell fruit and vegetables to the people of Canberra at a price which was more competitive. As a consequence and because of the growth of these services, it was decided that it would be better to have a market where fruit and vegetables could be sold at a reasonable price, a market that was not extravagant in design and construction but which adequately served the purpose of stalls where people could go and purchase.

The Fyshwick market was built first and subsequently the Belconnen market. I suggest to the Senate that they have been extremely succussful in providing competition in the area of pricing of fruit and vegetables. I believe that they have been the pace-setter for the pricing of fruit and vegetables in other shops in Canberra and that the people of Canberra have benefited as a consequence. They can buy delicatessen items, fish, meat and fruit and vegetables from a number of stalls at these markets. One needs only to go there, particularly at weekends, and see the number of people who shop there to have some idea of the benefit which is obtained. These markets are to be sold. It is true that they are to remain in existence as markets for three years, but I suggest that after that it is very likely that they will disappear. Those who own the land will want to use them for some purpose which will be more profitable and the opportunity will be lost to the people of Canberra to continue to get these vital food items at a price which is reasonable and competitive.

The other interesting fund-raising measure which the Government has indulged in is charging a fee of $6 per week for pre-school children, to raise $1.02m; that is without knowing how many may be exempt from it. I understand there is a fee for pre-school children in New South Wales. That does not make it good. I think most people believe that pre-school is a very important part of a child's education, that it is part of the education system and that children ought to be encouraged to commence their education at pre-school.

Pre-schools in Canberra have the location, the grounds and the teachers provided. Everything else is provided by the parents. Many of them raise a great deal and pay quite considerable amounts so that our pre-schools remain as good as they are. There is now to be an additional fee of $6 per week per child. From the questions asked at the Estimates committee we have not been able to find out how the money is to be collected, whether additional staff will be put in for that purpose, whether teachers will be expected to do it and how it will operate. I can assure the Senate that it will be a hardship for many.

At the same time as this fee is being imposed on pre-school children, it looks like the Montessori pre-school will be closed. The parents want to have the three-year-old stream included, but the Commonwealth Schools Commission will not allow parents of pre-school children aged 3 to pay to have their children in the Montessori program. As everybody would know, the program for a Montessori pre-school includes children from the age of 3. The parents have not suggested that taxpayers generally pay anything towards the cost of the 3-year-olds being there. We find that the parents of other pre-school children will be charged a fee, but the parents are not allowed to pay for the 3-year-olds to attend the Montessori program.

In the Telopea Park School there is a pre-school. Children from the French pre-school go there. It is substantially funded by the French Embassy. It is a significant part of our education system from the point of view of the diversity of what it can offer. Last year 72 students were enrolled at pre-school. This year the parents have been told that only 40 children can enrol. I understand that that has been amended to 60 children. What reason can possibly be advanced for cutting back the number of children attending that pre-school? I wonder whether it is to centralise and control the education system so that there can be no diversity and no opportunities for advancement offered to children to do much more than they might otherwise be able to do. There has also been an attack on the Telopea Park School in that the tutoring program for music, which parents have supported, cannot continue because it does not comply with the guidelines. What we need in our education system is something somewhat more imaginative that gives people the opportunity to do more than the bare minimum of an education system. I am talking about government schools.

The other fund raising measure which has been introduced is to increase greatly the cost of the use of sports grounds, particularly for junior sports. It applies to all sports, but the impact is particularly significant for junior sports. One club which has written to me says that its costs for competition alone would be $1,656. In Queanbeyan one pays $2 to use the toilet blocks for junior sports; in Cooma one pays nothing to use the sporting grounds for junior sport; and in Yass it is $1 per registered player per annum and in Goulburn it is 50c. There is a fee in Canberra of $4.60 per ground for the morning sessions and $9.20 for the afternoon sessions. The club to which I am referring will be paying $1,656 for regular use which, with the Sunday use, would climb to $2,760. I wonder what genius dreamt that up? What do such people think the purpose of junior sport is about? Certainly, to an extent, it is to encourage those who have real talents to develop them but to a very significant extent junior sport is to give young people the opportunity to learn co-operation, teamspirit, fairness and good sportsmanship, to make friends outside the school setting and to learn to be a part of the community.

Who runs junior sports? It is the parents of the young people who give up their time to do this because they appreciate the value of it and the benefit to young people. This is being attacked by these fees which are being imposed. I mentioned that we had to pay our way, and we had to pay as does New South Wales. I have just mentioned one area where we are different. It might seem very small and insignificant, but it mounts up for the families who have to keep digging into their pockets.

Another area which is important relates to payroll tax. Until recently, the Australian Capital Territory rate of payroll tax has always been adjusted to keep it in line with New South Wales, but that is no longer the case. In New South Wales, the exemption level has risen to $400,000. In Canberra it is still $300,000. It is significant in that a business which might want to set up in Canberra, looking at this fact, may very well go to Queanbeyan, and not come here at all. It is a significant impost. Firms in Canberra which are paying at this rate cannot understand why they are suddenly being discriminated against and being used as an area of fund raising in the Australian Capital Territory. We need to diversify our economy. Everyone keeps talking about it. The Minister goes to conferences and talks about it. In one area such as this where it is quite significant, he will not adjust the level of payroll tax to make businesses in Canberra operate in a similar way to those in New South Wales. We are being disadvantaged.

The Department of Finance recently brought in a new policy that no government accounts were to be paid under 30 days even if they could otherwise be processed and paid. At the same time, businesses in Canberra are expected to pay payroll tax and group tax by the 7th of each month or suffer severe penalties. As I said, we have a Minister who goes to conferences and makes speeches. His vision for Canberra is a casino. He has not given us any indication of the impact that that will have on the restaurant industry, on the very important club industry and on the racing industry in Canberra.

The Minister wants a casino no matter what. But some of the other things that he could do in Canberra which would assist business and assist growth he does not seem to have time for. I notice that recently he paid attention to the application by the taxi industry for an increase in fares and he has attended to that. What about trading hours for Christmas so that shops can operate on the Saturdays preceding Christmas? We do not hear about that. The other day 2,000-odd people gathered in Canberra. Honourable senators might not think that that is very many, but it represented far more people than that as more than 16 organisations were present at a demonstration in Canberra where they said that they did not want a casino. The only means they have of communicating with this Minister is to go to a demonstration like that and set out their grievances. The Minister does not seem to be approachable in any other way. People want growth and development in Canberra so that we can have a wider range of opportunities for employment, but they do not see a casino as the answer.

We have not had any financial impact statement from the Minister which would explain why a casino would be of such advantage. It would cut back income from some of the other areas which I mentioned earlier from which income is presently obtained-the club industry and the racing industry. It is merely circulating the same money. We were told earlier in the life of this Government that we would receive financial impact statements for the things that were important that were affected by Government decisions.

The Minister should be applying himself to the question of why Canberra at one stage had the dubious distinction of having the longest delays for building permits of anywhere in the country. That is the sort of thing that needs to be tidied up so that business can operate more effectively and more efficiently in Canberra. The Minister should apply himself to looking at the payroll tax that exists in Canberra, to which I have already referred. We want an atmosphere in Canberra where small business is able to flourish. We have an ideal environment for small business. Distances are not great and for any business that wants to produce but which does not have heavy items to transport, Canberra is almost an ideal environment. It would be an ideal environment if only some of the hurdles that were placed before people were ironed out.

Tourism is important. I think everybody agrees that that area must be promoted, but it is not the only area in which we want employment opportunities in Canberra in the future. The Public Service will always be important as a big employer in Canberra. It cannot employ everybody who lives in Canberra; not everybody would want to be employed in the Public Service. We need to diversify and we need to make sure that young people have the opportunity of obtaining satisfying careers.

As I have indicated, my criticism of the Budget as it relates to the Australian Capital Territory concerns the fact that the Government has its priorities wrong. It is raising money from those who can least afford to be contributing it and it is not paying attention to the sometimes small details where things could be much improved and where business could do much better in Canberra if only those details were attended to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating cognately the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88, and Senator Stone has foreshadowed an amendment which I support. In thinking about the state of finance in Australia, I noticed, when reading the paper yesterday, that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that the figures released showed a $1.18 billion balance of payments deficit in October and that that provided further evidence of the continued improvement in Australia's trading position. However, I am inclined to agree with the Western Australian newspapers which state that it is a sign of the depth of Australia's economic woes that figures showing that the country is spending only $1.18 billion a month more than it is earning can be greeted with a sense of relief.

SPEECH.PARA: When we see deficits continually rising like that, it makes us wonder whether Australia, as a nation, is not going down the drain financially. If we, as individuals, kept on acquiring a deficit all the time, I believe that our bank managers would soon be on our trail, asking us what we were going to do about it, or declaring that we were bankrupt. These are some of the problems that are being faced in Australia at the moment. There is probably a need for tougher policies, tighter spending on the part of the Government, and business and wage restraint.

However, the matter that I want to raise in this appropriation debate is the importance of primary industry to Australia. Primary industry provides over 40 per cent of our export income and accounts directly or indirectly for one job in every four. The Budget allocation to the primary industry sector is $403m, which is down $56m from last year. So an industry which continues to provide over 40 per cent of our export income receives less than one-half of one per cent of total Budget outlays. The point to be noted is that that $403m is not all actual government assistance; transfer payments of industry levies are collected from farms.

The Federal Government continues to disregard the importance of this industry sector. Its lack of emphasis on rural Australia clearly shows that it does not understand where the majority of wealth in Australia is created. I was told that one of our Australian Labor Party senators was out west just recently. I was not there, but I understand that he said that rural producers have never had it so good. I would like to think of all the days and hours that people work, from daylight to dark, seven days a week. Of course, we all know that the unions would like a 35-hour week, so I just wonder how people can say things like that about our rural producers.

This Government appears to be preoccupied with technology and manufacturing. While valuable resources are being directed to these industries the ability of agriculture to reduce the nation's deficit is being ignored. More effort is desperately needed in our established primary industries. I believe that more funds should be allocated to rural industries. I suppose that, to put it another way, less money should be taken from these vital industries by cutbacks in various Labor budgets.

Recently I read an article entitled `Crisis on the Farm', which asked whether there was a rural crisis, and if so, how serious it was and what were the causes. The article went on to state that there was no doubt that our perspective of the problem would depend on whether we were city or country oriented, what area we lived in and what we thought of government policy.

Rural Australia is in trouble and, as far as I am concerned, very many people in the cities will also be in trouble because the cities depend to a great extent on rural industries doing well. They are the life-blood of the nation. Certainly there are very great needs in rural industries in Australia and they need our help and understanding. I wonder what would be said to be the cause of the rural crisis anyway. It could be the high interest rates, the increasing costs of farm implements, falling product prices, the exchange rate, world financial markets, poor economic policy, or the subsidies paid to farmers in Europe and elsewhere. It has been said, of course, that one of the causes could be that farmers have paid too much for land or that perhaps they have bought too much machinery. They are some of the things that are raised from time to time. But I doubt whether there is any single cause.

The crisis is not unique to Australia for it affects the Western world generally. Actually, I was interested to read in one of the papers that the European Economic Community is going to consider a new plan to pay farmers not to grow anything on part of their holdings in its drive to prevent the creation of vast new food surpluses. One must remember that it was only a few years ago that grain production was more or less in line with world demand and prices for farmers in the major exporting countries were satisfactory. Output was rising and being encouraged. Today, the barns are full and that is, I suppose, why the European Community is thinking about the plan to pay farmers to grow nothing. I suppose some people may say that that is rather an odd way of dealing with the problem. But certainly, there are large quantities of grain, butter and meat in Europe for which a ready market at prices equal to their production costs cannot be found. Naturally, those excess supplies affect the markets for Australia's produce.

We must realise that there are some eight million farmers in Europe and two million farmers in the United States. In Australia, there are about 170,000 farmers, which is really not so many when one considers that, in the past few years, 280,000 farmers in the United States have gone out of business. How have those events affected Australian farmers? In the first place, the prices for some products, such as wheat and barley, have fallen. Others, such as meat, have risen only slightly. The overall index of farm product prices shows that produce which sold for $100 in 1980-81 would now sell for $117. However, in the case of wheat, the figure is $94. Inputs, such as fuel and fertiliser, worth $100 in 1980-81 would now cost $159. In other words, despite some increases in production efficiency, farmers today are worse off than they were in 1980-81.

The Government does not seem to take all those figures into account. Still we have rising fuel prices which, in turn, means rising costs for all rural producers. The further out one lives and works, the higher the freight charges and the higher the cost of fuel itself. The collapse in the terms of trade, as it is called, has, indeed, affected the cash flow of farmers and their ability to service their interest and capital repayments. Overall, farm debts have risen from $4,000m to $8,000m over the past five years. It is a sad fact that for more than a quarter of Australia's farmers, the gross cash income in 1986-87 did not cover their farming cash crops and so, in very many ways, there is a rural crisis.
Recently I was interested to read in one of my local papers the presidential report to the Burnett district council meeting of the Queensland Grain Growers Association at Wondai. The President said:
There are many measures our government could take to assist Australian farmers if it was anywhere near as supportive of our interests as are the governments of our competitors.

That is one problem with which farmers in Australia are faced. Overseas, growers are subsidised to a great degree. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) would not take too kindly for a start to the suggestion of tax free fuel, or allowing us to buy our imported inputs at world parity prices, or giving us some relief from the burden of debts and high interest rates. They are perhaps some of the ways that people on the land could be helped in this crisis. Not only farmers but also people living in rural communities are suffering in the same way.

Quite a large area of my State is facing one of the worst droughts on record. Overall, 15 per cent of Queensland is drought affected. Nine shires, five part shires and 1,700 individual properties have already been drought declared. It is no wonder that primary industries in Queensland and, indeed, in other States, are in trouble. The United Graziers Association and the grain growers have requested the Federal Government to permit a 50 per cent rebate in local government rates and charges for drought declared areas.

The area around the Burdekin River in north Queensland is very badly drought affected. In fact, the Burdekin cane growers estimate this year's loss in production at $10m. It is many years since the mighty Burdekin River has flooded. My memory takes me back to years when all traffic to north Queensland was held up because the Burdekin River was in flood. One could not get over the river either by road or by rail.

Cattle numbers have been reduced, some completely and others by 50 per cent. Grass growth is poor and many properties are supplementing feed. All this is costly and very time consuming. If one lives in a State where droughts like that do not occur, one may not realise the problems confronting rural Australia. The sooner action can be taken by the Federal Government to assist our primary industries, the better our chances will be that a disaster in Queensland and in some of the other States will be prevented. I regret that the recent Federal Budget did little to improve the dire situation of rural industries. In essence, the Budget means for farmers a further decline of at least one per cent in real terms for farm income. Farmers will continue to face a domestic inflation rate and interest rates twice that of their major competitors, as well as bearing additional burdens of fuel tax and other excessive government charges.

As I said earlier, the Budget allocation to the primary industry sector is $403m, which is down $56m from last year. An industry which continues to provide over 40 per cent of our export income receives less than one half of one per cent of total outlays. Transfer payments of industry levies collected from the farms are included in that $403m. The Labor Government broke a promise to the wool industry by failing to continue to match industry funds for promotion. It has frozen its outlays at last year's figure, $35.4m, instead of the expected $50m.

Wheat funding is now almost negligible at $11.6m, but the decrease of 40 per cent on last year's outlays is due mainly to the near completion of the Port Kembla grain terminal. The Labor Government has offered sugar growers too little, too late. It failed to act with compassion and understanding during the industry's time of greatest need. Brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign revenue from producers is down slightly, and the Government has largely ignored the beef residue testing crisis, allocating only $500,000 at this stage for increased testing in the wake of complaints from the United States of America. There is little relief for the beef industry from the $30m costs which were a result of the beef residue problem. The meat industry, along with the other export industries, will be hit with an increase in animal and plant quarantine services to 60 per cent of attributable costs from 1 March 1988.

The dairy and horticultural industries will also be disadvantaged with the continuation of the unfair sales tax imposed last year on flavoured milk, fruit juice and wine. The continuation of automatically indexed fuel taxes will hurt all country people. Of course, it will hurt people everywhere throughout Australia. The current 20c per litre will rise by a further 2c this financial year. The Labor Government continues to decimate the fuel freight subsidy scheme and the further 50 per cent reduction to $8m in support this year will mean dramatically increased fuel costs for many people in outback Australia. Federal road finance, in real terms, is also down by 9 per cent and an even greater fall is projected for next year. It does not take much understanding to realise that country roads will continue to suffer disproportionately.

The Budget did nothing for rural Australia and is further proof to both country people and those honourable senators in this place who represent them that this Labor Government does not understand the value of the rural sector, which earns more than 40 per cent of export income and which accounts for one job in every four in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the three Appropriation Bills: Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88, and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88. Therefore, in essence, honourable senators are debating the Government's Budget because the Appropriation Bills are the essence of the Budget. The Budget was brought down several weeks before the events on the stock markets, which took place commencing on 19 October and which, therefore, have in many ways rendered the Budget irrelevant, to those on this side of the Senate, and it is certainly in need of dramatic change.

SPEECH.PARA: Even if the stock market crash had not occurred, the Opposition would have maintained, as it has since the day the Budget was brought down, that the Budget was entirely inappropriate for the time and for the dangers that we faced as a nation. As I shall outline later in my remarks, the Opposition has strong support for that view from the Government side of the chamber. I note that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is in the chamber at the moment. His remarks could not have been more pertinent when he referred to the inadequacies of the Budget, had those comments come from the Opposition. Although the Opposition will not seek to prevent the Budget being passed-that would be unthinkable-it has foreshadowed an amendment. The amendment, by Senator Stone, bears some repeating because it succinctly expresses the concern of the Opposition about not just the Government's Budget but also the whole economic strategy of the Government. For those reasons the Opposition has foreshadowed the following amendment:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(1) this Bill is part of a continuing pattern of failure by the Hawke Government to face up to the need for adequate and timely adjustment of the economy;
(2) this failure by the Hawke Government has heightened Australia's vulnerability to changes in world economic conditions at this time of crisis on world financial markets;

(3) because the Government has squandered time and resources while persistently running Australia into massive debt, our national economic options are now so narrowly limited as to largely deprive us of independent options; and

(4) the Government no longer has the scope to protect jobs, to stop the prospective rise in unemployment, to stem the continuing rise in numbers of Australians living in poverty or to protect the position of families more generally;

and therefore calls of the Government to revise its fiscal, labour market, taxation and other micro-economic policies with a view to providing a more appropriate economic framework to meet our current economic and social dangers''.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the words `social dangers'. The Opposition is not just discussing economic matters in this debate: Budgets are often thought to be just about arithmetic and figures but they also provide the framework and structure within which our society operates under the impact of the Government. The social dangers are just as real as the economic dangers facing this country. The two cannot be separated.

Last weekend the editorial in the Weekend Australian was interesting reading. It was headed: `The World we have known since 1945 is ended'. I seek leave to table the editorial of the Weekend Australian.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the document. The editorial makes some pertinent points and, in essence, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Although the United States has brought a prosperity to the Western world, the extent of which was unimaginable last century, this is unlikely to continue next century unless its own economy is strengthened. In the past 20 years, the Pacific region has arguably gained the most from the paternalism of the United States.
The article also states:
The United States supplied economic prosperity and then offered to defend it.

That is, to defend our region of the world and indeed the free world as a whole. The editorial then makes the point that the financial crisis of recent weeks has shown that our region of the world `can no longer presume that the United States will continue in this role or will even want to'. The editorial also states:
Faced with its own economic decline, the US may one day have to renege on its commitment to defend Japan, West Germany and South Korea.

The editorial then refers to the defence and balance of power implications in the region and all the related matters. No doubt, the world that we have known since 1945 has changed. At present it is in the process of very rapid change. I believe we are now on the threshold of seeing a change in the balance of economic power in the world and, therefore, other power shifts will have enormous implications for us, for our region, and for the world as a whole as we move towards the twenty-first century.
It was for that reason that Senator Stone, in introducing the debate yesterday-and I shall repeat the words because they are what the debate is all about-said:

It is the tragedy of this Government and of Australia under this Government that it has frittered away 4 1/2 years of office, particularly the last three years of office, without putting to right the fundamentals of our public finance and our balance of payments, and without attempting to break the growth of our international debt. Because of all those failures, the Government is now helpless in the face of economic events bearing down on us and Australia will be tossed around in the wake of those events.

The reason we have a continuation of those very problems is that the economic policies pursued by the Government, including the policies that were followed in the latest Budget, seem to take no cognisance of the major fundamental changes and the major fundamental dangers that are facing us and our region of the world.

In releasing his Budget this year, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) waxed absolutely euphoric about the great virtues of his Budget. The Australian media picked this up and it was conned in the most disgraceful way. Very few of the journalists managed to escape and to point out the reality of the situation; one journalist was Terry McCrann from the Melbourne Herald whose recent article, which should be compulsory reading for all of us, is headed `Sycophants of Keating delude us all'. What McCrann was saying in that article was that the Government had conned the media and, therefore, in the short term the public, into believing that we had a Budget that was appropriate for our times. It was helpful to find that not all members of Mr Keating's Government believed him. One of the major architects of the Budget, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, was not conned; he made some very pertinent comments following that Budget. For example, the week after the Budget had been released he said:
I'm worried that the Budget has been oversold and it will make the public and the Government complacent and think that we can slip back into our old slothful ways and we don't have to worry any more.

Senator Walsh also sounded, quite rightly, warning bells over the deep-seated problems in the economy. He pointed out that if we did not get our act together, we could well have the International Monetary Fund knocking on our door. He also hit out at the lack of what he termed political courage shown by his own Government in the social welfare area, by repeating a statement that he made at the Australian Labor Party Conference last year. He said--

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say anything about social welfare. That is your prejudices. You are putting the words in my mouth.
—I will quote the Minister. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I can think of 200 programmes that are not justified on social or equity grounds, but will not be abandoned because the Government does not have the political courage to do so.

Was the Minister not talking about social welfare-type programs? We on this side of the House have been waiting for the last two months for him to tell us what those 200 programs are. I look forward, in due course, to hearing what they are. A few days before the Budget, the Minister made another worthwhile statement. He said:
I fear . . . that though we have been going in the right direction we have not been moving as quickly as the externally imposed circumstances demand.

So there is confusion and disagreement on the Government side of the Parliament as to the appropriate economic policy to be followed. Senator Walsh has made his position clear. He does not think that the Government is going too well at all. Other very notable people in the community would agree with him. Professor Heinz Arndt from the Australian National University, said in a letter to the Australian Financial Review on 21 September, just a few days after the Budget, that the Budget reaction that had been brought about by the media was at odds with reality. He pointed out that if confidence in the economy should wane, the capital flowing into Australia would cease, that it probably would flow out, and that we would have a compounding of the enormous current account and balance of payments problem that we have. How right Professor Arndt was. A month afterwards precisely what he had feared came to pass with the stock market crash.

The Director of the Centre for International Economics in Canberra and former chief of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, and a very well respected economist, Dr Andy Stoeckel, said recently that the Australian economy was in terrible shape and faced recession. Again, how prescient that remark has proved to be. After 4 1/2 years of the Hawke Government we now have a tax burden which has increased inexorably in each of those years. As a country we now have the heaviest tax burden that we have ever had. As Senator Bishop remarked earlier this evening, over the last four years of the Hawke-Keating Government we have had no less than 17 new taxes imposed. That does not include, of course, the enormous increases in tax revenue within the whole multitude of other taxes.

We have had an enormous hike in the tax burden to fund an ever-growing appetite by government for more and more government expenditure. Although, again, some members of the economic and financial media have given the Government plaudits over its last two Budgets for reining in growth in expenditure-and that is very questionable-all the Government has done in the last two years is try to pull back a little of the enormous blow-out of spending that occurred in its first two Budgets, a blow-out in spending which has left the economy weakened and much less capable of dealing with the international economic problems that are flowing over and around us at the moment than should have been the case. We have had also-and these aspects are related-an enormous interest rate burden on investor and consumer alike. We have had an enormous blow-out in our national debt-that often does not get much attention because the foreign debt problem gets the headlines-at the Federal Government level alone over the last four years of a further $25 billion. Our foreign debt has blown out since this Government came to office, in gross terms, from $35 billion to $110 billion. Even if we net that to take account of our holdings of assets overseas, the increase is still from $21m to $85m, a four-fold increase.

In terms of the increase in expenditure that I was referring to, the increase in government spending has been very significantly understated because the spending financed by fees and charges is not shown in the Budget as a gross figure. Expenditure figures are netted out for that spending. Fees and charges collections, and the expenditure to match that, have grown since the last year of the Fraser Government, 1982-83, when the figure was $1.7 billion, to the estimate for this year, 1987-88 of no less than $4.1 billion. So the implication is that the real level of increase in government spending has been significantly understated.

I have only a minute or so before the adjournment so I would just like to say that whilst being critical of the Government we on this side of politics do need to present our views on what should be done. We have done that consistently over the past four years that we have been in Opposition. We have said that it is essential that an environment for investment and job creation be provided and the economic imperative is for greater incentive and an increase in productivity. The only way to achieve that is to have a totally different mix of fiscal, monetary and wages policies from what this Government is following. We must reduce the level of taxation and the overall tax burden. To do that we must reduce government spending. Senator Walsh uses the terms `voodoo economics' and `Reaganomics'. We are talking about a sustainable reduction in taxation enabled by expenditure reductions. We are not talking about trickle down economics and what Senator Walsh has been saying of the Opposition's economic policy is just a pack of lies. We need a reduction in the level of interest rates. We have to tackle the wage inflexibility which has retarded our economic growth for decades. We must lower our cost structure to industry through increased competition and through decreased regulation, and we must increase our productivity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the limitations on time. I am in a hurry to get away, as is everybody else, so I will not keep the Senate very long. I read an article on page 1 of the Canberra Times today which attracted my attention. The article by Karen Harbutt is headed `Hollow-head bullets now in police use'. I quote a couple of short paragraphs from that article:

SPEECH.PARA: All Australian Federal Police should now be carrying the ``shoot-to-stop'' hollow-headed bullets in their 38-calibre revolvers, replacing a bullet which police say was unsafe.
The article continues further down:

Anyone struck by the bullet will sustain greater injuries than they would have if struck by the solid-head projectile, formerly used by the AFP, because of the mushrooming effect impact has on the bullet. But police say it is because of that that the bullet is . . . safer . . .

I am not arguing whether that is true. I think perhaps it is but I am aware that hollow-headed bullets, or as they are colloquially known, dumdum bullets, do cause individuals greater injury than normal bullets that might pass through one of the limbs, for example. I spoke on this matter in the Senate some time ago. I just wonder where Australian society is going. In most of the major capital cities of this nation these days we see police on point duty, on traffic duty, wandering through the cities, carrying guns. When I see this I am forced to ask the question: Is Australia a violent society and is the carrying of guns by police necessary? I further ask: Has Australia become less violent since police started openly wearing firearms in public? Has Australia become safer since police first started wearing firearms in public? Also, we have to address a couple of other questions. Has the wearing of firearms by police forces across the country encouraged greater use of firearms in our society by those who seek to break our laws? I finally ask: Where are we going when we have to see this happening in our society today? As the arming of our police forces and other forces continues, where will it all end?
Question resolved in the affirmative.
