QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 18 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Has Australia ratified International Labour Organization Convention 107 on Tribal and Indigenous Populations; if not, why not, and will the Australian Government consider doing so in 1987, the 30th Anniversary of this Convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has not ratified International Labour Organisation (ILO) Convention 107.

In recent years ILO Convention 107 on Tribal and Indigenous Populations (1957) has attracted adverse criticisms in various forums because it contains a number of outmoded concepts, especially the emphasis on integration. The ILO now considers that revision of the Convention is necessary, in particular to shift the Convention's emphasis from the objective of integration to that of respect for the identity of indigenous populations.

This view is consistent with the Australian Government's policy of recognizing the fundamental right of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to retain their identity and traditional life style, where desired.

Australia has not ratified the Convention because of the outmoded concepts it contains. However, we have been active in the processes developed by ILO to review the Convention. Australia played a central role at the Meeting of Experts on the Revision of Convention 107 in Geneva in September 1986. The ILO Governing Body in November 1986 decided to include the revision of the Convention on the agenda of the International Labour Conference in 1988 and 1989.

The Australian Government supports the revision of the Convention and will work towards a revised text which can attract the broadest possible support. A revised Convention should be adopted by the International Labour Conference in June 1989, after which it would be open to competent national authorities to ratify.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 6 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under what authority is the Interdepartmental Committee on fees and allowances for clinical fees and allowances for clinical psychologists established.
(2) Are clinical psychologists salaried professionals, do they contract their services to the Commonwealth, or what other arrangements exist for the provision of their services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Interdepartmental Committee on Fees and Allowances (IDCFA) was established in 1949 by the then Prime Minister, the Rt. Hon. J. B. Chifley. The Committee makes recommendations to the Ministers for Community Services and Health, Finance and Industrial Relations on matters relating to the payment of fees and allowances to private medical, dental and allied health practitioners who render services on behalf of Commonwealth Departments and Authorities.

(2) Clinical psychologists are employed by a number of Departments as salaried professionals under the Public Service Act. Private clinical psychologists also provide services on a fee for service and/or sessional basis. Sessionally engaged clinical psychologists may also be employed by a university or similar institution and work part time for Commonwealth Departments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 October 1987 (Hansard, page 854), Senator Chaney asked Senator Button, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware of the settlement which followed the recent protracted strike on the North West Shelf project? Does he agree that this appears to be the case of the unions using their industrial muscle to force employers to concede wage increases which are way outside the wage principles? Is the Government planning to intervene in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearings expected later this week to consider the settlement, in order to ensure that the wage principles are adhered to? Will the Government push the very strong views just expressed by the Minister for Finance and ensure that only wage rises which are in accordance with the wage principles are granted?

In Senator Button's reply he undertook to obtain an update from the Minister for Industrial Relations on the basis of the nature of the (North West Shelf) agreement and provide an answer as soon as possible. The Minister has provided the following response:

The Government is aware that a strike on the North West Shelf construction project was settled following an agreement reached between the parties on 21 September 1987. The Government understands that as part of the settlement package, the parties would refer the agreement to the Western Australian and Federal industrial tribunals.

The package was subsequently ratified by an Anomalies Conference of the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission (WAIRC) on 16 October 1987, operative from that date. WAIRC Anomalies Conference involve representatives from the Confederation of Western Australian Industry, Australian Mines and Metals Association, Trades and Labour Council of Western Australia and the Western Australian Government's Office of Industrial Relations, in addition to the direct parties.
As the package is being properly processed in the appropriate industrial tribunals, there is no need for Government intervention.
